PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Consideration resumed from 5 November.
Consideration of Senate's request.
Senate's request-

Page 2, clause 4, lines 3 and 4, leave out ``and for all subsequent financial years'', insert ``, the financial year that commenced on 1 July 1987 and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, the financial year commencing on 1 July 1988''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the requested amendment be made.

The Senate has requested that the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 be amended to remove the words that would make the imposition of income tax a standing measure. A similar request has been received from the Senate in relation to the Bill that would impose the Medicare levy. While the Government holds to the view that there are sound reasons for making income tax and the Medicare levy standing measures, it does not wish to further delay passage of these Bills and the issue of income tax assessments which are dependent upon their passage. Accordingly, I move that the amendment requested by the Senate be made without modification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is just another example of this Government either not thinking through the consequences of its actions and/or just treating this Parliament as a rubber stamp of its actions. The lifeblood of this Government is the taxation it receives. It has been the highest taxing government in the history of this nation. When this legislation, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2), came before the House of Representatives, we said that we were not going to allow an attempt to deny the annual review of tax scales by the Parliament. The Government sought to put down legislation which would not require it to come back and account to the Parliament in regard to the rates.
—Sneaky.

—Absolutely sneaky. Because income tax represents well over 60 per cent of the total receipts of the Commonwealth Government and a large proportion of that was embodied in the legislation before the House, we demanded at the time-and moved an amendment-that those rates be dealt with annually. Those wiser heads in another place have determined that our argument was correct in not being prepared to allow the Executive arm of government to ride roughshod over the Parliament. The Senate accepted our argument and, as a consequence, this amendment was carried in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be another lesson to the Government not only to think through the consequences of its actions, but to consider the high rates of tax that it is dumping on the Australian people and to recognise that in this Parliament the Opposition will not permit it to allow those high rates of tax to run sine die without any reference to the Parliament. I am very glad that the Government has accepted the wisdom of our initial argument and that of the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 5 November.
Consideration of Senate's request.
Senate's request-

Page 2, Schedule, proposed amendment of sub-section 11 (1) of the Principal Act, leave out ``and for all subsequent financial years'', insert ``, the financial year that commenced on 1 July 1987 and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, the financial year commencing on 1 July 1988''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the requested amendment be made.

The Senate has requested that the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill be amended along the lines of the amendment to the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987; that is, that the words that would make the imposition of the Medicare levy a standing measure be omitted and that words be inserted that would impose the Medicare levy for only the 1987-88 financial year and, until Parliament otherwise provides, the 1988-89 financial year. I have already foreshadowed the Government's acceptance of the Senate's request for this amendment during the committee stage of the debate on the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remarks I passed in relation to the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) apply to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. We proposed this amendment in this House, but the Government rejected it. However, the wiser counsel of the Senate prevailed and recognised that this Government would not ride roughshod over the Parliament; that it had a duty to account to this Parliament in regard to rates, levies and taxes, not simply to legislate to apply these measures sine die so that at any time it could change them at its whim rather than at the determination of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning we have seen the spectacle where not only the legislation itself but also the running of the Parliament is out of control. I will not dwell on that. In the past we have been critical enough of the leadership of this Government. Not only has the Government now sought, through its legislation, to deny Parliament the opportunity of reviewing rates of taxation and of reviewing the levy referred to in the Medicare legislation to which the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) just referred but also it has paid no regard to the proper chairmanship of this committee. I simply say that if the Government had listened to the clarity of thought and the strength of argument of those on this side of the chamber in regard to arguments on taxation we would have a damned sight better Government. However, at least we have been able to force it to come back and account to the Parliament in regard to the rates of taxation which have made it the highest taxing government in the history of this nation. The Government will be called to account annually for that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1987
BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1987]
Debate resumed from 29 October, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill concurrently with the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —These three Bills-the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill-come before the House with the support of the Opposition. Many people probably will think that these Bills deal with the freight compensation scheme between the mainland and Tasmania, but they do not. They are concerned with oil legislation and relate to a scheme which I shall describe. Primarily it is compensation for freight disadvantages that are borne by refiners who do not have the good fortune to draw their oil stocks from Bass Strait into refineries in the Western Port area and have to carry them to their refineries in other parts of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills comprise a package of measures which are proposed as a consequence of the Government's decision to deregulate parts of the crude oil market from 1 January 1988-a move supported by the coalition and a move which will bring about major changes in the oil industry in this country. The main purpose of the Bills is to ease the transition from a regulated to a free market and to ensure equity among refiners.

The crude oil marketing arrangements as they exist at present fall into three main categories. The first is the crude oil allocation system-a scheme introduced back in 1965 to provide producers with a guaranteed market for their oil and to give each refiner-marketer a share of indigenous production. The existing provisions date from 1 January 1985. All production from small ventures-that is, up to 50,000 barrels a day, other than Bass Strait producers-and the first 350,000 barrels a day of Bass Strait output are allocated to refiner-marketers in proportion to their market shares of major refined products. Condensate, which is a product similar to oil, and Jabiru crude, from the North West Shelf area, are not covered by this scheme. The latter, because of its remoteness, is available both for export and domestic sale. Production in surplus to that required by the allocation scheme may be exported. As people will know, last year we exported somewhere in the vicinity of $300m worth of oil from this country. The Customs Tariff (Stand By Duty) Act 1985 enforces the refiners' obligations to use the allocated domestic crude by providing penalty import duties on light crude and products.

The second category is the import parity pricing mechanism, which we have all heard about and of which I suppose few of us know the detail. It works something like this: sales of allocated crude oil are based on the import parity price which is calculated by the Government from a formula which determines the price which Australian refiners would have to pay overseas for oil of similar quality. An import parity price is determined for each producing area. The formula takes into account the price for Arab light or its equivalent, the costs of shipping such crude from the Arabian Gulf to the refinery, an allowance for the quality differential of the oil, the exchange rate of the Australian dollar against the United States dollar and domestic freight allowances.

I turn to the third category. The Bills we are debating this morning-the Bass Strait coastal freight adjustment Bills for want of a better way to describe them-partially reimburse refiners remote from Bass Strait for the higher costs of shipping the oil to those refineries. The allocation sales of Bass Strait oil since January 1987 have been subject to a surcharge of 29c a barrel, which is determined at 65 per cent of the coastal freight allowance component of the import parity price. The proceeds are redistributed from a trust fund to refiners in proportion to movements of allocated Bass Strait crude, freight costs for shipping and actual pipeline costs. So the moneys collected from the industry, which are redistributed back to the industry, are not taxpayers funds.

The transitional arrangements imposed by the Bills are interesting. The Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill provides for the collection of the Bass Strait coastal freight adjustment levy at December 1987 rates into 1988 from those refiners who have not met their allocated obligations by January 1988. Some of them have not taken up their full allocation and will not have taken it up by the end of December. The Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill removes the liability on Bass Strait producers to pay the Bass Strait freight adjustment levy on exports and free market sales of crude oil made on and after 1 January 1988. Finally, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill will allow disbursements from the freight adjustment trust fund to be made at the end of January 1988 to producers and refiners.

The Bills are intended to be repealed in 1988 following the finalisation of all outstanding payments and disbursements. As I said, the coalition supports the Government in the move that it has taken because this is a necessary step to give effect to the deregulation of the oil industry up to the refining stage. Many of us are wondering about the effect of deregulation. Deregulation will have the effect of placing crude oil in the same category as any other commodity-one which the seller will need to package, promote, establish a price for, and develop a market for. Australian oil producers, who currently provide over 80 per cent of our domestic oil needs, will be able to sell their crude oil at freely negotiated prices and volumes. Australian oil refiners will be able to buy their crude oil and other refinery feedstocks from producers here or overseas who offer the best deal in terms of quality, price and delivery.

This will mean some interesting scenarios for Australia in the new year. It is interesting to see an article in today's Australian. Those who are interested in oil should look at that article because it says, `Prices sinking in a sea of oil'. It is anticipated that there will be an oversupply of oil next year and that the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is looking to increase production and the article deals with how that will affect price. It says:
Forecasters are reworking their 1988 estimates.

It should be remembered that oil remains the main fuel in most industrial countries and accounts for some 40 per cent of all energy consumed, but there has been a downturn in international economies and less travel. The article contains interesting figures of the number of Americans who are expected to buy motor cars, and so on. This will probably mean that demand will not grow as rapidly as was thought, with the oversupply, overpumping and the buildup in stocks of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries which has taken place in the last eight to nine months because of the threat of interrupted supplies due to the strife in the Middle East. Prices could fall and crudes become available to Australian refiners at far cheaper prices. It will be interesting to see whether that eventuates and what benefits might flow to consumers in this country.

All of us, regardless of where we stand in this Parliament, will be concerned about the high price of petroleum products, and I shall comment on the extent to which governments of both political persuasions have seen the oil industry as a mechanism for raising revenue. If one looks at the components that make up the consumer price index, one sees that the area of the index that has moved the fastest in adding to the increase in the CPI is transport costs. A not insignificant role in that movement in CPI transport costs has been played by increases by Federal and State governments in taxes on the oil industry.

It is interesting to look at industry reaction to deregulation. The oil industry, with some minor exceptions, is clearly divided into three broad camps. There are those in favour of deregulation, including the refiners-BP, Shell, Mobil and Esso-and the Bass Strait producers, Esso and BHP. It is interesting to know who might be the beneficiaries of this change. I looked recently at the Review of Business Regulations on the Indigenous Crude Oil Marketing Arrangements of the Business Regulation Review Unit dated April 1987. Its concluding comment was:
On existing forecast production levels, the balance of relative advantage is likely to shift towards producers over the next five years.

I can see why domestic producers would favour deregulation and the refiners-primarily BP, Shell, Mobil and Esso, which are closer to the primary source of domestic production in Bass Strait-would also favour it. As I have said, the refiners argue that deregulation will enable the Australian oil industry to respond more quickly to changing circumstances. It will allow Australian refiners access to more competitively priced crude oil and feedstocks and will increase their efficiency and make them even more competitive internationally.

Shell and Petroleum Refiners Australia, which is the Mobil-Esso concern with refineries at Geelong and Altona in Victoria, will continue to take the bulk of their feedstocks from Bass Strait because they are both connected by pipeline. The producers argue that deregulation will benefit industry and the community through increased economic efficiency and investment incentive.

The deregulation group maintains that oil exploration will be virtually unaffected by deregulation. I certainly hope that that is the case. When this House debated the cash bidding legislation and also the resource rental tax legislation, much comment was made by Opposition members as to our worries about the declining amount of exploration taking place in off-shore areas in Australia. We hope that that turn-around will speed up the level of exploration that will take place, because with a declining self-sufficiency, regardless of the fact that demand in Australia for petroleum products may be lessening slightly, there will still be a large use of oil in this country. With a drop in domestic reserves in Bass Strait there will be a window of crisis in the near future.

If we want to continue to use oil products, they will have to be supplemented by imports. The cost of imports needed to maintain existing levels of usage is estimated to be in the vicinity of $3 billion to $4 billion. That cost will have to be added to our balance of trade at a time when it is not in a healthy state, to say the least. When the figures released yesterday indicate that all is not well, all of us want to see greater exploration in this country.

It is partly because oil exploration is governed by a variety of factors, such as the tax regime, as I have mentioned, oil prices, prospectivity and access to acreage, that Australian refiners, it is argued, have a strong incentive to seek secure sources of supply at home. I certainly hope that is the case. Interestingly, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd argues that a free market is likely to attract exploration from substantial overseas groups. BHP has been leading the charge in the utilisation of dollars to develop exploration capacity overseas. One hopes that perhaps if BHP sees some benefit in others coming here to explore for oil it will be prepared to invest its shareholders' funds in the development of exploration potential in Australian off-shore areas. I sometimes wonder whether BHP is having a bob each way.

In any event, the smaller to medium producer-explorers, such as Santos Ltd, disagree. Santos claims that the free market will transfer funds from small producers to large refiners which, in turn, will reduce funds available to small producers for investments, including exploration ventures. This will lead to the rationalisation of shipping and fewer calls at inland producers' ports. It will force small producers to make additional investments in infrastructure such as storage at delivery points and marketing teams to operate on the world market. In contrast to the large refiners, the small producer-explorers do not have marketing experience and expertise on the world stage. It will also remove the security, that is the allocation system, which small companies need to explore in otherwise uneconomic areas.

The coalition went to the last election with an oil policy which in part reflected the concern that we had about the small producers. Our policy was to phase out the crude oil allocation system which, as I have said, has been in place for some considerable time except for the small producers. One of the detailed papers given at the Australian Financial Review's energy seminar recently was delivered by a Mr Nicholls from Hartogen Energy Ltd. It was particularly pertinent. He made the point that the small producers in this country have a role to play because small producers, given the right incentive and encouragement, can become large producers. We want to ensure that, whatever mechanisms and tax regimes we put into place, we provide the incentive for smaller producers to become larger producers. If they are domestic Australian companies, then the community, taxpayers and investors will be far the richer. We should not discount the importance of the small producers. If the deregulation system is put into place we must keep an eye on small producers to make sure that their role in the market-place is assured.

I note with some interest that the Government has not formally stated how it will ensure that the small producer's product will be uplifted and refined. It seems to be operating on wishful thinking. I am aware of no formal arrangements between the Government and the major refiners to ensure that the product of small producers will be taken up. It is reported in the Australian today that the International Energy Agency forecasters are reworking all their estimates because there will be large over-supplies of oil in the new year. There will be the temptation for refiners to get the product at the best possible price. One does not blame them for that. This could well mean that smaller producers in Australia, having no given way in which to sell their product in Australia, miss out altogether. All of us will be watching that with interest. The Go-vernment has not said anything at all about small producers. There are no formal arrangements that I am aware of for the product of the small producers to be taken up. I will be interested to see whether the Minister, when he responds, can throw some light on that particular point, because I think it is important. The discussions I have had with the smaller producers, and indeed the larger producers, indicate that they also are wondering how it will work. It may all sort itself out, but I think that point needs to be kept in mind.

The third group comprises refiners such as Ampol Ltd and Caltex Australia Ltd which, with refineries further from Bass Strait, favour the present freight equalisation scheme, but realise, I suppose, that it must go in a deregulated environment. Indeed, the primary beneficiary of the freight compensation scheme that we are debating would be Caltex, and its view is that it has to work out a system whereby it can deal with the added freight costs. It is an interesting coincidence that an article appeared today on the Ampol annual general meeting which was held yesterday. There was also another article in the Australian newspaper.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very interesting article.
—I note that the honourable member for Franklin is in the chamber-a man who is well known for his views on and interest in the oil industry.
—And the honourable member for Deakin.
—Look, we have another one. The honourable member for Deakin is well known for his long association with, and investment in, domestic oil production in this country, a man who was there--
—He has already done that.

—I notice that the honourable member for Macarthur is giving him a wave and applauding his efforts. It is good that we have in the Parliament such people who are concerned about these issues. It is interesting that very few people are on the speakers list for this debate. Yet governments rely to a large degree on the massive amounts of tax they draw out of the oil industry. All of us in this chamber receive many representations from consumers about the costs of fuel. Yet very few people in this chamber seem to want to take the time to try to understand it all. I come back to this article in the Australian in which the comments of Sir Tristan Antico, the Chairman of Ampol, were reported. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The argument emerging between the refiners about how the maximum wholesale price is derived comes down to whether the non-Melbourne based refiners will be compensated for the costs of freighting Bass Strait crude to their refineries when the refiners in Melbourne have cheap access to Bass Strait crude via the Bass Strait-Melbourne pipeline.

It was that argument that led in earlier days to the establishment of this legislative mechanism to compensate for the freight disadvantages that had been suffered. Interestingly, the article goes on to discuss the arrangements under the new deregulated system that will start on 1 January. It quotes what Ampol, Shell and Caltex believe. It is quite interesting that there are variations in the stands that all of them are taking. There is not time now to go into any detail about that, but I commend that article to people who are interested in the matter.

I wrote to the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) because I have been somewhat critical of the fact that it has not yet stated how it will determine the maximum wholesale price. Today, I got a letter back from the Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority. I will read that into the Hansard record:
. . . I advise that the Authority has not determined how it will approach its tasks in relation to petroleum product pricing after indigenous crude oil prices have been deregulated.

Submissions from and consultations with refiners and other interested parties are presently under consideration. It seems unlikely that our methodologies will be determined until some time in December; any such determination is likely to be of an interim nature, to have regard to the development of trading in indigenous crude oil.

So no decision has yet been made. If one looks at this article in the Australian one can see that the industry is putting contrary submission to the PSA. All I can say is that we have deregulated up to the refining stage but we are still highly regulated in the marketing stage. We would like to hear from the Government how it believes the whole system will work. It is going half way with deregulation but not the whole way and we are all left up in the air. The Prices Surveillance Authority obviously does not know exactly what will happen.

Of course, we are dealing with a product which is subject to the vagaries of world supply and international conflict, so there are many aspects that have to be considered. I do not know whether the Government has fully considered all of them yet. The Prices Surveillance Authority does set a maximum wholesale price for petrol, which is adjusted to compensate for changes in crude oil prices, the United States exchange rate, freight costs, wages and so on. It allows the oil refiner and wholesaler a reasonable mark-up. The wholesale price is uniform in all capital cities. For example, if the wholesale price is 51c, on top of that must be added the State government franchise fee, which in Victoria is 4.24c a litre, and a gross margin for the seller of, say, 4c a litre. This would give a normal price in Melbourne of between 59c and 60c a litre. Of that 59c or 60c, the Federal and State governments together pocket 33c while the crude oil producer takes 8c. When the retail price is discounted by 10c to 49c, the governments and producers still take their combined 41c. This leaves the refiner with about 5c and the reseller with 3c. The refiner has forgone 9c and the reseller 1c. The situation where a service station franchiser has paid the usual contracted price for a load of petrol and an independent station down the road has bought a surplus stock of petrol from the same company on the same day for several cents per litre less is not likely to change for the better in 1988.

With deregulation, prices are likely to fluctuate by even wider margins, and more frequently. Companies will be free to buy their crude oil wherever they want and pay the lowest price they can find in the market. Australian crude will have to be priced competitively and the price will have to be adjusted frequently to follow movements in the world market. The change may reduce the consumer price of petrol slightly, by 1.3c per litre estimated by the Minister for Resources back in June, but deregulation will make it very difficult for the Prices Surveillance Authority to check supply costs of crude oil, a major component of the final price, so a major killing on the spot market may not result in lower consumer prices. I issue that warning.

In future, fluctuations in consumer prices are likely to be much sharper because supplies will vary more in origin, price and cargo size, causing changes in actual cost of the refined products. Speculative behaviour in the supply of petrol may further exacerbate price movements. Indeed, the Australian Consumers Association (ACA) notes that deregulation should be good for the consumer, if it does really give us cheaper petrol. The ACA has called on the Prices Surveillance Authority to assess the performance of each oil company on a yearly or half-yearly basis to ensure that the maximum wholesale price has been calculated correctly, and to reduce the maximum wholesale price closer to the average retail market price in the area.

Of course, the oil industry goes further. It claims that greater stability and competitiveness would occur if the wholesale marker price were removed. Indeed, I have some sympathy with that position. The industry claims that this would allow the Prices Surveillance Authority to exercise the same degree of security over petrol prices as it does over other consumer sensitive products-indeed, why is it that we must treat oil so differently from other products?-and would be more consistent with the deregulation of the crude oil market and with the widely accepted policy of making the Australian economy more responsive to and integrated with the world economy.

The industry rejects any suggestion that it will be in a position to exploit the public. Factors restraining such exploitation are: strong competition among refiners and among resellers for their share of a market which is growing by one per cent per year, competition from product imports, and the very effective-although there are some question marks over this-trade practices legislation in Australia. It will ensure that deregulation will create far stronger competition at the refining level. One hopes that the consumers will get the benefit.

The big losers if all of this discounting continues are the service stations. What will happen in Australia is that there will need to be a greater volume throughput in service stations around this country. I believe we have in the vicinity of 10,760 service stations. The number of service stations will decrease over time and we will need to see greater volumes going through service stations. But this new change will create greater pressure for that rationalisation to take place.

The Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce says that the service stations and the public would not benefit by a simple removal of the wholesale marker price. It says that wholesale prices offered by oil companies must be available to every retailer, not just some of them. If the present price discounting continues, there is every likelihood that service stations will go out of business.

The coalition parties welcome the drive towards deregulation of the oil industry. It is necessary, but it does have risks. However, the issues which have arisen as a consequence of deregulation are exceedingly complex ones. As I have said, we have witnessed the different positions which the oil companies are taking about how the wholesale maximum price should be set by the Prices Surveillance Authority. The main beneficiaries would appear to be the large well-established companies which already have the infrastructure and expertise to compete on the world stage. The effects on smaller companies, especially oil producers and retailers, as well as the consumer, will need close monitoring if no one is to suffer unduly. The coalition parties believe that perhaps the crude oil allocation system should be retained for small producers. I would like to hear in the Minister's response what arrangements will be made-if there are to be formal arrangements-to ensure that the product of small producers is taken up and refined.

Another important point is that State governments should be encouraged not to intervene in the pricing system. If we have a national pricing system, which I think should be reviewed in any event, and substitute that with all the States getting in and having their bit as well, we will end up in a bigger mess than the one we are already in in terms of oil pricing. State governments ought to keep out of it and not get involved. There is nothing worse than seeing a product as essential as this to Australia's economy become subject to the interfering hands of the States as they try to get their cut. It makes it very difficult for those who want to sink capital into developing refinery capacity and so on. I think that in the longer term it would be a retrograde step for the States to move wholesale into the setting of prices in the oil industry.

The role of the PSA in the oil pricing area requires examination and probable abolition. Perhaps there should be an examination of some mechanism whereby the Federal Government can maintain a monitoring role in the oil industry. Of course, that has yet to be determined on this side of the House. At present, we do not believe that the current system is working well. Oil exploration is governed by a variety of factors such as the taxation regime. Earlier, I referred to cash bonus bidding and the resources rent tax. A whole range of issues affect the investment of companies in the oil industry in Australia. Many honourable members - the legislation will be passed with the support of this side of the chamber - are looking very closely at the deregulation of the oil industry up to the refinery stage to see what happens. As I have said, the oil industry is not a national industry; it is an international industry. We are affected by what happens in the OPEC area. It can be seen that OPEC, in its next round of price setting in early December, may maintain the price but seek to increase volumes. As I understand it, the result could be to place more crude on to the spot market. As I have said earlier today, the deregulation that will be part of the Australian oil system after 1 January could mean that refiners here may be able to pick up cheaper oil on the spot market, but that will not mean necessarily that those prices will flow through to the petrol pump. That is partly because of the massive take by governments in this country.

In the couple of minutes remaining to me, I draw the attention of honourable members to an interesting little graph that gives a breakdown of the price of petrol in this country. The wholesale maximum price as set by the Prices Surveillance Authority is 54c. The graph shows that 35c of that is taken up by government taxes and charges. As I have said so often, if we are to continue to tax petrol as we do now, we ought to be looking far more carefully at its consequent economic impact on the CPI. This country is suffering an inflation rate which is three times higher than that of some of our major competitors. We have seen in the past that there are some benefits in taxing petrol, because of conservation aspects, but, at the same time, we must weigh that against the economic impact and the flow through to the CPI and the inflationary impact that that has. I seek leave to table the graph.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. We support the legislation. It is a necessary consequence of deregulation. This legislation is not about the Bass Strait compensation scheme, which will be a debate for another day. I thank the House. I hope that those who have listened and who will continue to listen to this debate will take some interest in the oil industry. We can be certain that in the next six months the oil industry in this country will become the subject of intense speculation and public discussion. All of us in this chamber ought to be aware of what is going on.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel somewhat of an infidel entering the debate this morning. When one looks at the speakers list one sees that it is one New South Welshman versus three Taswegians. On those numbers alone I think I am guaranteed to win. The Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill are a package of measures to enable the implementation of arrangements for the transition of marketing of Australian produced crude oil from a regulated to a deregulated or free market. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who spoke immediately before me in this debate, went to some length to point out some of the perceived benefits that will flow into the Australian economy from this decision. I support him in those comments. The Government obviously welcomes the Opposition's support for these particular measures.

SPEECH.PARA: The transitional arrangements will be known as the Bass Strait freight adjustment scheme. This scheme provides partial compensation to refiners for the cost of transport by sea or pipeline of allocated crude oil-that is to say, Bass Strait crude oil purchased at Western Port in those volumes and at the import parity price determined by the Government-to their refineries for processing. The amount of compensation is based on the actual transport cost incurred by refiners in transporting their allocated oil from Western Port to the refineries. So there are no hidden charges, no hidden taxes; it is all up front and everybody knows where he is going.

As the House will be aware, the present crude oil allocation scheme will terminate on 31 December this year and be replaced by deregulated marketing arrangements from 1 January 1988. Notwithstanding the comments that have been made by the honourable member for Bass about the position of the Prices Surveillance Authority in trying to establish the correct procedures that will operate for the future, the Government is of the view that the necessity for implementing these sorts of proposals have been demonstrated. The support from the major oil companies in Australia is there. As I have indicated, I believe that this legislation will lead to benefits to Australian consumers.

Under the existing marketing arrangements, refiners are subject to the requirements of the crude oil allocation scheme, under which they are obliged to lift over a calendar year an average of 350,000 barrels of crude oil a day from Bass Strait and the total production of crude oil from other producing areas, excluding, of course, Jabiru. Each refiner is required to purchase a share of the total allocation obligations, with the share determined according to its market share of sales of specified petroleum products. Crude oil purchases are made at the prevailing import parity price for the relevant producing area.

I would like to make one or two observations about the import parity pricing (IPP) system that operates in Australia at present because, again, the honourable member for Bass made some comments about this matter. We should never lose sight of the fact that this particular system was put in place by a previous conservative government and this Government has chosen to maintain that system in operation. Continually to come into this place, as a number of speakers do, and claim that this particular mechanism is the cause of all the problems in the oil industry and is keeping consumer prices extremely high is not, I believe, a true reflection of the position. I ask honourable members to take that point into consideration when making their contribution to the debate on the question of pricing petrol products.

Refiners who are underlifted against their Bass Strait allocation obligations as of 1 January 1988 will need to clear their underlift in 1988 before being permitted to purchase Bass Strait crude oil on the free market. This has come about because it is possible that a number of refiners may not have lifted their share of the 350,000 barrels per day by the end of this year. Therefore, there is this need to implement some transition arrangements to ensure equity between all refiners. Obviously the Government is not in a position to try to facilitate one refiner's advantage over another.

The amendments proposed in the three Bills provide for four major things: firstly, that the levy on liftings by refiners that have not met their allocated obligations continue to be collected into 1988 until those obligations are met; secondly, that when all refiners have met their lifting obligations the Minister will set a nil rate of levy and thus effectively terminate the scheme; thirdly, for removal of the liability from the producers to pay the levy on exports and free market sales after 1 January 1988; and, finally, for the disbursement of the funds in the freight adjustment trust fund that have been collected under these arrangements.

The Government envisages that the three proposed Acts will be repealed in 1988 following finalisation of all outstanding payments. Something has to be said as to why the Government is moving from the allocation to a deregulated marketing arrangement necessitating the Bass Strait freight adjustment scheme. The Government is pursuing this because in its view, and I believe that in view of the fact that the Opposition supports the legislation it must be a view supported on that side of the chamber, this scheme will generate a number of benefits for this country. This first and major benefit, of course, is that it will produce a greater efficiency in the use of the nation's oil resources. I think that is of paramount concern in an area where quite clearly the supply of Australian oil is fast dwindling from a number of sites.

I support the comments that the honourable member for Bass has made about the need to try to stimulate further exploration. However, unlike him-and I think I argued this point when I followed him in a previous debate on oil matters in this place-I believe that the scenario is in place through the resource rent tax regime to encourage rather than discourage the explor- ation for further oil supplies in this country. As honourable members would be aware, the oil in Bass Strait, because of that very point I am making, is of a comparatively high quality. It is low in sulphur and high in gasolene content, and by exporting this high quality oil and importing greater quantities of lower quality oil for use in our refineries, we are stretching our oil resources further. I believe that is an appropriate way to go in approaching a conservation policy for Australia's oil reserves.

There is also the possibility of a trade benefit in this arrangement being put in place. Finally, another possible benefit from deregulation is a reduction in the price of petrol, perhaps by 1c or 2c a litre. Our friend on the other side the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) is going to contribute to the debate shortly. I am sure that is something which is near and dear not only to his heart but also to the hearts of all honourable members of this place and to all consumers of oil products in Australia.

A further telling argument for the move to deregulated marketing arrangements is that quite simply, as I have indicated, we are running out of Bass Strait oil. Production is slowing every year, and when the end of production looks imminent, obviously there will be a push from overseas for Australia to move to a free market. It would appear therefore that this is inevitable. If it is inevitable, perhaps the Government should make arrangements to ease into that position so that the consumers are not kicked in the teeth all in one go. I believe this is what the Government is endeavouring to do. The Government believes it is best that we deregulate as early as possible and thus gain any benefits as soon as we can. In this way we will be able to prepare our industry structure for that inevitable day when our Bass Strait oil resources are exhausted and we must resort to an open market.

This argument is being advanced when we look at the whole concept of the import parity pricing system. No doubt members of this place have received from time to time over a long period letters, telephone calls and inquiries from consumers asking why petrol prices are going up, why we have all these fluctuations and what this import parity pricing system is. I think it has to be said, and this needs to be recorded yet again, that if that system was not in operation the effect of simply taking and using all Australia's oil resources without a conservation policy, and perhaps selling them at a much lower price-obviously we could do that in this country-would be fine for that time while the oil reserves lasted. But when we came to that crunch time, that inevitable day when those reserves no longer existed and we had to swing to a greater reliance on imported oil products, the price of which is likely to be much higher, then the shock that would go throughout the economy would obviously be far more sustained. Its effect, flowing through to the consumer price index increase and a range of products, needs to be addressed and the consideration therefore of the Government is that we cushion those effects by having an IPP policy, by taking a very strong approach to conservation in terms of Bass Strait crude oil and also by encouraging further exploration.

I conclude on a couple of points in response to issues raised by the honourable member for Bass in his contribution. Firstly, let me say that I also support him wholeheartedly in his call for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to look to Australia in which to invest in exploration for oil resources. We have seen the Big Australian, as it was once known, going overseas in a number of areas. I suggest that that company should play a leading role in its own country by leading the charge for further exploration and that it should endeavour to conserve Australia's oil reserves. Secondly, with regard to the taxing question associated with oil products, I have to say to the honourable member for Bass that clearly all governments would, if at all possible, like to see the lowest taxation regimes put in place if they could sustain their outlays and responsibilities in government in providing a range of services. Of course, through some of the taxes and even through the 1c a litre levy for the bicentennial road development program and so on, the Government is benefiting all Australians by having extra resources available to put back into service provision. I am talking about roads, the national highway program and a variety of other things that exist within both the electorate of the honourable member for Bass and my electorate as well as throughout Australia. We have to weigh up a disincentive that some people might perceive of a levy or additional tax regimes against the greater community benefit that comes though improvements in transportation systems, in networking and so on around Australia.

As I said at the outset, I believe it is appropriate that all members of this House are as one in support for these Bills. I think they will provide, as a transitional arrangement, a very strong working arrangement in the Bass Strait. We certainly look forward to the announcements of the Prices Surveillance Authority as to how the changed arrangements will operate after 1 January. We also look forward to continued exploration for additional resources in oil for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) said there were three Taswegians following in the debate, the reason being that we were conned. We were not conned --
—There are only two good ones.

—Two good ones, yes; I beg your pardon, and a third one. No, I had better say three Tasmanians, and the reason being that we thought this debate was on the freight equalisation scheme. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) did too. He can smile but he thought so too. He thought it was about freight between Tasmania and this other island, Australia, and that is the reason he got involved. I am sorry that I am speaking before the honourable member for Denison, because I cannot come back at him and at what he says about me and about petrol pricing in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Denison had the audacity to say, `The honourable member for Franklin has been talking about the price of petrol for 12 years, and what has he done?'. What a horrible, nasty thing to say. Never mind, I will come back at him later on that. It is interesting to see the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) at the table, because I think he issued a Press release during the week and said that we should use liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) more than we have been, and I agree with that. But the Minister also made a few caustic remarks, such as, `I have heard that speech from the honourable member for Franklin about 15 times'. I always say that it is a shame we have not used LPG as much as we should have. I was in a taxi earlier this week and I said to the driver-I tell the honourable member for Bass that he should always talk to taxi drivers --

TALK.START.PARA: —They support you.

—They all support me, as do the pensioners and other people in Australia, because I tell the truth. I said to the taxi proprietor, `What do you use-LPG or petrol?'. He said, `Bruce, if I didn't use LPG I would be out of business'. That is in Tasmania where the price of LPG is about 10c a litre more than it is in Victoria and New South Wales. The problem is always the freight component and the fact that we do not have the storage capacity, et cetera. However, I agree with the Minister: we should introduce legislation in this country to make it absolutely necessary for a certain proportion of motor vehicles registered on the roads in Australia to use LPG.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people get confused with the oil industry and that is probably the reason why there are not many speakers in this debate. It is a confusing issue; it is confusing to consumers; it is confusing to politicians, and it is confusing to everybody in Australia. I forget the amount of LPG that we export to Japan. The Japanese are laughing all the way to the cookers because they cook with it and use it in their motor vehicles. And they are saying, `What are those silly Australians doing with it?'. LPG can be used in a motor vehicle. It is efficient and non-polluting, although it reduces power a little. One does not need to change spark plugs so often or to change the oil, and LPG is efficient. One of the manufacturers-I think it was Toyota; forgive me if I am wrong-introduced an LPG-driven vehicle and regrettably it was a failure. There are options on differentials, options on gear boxes, options on the types of seats in motor vehicles; we have all the options except the option of having an LPG-driven vehicle or a petrol driven vehicle. Toyota introduced such a vehicle with just the option of LPG. People started to read that it was dangerous and that LPG could not be bought, et cetera. As a consequence, the motor vehicle was a failure. Would it not be a sensible idea for the manufacturers of motor vehicles in this country, with the push and power of governments, to say, `All manufacturers in Australia should make, say, 25 per cent of their vehicles LPG driven or have the alternative of petrol driven vehicles.'? If this were to happen we would conserve our petrol and we would also be able to utilise our LPG. That is just a suggestion about which the Minister talked during the week and I think it is one that could be looked at very seriously. It would greatly assist consumers in Australia.

We are deregulating the industry up to the oil refiner. Again I compliment the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) on the work he has put into his shadow portfolio. He has detailed this matter and has spoken about what will happen if we do not conserve, if we do not get our refiners to refine or if we do not continue oil production in this country. We will be in strife. I only hope that this move will be successful. We have talked about consumers and the Prices Justification Tribunal or the Prices Surveillance Authority. The letter from the Chairman is interesting in relation to what will happen to oil pricing after 1 January. Consumers will benefit, but the poor old service station proprietors, the suckers in the game-if honourable members do not mind my saying that-the pawns in the game, the people whom consumers blame for the price of petrol, are innocent bystanders. I have been critical in the past of the oil industry and oil companies. I am the first to agree that we need oil refining in this country. We need a vibrant continuing oil industry and we need oil companies which provide employment opportunities. And governments need their taxation. This Hawke Government needs its taxation. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that it was stealth at the petrol pumps when the Fraser Government was in power, but the Hawke Government has not been able to stop the stealth at the petrol pumps.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have got worse.
—Prices have got worse. Instead of the price of petrol going down, it has gone up.
—It has gone down in the rest of the world.

—The price has gone down in the rest of the world, but up in Australia. The Government cannot look at the Opposition and say, `When you were in government, the Fraser Government introduced import parity pricing and the price of petrol went up'. It went up as a result of world shortages at that time. We needed to conserve petrol and to explore. I did not like the price of petrol going up, because it affected the consumers of Australia, transportation and a lot of things. Regrettably, it had to be that way and that is what happened. However, the Government has not been able to stop using it as a mechanism for raising taxation to support some of its schemes. Many people suffered as a result. We need a very vibrant industry. The honourable member for Bass said that he hoped that deregulation would assist. He said, I repeat, that it would help the consumers. That is the important part. It we can reduce the price of petrol in Australia in a fair way it will be advantageous to the city of Hobart and the State of Tasmania. The honourable member for Denison is yawning. Fancy yawning when I am making a speech! That is typical.
—Hodgman never would have.
—The former honourable member for Denison would not be yawning; he would be supporting me and saying that we need cheaper petrol for the people of Tasmania, including the people of Hobart.
—He was a fighter for his people.

—Yes, he would not be yawning. Never mind. I found an article in today's Australian most interesting, especially what each general manager of the oil companies had to say about the future pricing mechanism for oil. What they all say is different; none of them agree. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: An Esso Australia Ltd spokesman said the company would prefer not to have a maximum wholesale petrol price.
`We never reach maximum price anyway, and we're usually at a discount of about 4c to 5c a litre,' he said.

The Prices Surveillance Authority fixes a maximum wholesale price for petrol in every capital city. Each State government then adds its charge and that is the wholesale price to the service station proprietor. He pays for the petrol, which is, say, 54c a litre, and he puts on his margin and then sells it. My argument has been that the price varies in every capital city. We talk about all Australians supporting the oil industry. We need a vibrant industry; we need the taxation revenue from it; we need to make certain that we will be self-sufficient in the long term and that we will not be dependent on Arab countries or other people who could torture us and have us over a barrel at any given time. We need to be self-sufficient in this country. But then all the little devious actions start to occur. Oil companies find that there might be a glut of petrol in one of the heavy volume areas in Melbourne, so the price dips below the wholesale price. That is exactly what the man from Esso said happens-`Regrettably, we are always selling petrol between 4c and 5c a litre below the wholesale price'. But the country areas of Australia, including Tasmania, always pay the full maximum price. There is no discounting for them. That is where all the problems occur and that is something which we should look at. When we get back into government let us bring back some fairness into the oil industry, particularly at the retail level. All Australians should get a fair opportunity to buy petrol at a fair price if they are to pay a high price for the good of this country.

I support the legislation. I could say a lot about it, but I will not. I hope that after 1 January the legislation will be in the best interests of the refiners, the consumers and those poor old service station proprietors who lease their service stations and all of a sudden are attacked left, right and centre. People say that there are far too many service stations and that there are roster systems, et cetera. All the poor devils are trying to do is survive in a market-place that has been created by oil companies. Once upon a time a service station was built on every street corner. The oil companies knew what they were about. They were buying cheap real estate and setting up service stations left, right and centre. All of a sudden, it was necessary to rationalise. Now it is necessary to have big multi-service stations and cut out all of the small people. I do not know what we will do with them and their employees. I do not believe that to cut them out altogether would be the only way we could get cheaper petrol. I do not believe that in its entirety. It is something that should be looked at very seriously and debated in this Parliament with the good will of all members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The history of the measures to which the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill relate is important to understand. The oil import parity pricing scheme was introduced by the former Fraser Government for a number of very appropriate reasons. At that time there had been a rapid surge in the cost of imported crude oil and as a consequence there was a huge price differential between the prices being obtained for imported crude and oil being produced domestically through Bass Strait. In fact, at some stages the price differential was extreme. Local crude would be produced at around $2.80 a barrel and the price for imported crude was around $40. As a natural consequence of that, domestic demand for local crude soared and there was a real prospect of a too rapid depletion of local resources and the threat of circumstances arising in which Australia would be totally dependent on overseas sources for oil imports. So the former Government acted to introduce a system of import price parity for local oil to ensure that that circumstance did not arise.

SPEECH.PARA: Times have changed. It is now seen as appropriate-and the Government believes it is appropriate-to change our policy settings. What has been occurring is a gradual decline in the amount of the available Bass Strait resource, so that different policy responses are required. In response to this necessity the Government has decided to deregulate the Australian crude oil market. This will have a number of effects which have been discussed by previous speakers in this debate. I note that both sides of the House are of the view that the benefits of this move will exceed the possible detriments. Certainly it seems that the benefits will include two things. First, the move will permit the most efficient use of the available resource, including potentially the export of some component of Bass Strait crude, which is of a very high quality. Secondly, it will impact in a slightly reduced price of petrol at the pump, which is something that everyone will welcome.

We now have a number of pieces of legislation which are necessary to operate as complementary measures until the ending of the scheme. The crude oil import price parity scheme operated in such a way that all refiners were required to take a proportion of oil from the Bass Strait oil fields. Naturally that meant that those refiners closest to the Western Port site would have a clear cost advantage. Oil refiners in Melbourne would be able to obtain their crude from the Bass Strait field at much lesser prices than those in Sydney and, of course, particularly those in Western Australia. A scheme was evolved in which a trust fund was established whereby the cheaper refiners-those able to access cheap crude-were required to pay into the fund to subsidise the costs of refiners who were more distant from the Bass Strait oil fields. With the end of the import parity pricing scheme, there is no longer a need to maintain that price mechanism because now all refiners, wherever they may be in Australia-Perth, Sydney, Melbourne or wherever-can draw from whatever sources they see fit. They no longer have an obligation to import any percentage of Bass Strait crude or, indeed, crude from any other source at all. So we have a situation where there is no necessity for a scheme to exist to even up the transport costs of that crude. The three Bills before the House, in effect, end the oil freight equalisation scheme but provide for transitional arrangements so that those refiners who have not yet discharged their current obligations can do so. From next year there will be a completely free market in crude oil.

The pricing effects-and I suppose this is the area where the ordinary consumer is most concerned-will be such that the average consumer will get a small but significant benefit in the reduced cost of petrol. It has been estimated that the pricing effects of the introduction of a free market in crude will represent between 1c and 1.5c a litre to consumers. The Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) has estimated that amount to be 1.3c. For the purpose of this debate I will use that as an estimate. The actual effect of the end of the transport levy scheme-the trust fund arrangements which I have just described-will have an average impact across Australia of no discernible amount at all. Naturally, one would expect that because, the trust scheme was completely funded by the industry. With the removal of the scheme, there will be some advantages to those areas which have access to Bass Strait crude more cheaply, particularly Melbourne. There will be slight rises in some other places where refineries have previously been subsidised for such part of the crude oil trade that they will still be obtaining from Bass Strait crude.

An estimate has been made of the effect of this. For example, the Sydney market will bear a one-sixteenth of a cent increase in the cost of petrol. That is because the local refiners in Sydney who were previously using Bass Strait crude and were subsidised for receiving it will no longer be subsidised. To the extent that they draw on that Bass Strait crude, they will have to pick up a small additional cost. But it is only one-sixteenth of a cent compared with an estimated 1.3c a litre benefit.

I come from Tasmania and I am most concerned about the Tasmanian impact. Of course, Tasmania has no local refinery and was thus not linked into the levy scheme. Therefore, the effect of the removal of the scheme will have no significant impact at all in Hobart. It may mean that petrol imported from Melbourne will be marginally cheaper and that petrol imported from Sydney will be up to 0.05c a litre more expensive. But, on average, Tasmanians will get a benefit of approximately 1.3c a litre at the petrol pump in cost reductions, and that is something which we should all be pleased about.

I cannot leave this debate without some comment and a smile, I suppose, at the expense of my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith). He expressed in a most delightful way what many members of the House on this side feel about petrol pricing, particularly in Tasmania. In Tasmania we make the greatest State contribution to the cost of petrol anywhere in Australia. There is a 7c a litre surcharge imposed by the State Liberal Government. The honourable member for Bass said that State governments should not interfere in the oil pricing situation. In a product so essential, he said, the interfering hands of the States should not add to the problem, as they want to get their cut. The shadow spokesman was speaking in the context of the States not being involved in trying to double up on the response of the pricing authorities. It is appropriate to note that in Tasmania the State Government has had its hands in the till, adding to the cost of petrol in the State.

When perpetual complaints are raised by the honourable member for Franklin about petrol prices, it is strange that his criticisms are never directed where they should most appropriately be directed, because the only element of the petrol pricing scheme that exists at the moment which is not uniform throughout Australia is State charges. It is in that area where the Gray Liberal Government has imposed taxes on the ordinary consumers of petrol and they are much higher than those imposed by any other State administration throughout Australia. It is a pleasing aspect of this debate that both sides agree that these Bills are appropriate and a correct response to the difficulties we are facing in the rundown of the Bass Strait oil fields. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) for participating in this debate. The Government welcomes the Opposition's support for this package of Bills dealing with the Bass Strait freight adjustment levy. The honourable member for Bass expressed some concern about the future role for small oil producers and small oil producers being disadvantaged following deregulation. It was clear during the Government's review that it would not be possible to maintain a system for on-shore marketing which sets prices artificially higher than those prevailing elsewhere in the market. It was decided that the best way to provide support for these producers was for the Government to seek assurances from refiners that oil producers producing less than 5,000 barrels per day would continue to have their output lifted in a timely manner and at fair market related prices.

SPEECH.PARA: From the number and nature of assurances received, the Government is confident that these producers will not be unfairly disadvantaged. However, under the free market small producers will have other options available apart from selling to refiners. These options will include the opportunity to sell to larger producers and pipeline owners or having them act as marketing agents; secondly, using the services of commodity brokers or trading companies; thirdly, forming selling co-operatives or consortia; and, fourthly, by exporting their own oil. Small producers and others may well find opportunities in a free market which were not available or considered in a regulated market. The Government will be seeking to ensure that formal commercial arrangements for the sale of crude oil produced by small producers will be entered into prior to the introduction of the free market on 1 January next. The terms of these arrangements, naturally, are a matter for commercial negotiation. In the course of these commercial negotiations the Government expects small producers to explore the full range of possibilities available to them for disposal of their output.

Some discussion has also taken place on the role of the Prices Surveillance Authority as the appropriate body to set maximum wholesale prices for petrol to ensure that consumers get a fair go. That is the Government's view and it is committed to that objective. However, it is not for the Government to impose on the Prices Surveillance Authority a mechanism for determining prices in the deregulated crude oil market after 1 January. The Prices Surveillance Authority is studying the matter, as was mentioned by the honourable member for Bass and as is provided for under its charter. It is acknowledged that the Authority is taking into account the content of submissions from refiners, State governments and other interested parties.

I turn to the question of petrol discounting. From time to time in this place we hear many suggestions that government should intervene to stop discounting. I suppose in a way discounting of petrol has become very much like supermarket specials. The discounted price of petrol long term could not be maintained without affecting the viability of service stations-I am sure all honourable members are aware of that-or, alternatively, without reducing the level of service available to customers. We also know that the brand loyalty of petrol purchasers is highly responsive to quite marginal changes in price. In that sense it is a highly priced sensitive market in respect of brand loyalty. The old saying in business that the most fickle kind of loyalty is price loyalty is clearly evidenced in the sale of petrol. People will do all sorts of things to move to other brands or other outlets for relatively minor changes in the retail price. To put it in perspective, the indicative international retail price of petrol in Australia is 55c a litre-the price varies in some parts of Australia-in Canada, 49c; in the United States, 41c; compared with Japan at 123c; Italy, 138c; Norway, 103c; and the United Kingdom, 88c a litre. Much of that information is already known to honourable members and generally to those involved in the industry.

I want to take a little further the point made by the honourable member for Denison in respect of the State take from petrol sales in Tasmania. The differences in petrol price between capital cities are attributable mainly to the influence of price discounting and to State government business franchise fees. The franchise fees are levied on wholesale petrol sales throughout Australia, except in Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory. For the record, the franchise fees for leaded premium grade petrol at 1 September 1987 Sydney, 3.53c; Melbourne, 4.35c; Adelaide, 2.51c; Perth, 4.17c; and Hobart 7.15c a litre. In Darwin the figure is 3.5c a litre and in Canberra 3.53c a litre. With the exception of Western Australia, the State franchise fee in cents per litre in Tasmania is more than twice the fee in any other State. So there is some relevance in the point made by the honourable member for Denison.

There is one other matter on which I shall conclude my remarks. Those of us who have been here a little longer know full well the zeal with which the Secretary to the Treasury at the time, now a member of another place, pushed through the bureaucracy and Cabinet, with the support of the Government at that time, the introduction of import parity pricing. We all know that the effect of that during the life of the Fraser Government was to quadruple the Federal fuel take. The Federal fuel related revenue quadrupled in that period and the price of petrol trebled. Any comment that comes from the Opposition in respect of Federal revenue from fuel has to be seen in that context and placed in that perspective. Although I listened to the words of support expressed by the honourable member for Bass for this legislation, which is welcomed by the Government, I have to tell him that the Opposition has a problem. If the Government were to adopt the kind of proposals put forward by the Opposition-the abolition of a range of taxes and the suggestion of a considerable reduction in the Federal revenue take from fuel-then at the same time the honourable member has to suggest where other alternative revenue will be produced or what specific government services will be abolished. The effect would be to increase considerably the deficit, but it is not in my view an argument that will stand examination. I thank honourable members for their support for the legislation and commend the Bills to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
