DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987]
Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill with the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation and its associated Act, introduced in the dying days of the last Parliament, contain the most significant range of amendments introduced into the social security legislation of this country for many years. It has been the role of the Opposition over the last five Budgets of the Hawke Government to emphasise on every occasion the fact that social security and the costs contained therein must be one element of the total budgetary process which requires the most close and detailed examination. From time to time we hear members of the Australian Labor Party complaining that the Opposition is without heart and without sympathy for those in need. Nothing could be further from the truth. But at times such as these, when the people of Australia, as a nation, have absolutely no alternative but to look most carefully at all aspects of government expenditure, it goes without saying that social expenditure must be examined in detail to ensure that those most in need get first priority.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will be supporting this legislation because it contains some very necessary and far-reaching reforms, in the context of not only access to benefits but also some worthwhile changes such as the family allowance supplement. Honourable members will be aware that for many years we have had in place the family income supplement. That has now been replaced by the family allowance supplement, better known as the FAS. The objective of this new supplement will be to increase the benefits for low income families. All families with incomes of less than $300 a week will be entitled to receive the FAS. The effect will be that children under the age of 13, for example, will have their allowances increased from $17 to $22 a week. Children between the ages of 13 and 15 will receive $28 a week-increased from $17-and dependent children over 16 not receiving an educational allowance will receive the same rate, $17 a week.

The problems, however, of maintaining children have not been adequately addressed. The Australian Institute of Family Studies has estimated the cost to be about $36 a week for a five-year-old and as high as $89 a week for a teenager as of March 1987. Assuming that those figures are correct-they have certainly been produced by an organisation which is respected on both sides of the House-one would have to say that the current increases in the FAS are nothing to get carried away about. But under difficult circumstances, such as those we are facing, any improvement must be supported.

The wider issue which must be examined by the House in the context of this legislation is precisely what we are trying to achieve. What should the objectives of family income support be? The Social Security Review issues paper No. 1, entitled `Income Support for Families with Children' made four observations which are worth noting. It said that the objectives of family income support should be, firstly, horizontal equity to provide a fair share for all families; secondly, vertical equity to provide adequate support to low income families; thirdly, intra-family equity to provide resources to the parent primarily responsible for the children's care; and fourthly, incentives to provide family assistance which does not discourage parents from work force participation and income earning. Most people would support those four principles or objectives of family income support policy. It is in that context, therefore, that we must examine the proposals contained in this legislation and, as I said, in the associated legislation introduced a few months ago.

The effects of these two Bills will be to change profoundly not only the social but also the economic impact which low income Australian families can make upon our society. The point is not made often enough that future generations-nay, the very survival of this nation-will always depend on our capacity to create, to build and to maintain our family structure. It is a matter of grave sadness that in the last decade or so we have seen a steady but determined breakdown of the structure of family life in our society. We have seen a significant increase in the divorce rate. One of the reasons people get divorced is economic pressure. They simply cannot cope. Others get divorced because they probably expected more out of marriage than the institution is able to offer. The sad reflection of all this, irrespective of people's reasons for divorce, is that it leaves hundreds of thousands of children often in a state of poverty or near poverty. This Parliament must relate to the problems which have been created in debating this legislation today.

Whilst we have always had the tendency to try to solve the problems, I wonder to what extent we are prepared to examine their creation. Surely if we are to have a long term approach to the solutions we must also examine the causes in detail. The causes of family breakdown today and the causes of growing proverty, especially over the last five years of the Hawke Labor Government, should be a matter of the gravest concern to every Government member, coming as they do from a party which claims that compassion and concern are the hallmarks of its social policy. Yet the sad facts are that more people and, in particular, more children are living in poverty today than ever before in Australia's history. Some 25 per cent of the children of pensioners and social welfare beneficiaries are living in poverty.

As we were told by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) when he introduced this legislation, as we were told by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last May when he introduced the May economic statement and as we were told by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the election campaign, after 1990 no children in Australia will be living in poverty. I found it more than amusing to note that only last Friday in Sydney's western suburbs, when the Prime Minister went there to release his new policy to the people of that area-many of whom are living in an environment of poverty-he said that it is not now a case of no children in 1990 living in poverty but that no children need live in poverty. Without arguing the semantics of the case, I would simply say that there is more than a small difference between making an absolute statement during an election campaign that there will be no children living in poverty by 1990 and the present situation where he has now resiled in the face of reality and said that, as he sees it, no children will need to live in poverty.

It is also interesting that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young), during the election campaign, some days after this grand statement by the Prime Minister, was required to back off. He realised, as did everybody else, that the realities of life are such that no government, irrespective of its commitment, can ever guarantee that no children will be living in poverty by 1990. Nevertheless that commitment was made by the Prime Minister on behalf of his Government, and the Opposition will make sure that he lives up to it.

The sad fact in relation to the family assistance package in this legislation is that, despite the obvious improvement in the level of funding, some half a million children will remain in poverty after the Federal Government's family assistance package comes into effect. That conclusion is the result of research carried out by Mr Peter White and Dr Peter Saunders at the University of New South Wales. Honourable members who wish to read this research in detail will find it in the September issue of Australian Society. The report said:

. . . the attempt to eradicate poverty was significant, ``even if it only succeeds in making the financial circumstances of the worst-off groups in society slightly less indecent than they currently are''.
The Opposition supports that proposition. Nevertheless, the report also said:
. . . between 135,000 and 180,000 children dependent on social security would be lifted above the poverty line because of the package, but that 450,000 to 500,000 would remain in poverty.

In this House I have emphasised the fact that with the introduction of these arrangements the Government has once again ignored the significant number of poverty traps which have been created and the disincentives to work. May I again remind the House of the fourth point emphasised in the Review of Social Security; namely, that incentives must be there and that family assistance should not discourage parents' work force participation and income earning.

Members of this Government and all people need to understand that, although the social welfare system may keep people alive in poverty, it is almost impossible for the system as it is currently constituted to raise those people out of poverty to the extent that they can have pride in self-achievement and be able to join the work force. One of the problems that we face with this particular package is that in so many respects it flies in the face of the fundamental fact that the objective of policy is not just to keep people alive, important though that is; the objective of a social welfare policy must always be to enable individuals and families to achieve an economic environment where they can do their best to look after themselves. That, regrettably, is not what has been achieved.

For example, part of this legislation provides for a rental assistance package, which again is part of the family support provisions. The Bill provides for rental assistance of up to $15 per week to be extended to low income working families. Again, I suppose $15 is better than nothing. But let us look at the impact of the policies of this Government over the last four to five years on housing in Australia. We have a lower level of commencements now than we have had since the year 1982-83-in the midst of the greatest drought that has faced this nation since the 1940s.

These are the problems the poor are facing. It is extremely difficult for a poor person today living in Sydney or Melbourne to meet the requirements for loans and rents in those cities. In June 1979, for example, median housing prices in Sydney were $51,900. They have doubled and risen substantially since then in every capital city of Australia. But incomes for people in those disadvantaged categories have not gone up to the same extent. We also find that there is now a crisis in the availability of public housing. Why is there this crisis? It is because the Federal Government's investment in housing has actually fallen over the last financial year-at the very time when hundreds of thousands of young married couples in particular who are living mainly in our capital cities are desperate to find adequate accommodation for their children.

Last Friday I visited the crisis centre in Sydney of the St Vincent de Paul Society. I met young families with two and three children. Some of these children are farmed out to relatives-to grandparents and to brothers and sisters. The husbands in many cases have had difficulty finding employment; they have come from country areas. They have applied time after time to the State Government for crisis accommodation, and they have been rejected. They are given support for up to three months in institutions such as the St Vincent de Paul Society which, incidentally, is getting no Federal support whatsoever to provide crisis accommodation for families. Yet we hear so much from the Australian Labor Party about the need for crisis accommodation for single women, for people coming from broken marriages and for children-all of which is important; I do not dispute that. But fundamental to the philosophical problem which the Government claims to be addressing with this legislation is the fact that what the Government is doing to hold family units together is simply not enough.

It is not good enough simply to look to the effect and to try band-aid policies while ignoring year after year the causes of the problems. In so many cases the problem is that poor Australian families simply do not have the wherewithal to make a reasonable go of it and to maintain even a standard of living which is acceptable as the lowest common denominator for our society. Yet we have a Prime Minister who does his best to hobnob with the rich and powerful of our land while at the very same time over 700,000 Australians are living below the poverty line. So much for this Government of compassion and concern. So much for the Government that claims that the basis of its philosophy is to look after those most in need.

We saw another example of this attitude when the Treasurer talked to the Fabian Society in Melbourne. Some newspapers made the point that Labor Party members now wear black ties-but what has happened to the culture of the Labor Party? What has happened to its genuine concern for the ordinary people? It is now the task of the Liberal Party of Australia once again to go back to the fundamental ethic of the Menzies years when we were the party that represented all Australians, irrespective of where they were or what their condition in life. I remind Government members that if they examine the income tax legislation during the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s they will see that the mechanisms built into the income tax arrangements to support families by giving a greater degree of horizontal equity have now been cast aside, ripped out, by a socialist government that claims to be concerned with the ordinary people and claims to be interested in the affairs of Australian families.

The issues before us are of profound importance. As I said earlier, these issues will determine not only the quality of Australian life but also the very existence of this nation in the future. If we cannot look after our families and encourage family formation in the face of a declining birth rate there will simply be too few to pay the taxes to maintain the benefits, support facilities and so forth for the older generations of Australians. There are many aspects of this legislation with which we concur. For example, there is the proposal to establish a double orphans' pension to assist pensioners whose only surviving parent may be indefinitely residing in a nursing home or similar institution.

We support the proposal for unemployment and sickness benefit so that there will be an equal rate for those who are unemployed and those who are sick. The concept of a new rate for an ill spouse, especially in the case of broken families or where the wife is living separately from the husband, is of course a sensible approach. People in those circumstances should get equal benefits.

I now go on to other issues such as the assets test on unemployment and sickness benefits. I notice that there is no proposal for tapering or hardship provisions. Perhaps the Government could look at that in detail because there are so many cases at the margin where people cannot support themselves even on the basis of what resources they may already have. While the family home is excluded from this very rigorous test as it applies to unemployment and sickness benefits, where there is a need to introduce provisions such as this, people who are precluded should be able to `borrow' pensions from the Department of Social Security on the understanding that the amount will be repaid when they go back into the work force.

I want to widen the scope of this proposal to some extent. In the legislation introduced before the last election, and again in this Bill, we have the question of the approach to widows, in particular whether B class widows should be required to register for unemployment and thus be seen as an unemployment statistic rather than as the beneficiary of a B class widows' pension, as has been the position in the past.

Of course, the Government's objective in this was to reduce overall costs. As I have said, under the difficult circumstances such as we face, that is a principle which naturally the Opposition supports. But at the same time there is a need for a little more compassion in the way in which these proposals are applied. For example, there is not the slightest doubt that people over the age of 45 have significantly less opportunity of finding gainful employment than people who are younger. It is equally a fact that many people who are beneficiaries of what was the B class widows' pension are precisely in this age group. What is worse, many of those women grew up at a time when they were not expected to be trained; they were not expected to go out into the work force. They were expected to become mothers and to look after their children. Whether that attitude is acceptable to the people in the Australian Labor Party is entirely another issue. But that is a fact of history.

That is the environment in which those people grew up. The question has to be asked: to what extent under current circumstances is it fair or reasonable to force these people back into the work force under current circumstances which are so difficult? For example, 21 per cent of people in the age group 45 to 54 years are out of employment for over 36 months. In the age group 55 to 59 years it grows to 24.8 per cent. In the age group 60 to 64 years 28.1 per cent of people are out of employment for a significant period.

All I am suggesting to the Government is that it should consider whether it is possible to apply a test which will take those factors into account. For example, I put it to the House that to require widows and people who previously were beneficiaries under this arrangement to present themselves every fortnight to the local Commonwealth Employment Service office, to the local Department of Social Security office, and to go through the work test provisions when they may well live in areas where there is simply no prospect of employment, is simply demeaning. It is something that needs to be looked at very carefully indeed.

There are other worthwhile changes in the legislation such as the young homeless allowance, and the job search allowance which will remove the capacity of school leavers to claim the unemployment benefit. But, again, there may well be an argument that poor families will have great difficulties in the three-month period for which unemployment benefit cannot be obtained after their children leave school. In the present Act and the regulations pertaining to it officers of the Department of Social Security had the opportunity to apply their judgment as to whether the personal circumstances of a beneficiary required the absolute interpretation of the Act or whether specific requirements should be taken into account. The Opposition finds it regrettable that in a whole range of areas this will no longer be the situation. There is also the question of pension deprivation relating to a recent decision of the Federal Court of Australia. It is now expected that certain loopholes of some significance will be closed.

I now turn to the question of the hardship provisions which I referred to briefly earlier. I would like to point out to the House that the Opposition will be moving an amendment to the second reading motion to the effect that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government's imposition of 2.5% deemed income on disregarded property in all cases under the hardship provisions of the assets test should not be proceeded with, and that the discretion of Departmental officers to apply this provision under the regulations should be maintained to prevent unfair and discriminatory treatment of pensioners, especially farmers'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be happy to second that.

—I appreciate that. The hardship provisions in this legislation are very onerous indeed. Under the previous arrangements the regulations stated that, in cases where a pensioner had property such as a farm from which he was not obtaining sufficient income not to disqualify for the pension, officers of the Department could classify that person as being not required to pay a deemed income on that land of some 2.5 per cent. There were instances in which a person was unable to rearrange his or her personal financial affairs or could not reasonably be expected to rearrange them because of particular circumstances. Consequently, the special provisions were included so that people were not placed in severe financial hardship due to the normal application of the assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: As the new arrangements will apply, the option is no longer in the hands of officers of the Department. The 2.5 per cent deeming provision is now to be built into the legislation. It will be applied in all cases irrespective of whether there is a case of hardship or not. What is worse, because of the intermeshing of the income test with the assets test, there may well be cases where existing pensioners will lose their pension entirely because of the effect of the implementation of this 2.5 per cent deeming provision. It is a matter of the gravest concern to many people, and one which the Government is earnestly asked by the Opposition to review. The explanatory memorandum attached to this Bill emphasises the fact that the overall saving from this particular provision will be minuscule.

Surely, if the issue is as important as we believe it is, it is very difficult to understand why it is necessary to put in place a provision which will gain so little in revenue but which could have such a major impact on people under those circumstances. In fact the estimated savings in 1987-88 will be a miserable $1.2m and in 1988-89 will be $2.3m. I warn the Government that across Australia, especially in country areas, this will be an issue which will inflame the passions of many because they will believe, and rightly so, that they are being unfairly discriminated against for no worthwhile financial benefit to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It destroys the Williamson case.

—As my colleague rightly points out, it destroys the Williamson case. I now refer to the question of investment income. There have been some changes which were necessary, although again one must make the point that pensioners, especially in Victoria, may feel that they have been somewhat discriminated against. The Opposition supports this amendment principally because the time has definitely come when it is necessary for friendly societies to be treated on the same basis as life insurance and superannuation companies in terms of their capacity to offer investments to pensioners. Under the existing arrangements, while the bonuses declared were meant to be built into the total capital amount and taken benefit of only at the time the final payment was made, the reality has been that many friendly societies have allowed the bonuses to be paid on an annual basis. In fact, therefore, those payments have been a form of supplementary income which has not been taken into account by the Department in the income test, with the result that people who put their funds into friendly societies have had a clear advantage over people who have taken our insurance policies, invested in a superannuation scheme and so on. Clearly, therefore, there is a need to have commonality. It is worth noting that the estimated savings from this proposal in a full financial year will be some $9.02m.

SPEECH.PARA: Another change of some relevance which is worth noting concerns pensioner earnings credit. Under this arrangement, pensioners will be allowed to have a gross income of up to $40 a week, if they are single, and up to $70 a week in the case of a couple. It has been best described by the Minister and others as the Santa Claus arrangement by which a person, theoretically, can work for a few weeks at Christmas, earn a reasonable income and not lose benefits. However, I am assured by the Australian Council of Social Service that there is a real problem in this proposal. That relates to the fact that it falls unfairly on people who may seek to obtain a relatively small income throughout the year on a part time employment basis, as distinct from a person who gains a relatively significant income for only a few short weeks. Therefore, whereas a person who goes fruit picking will be advantaged under this arrangement, it will not be so for somebody living in a metropolitan area who may have a part time job for most of the year. I draw that matter to the Minister's attention. It may well be something that he should consider amending in the future.

I emphasise that the family package as a concept is valid and is supported by the Opposition. However, we continue to be very critical of the Government for the fact that in a whole range of its policy approaches it is still not putting in place sufficient encouragement for the formation and development of families in Australian society. I cannot emphasise enough the great importance of family formation in our community. It is the only way that Australia will be able to survive in the future. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government's imposition of 2.5% deemed income on disregarded property in all cases under the hardship provisions of the assets test should not be proceeded with, and that the discretion of Departmental officers to apply this provision under the regulations should be maintained to prevent unfair and discriminatory treatment of pensioners, especially farmers'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a wonderful speech from the Opposition! It is a shame that today's proceedings are not being broadcast so that people in the community could hear the fine words, the rhetoric and the absolute irrelevance of the Opposition's comments. The Opposition is so out of touch with reality that its talk of the glories of the Menzies years must go down well out there. I am glad that at least one member of the public who is in the gallery today, that is, my father, a pensioner, would very much like to say what it was like to be a wage earner in the Menzies years and how society was or was not equal for all people under the glorious Menzies philosophy. That is all the Opposition can offer at the moment, yet it scoffs at our commitment. Let me tell those opposite that we dare to make a commitment and that we will fulfil our commitments.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Opposition of its record. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) said constantly that the real need was for families. During the coalition years payments for children fell by 35 per cent in real terms. The number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families has more than doubled-from 330,000 to 790,000. That is great for commitment, is it not? That is great for reality and for what happens when the Opposition is in government. The Opposition's policy for families at the last election was to increase the dependent spouse rebate. The coalition always thinks in terms of rebates, of tax. It forgets the number of people who are not even in a position to pay tax, who do not have sufficient income to get into a tax bracket. However, the coalition intended to increase the dependent spouse rebate from $830 to $900 a year for families without children and reduce it from $1,030 to $1,000 a year for families with children. In other words, its proposal would have financed gains to those without children from losses to families with the additional costs of children. That is the coalition's record in terms of promises.

The amendments in the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) to the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act are very comprehensive and, I am glad to say, have in large part received the support of the Opposition. These amendments will benefit a great many people. Without doubt, the most significant is the measure to introduce a $500m families package, which means real increases in the standard of living of more than one million children. There is the action, the commitment and the implementation for the children of Australia. Like many other speakers on our side, I will spend some time emphasising the family allowance supplement because it is absolutely central to the Government's determination to get all Australian children out of poverty. It is a necessary beginning to our implementation of a social justice strategy for all Australians.

Other speakers will give details of the benefits, but I bring a challenge to the Opposition. The fact is that the measures to be implemented in the family package will bring such improvement-in terms of untaxed cash-in the financial situation of low income earners, those who need it most, that perhaps the only real difficulty we face is making sure that those eligible know about it and apply for the benefits to which they are now entitled.

The family allowance supplement replaces the former family income supplement (FIS) which was often not taken up by those working families which were, in fact, eligible. This supplement is a much better payment because it pays more and it lets parents earn more and still qualify for child payments. Those on benefits already will get their increases automatically. The Department of Social Security is already aware of those on benefits. Child payments for people on social security will go up automatically in December. They do not have to apply for their increases. But those who will qualify for the family allowance supplement do have to apply. There was a problem with the former FIS in that it was not sufficiently taken up by those who were eligible. It is up to all of us, to Government and Opposition members-here is my challenge to the Opposition-to spread the good word of this legislation. We in Government certainly will. We plan, as backbenchers, to get the message through every sector of the community-trade unions, employers, community groups, ethnic groups and the Aboriginal community. I invite Opposition members too to do just that.

So often in the past the public has been misled by some of the Opposition's scare tactics about our legislation. Some pensioners must be astonished to find that they still have gold fillings in their teeth. If the Opposition really cares, if it holds dear to the ideals of the wonderful Menzies years, why does it not go out and sell the family package just as we will sell it? Why is this package so important? Why has the Government taken this historic step? It is not for some political advantage. That is why I invite Opposition members to join us in letting people know the entitlements for which they are eligible.

This Government has undertaken research to find out where the need is. The honourable member opposite talked about the need to understand and quoted figures. We in Government have undertaken the research. It was we who instituted the Review of Social Security, which is the first review of the social security system for 30 or 40 years. We found that low income families with children are most in need. I will quote some other figures. The National Institute of Economic and Industry Research has estimated the extent of poverty in both 1981-82 and 1985-86. The Institute's figures show that while the prevalence of poverty among single parent income units appears to have declined marginally over the four-year period, it is still very high and that poverty among sole parents is much higher than among other income units. The figures also show that the prevalence of poverty among married couple income units with dependants has actually increased over the four-year period for families of all sizes.

A particularly striking feature of the figures is that this prevalence increases significantly as the number of dependants in the income unit increases. Thus in 1985-86 it was only just over 8 per cent, both before and after housing costs, for income units with one dependant but rose to 40.7 and 31 per cent on a before and after housing costs basis respectively for units with four or more dependants. That is why we, understanding the need, have made the commitment and are targeting, with the amendments to the social security legislation, those most in need-the people we understand and the people who are in our electorates. It is all part of our social justice strategy. Social justice crosses areas such as housing, education, welfare and health. Every possible facet of life is covered by social justice.

Part of our social justice strategy emphasises the need for Labor in government to develop a more strategic approach to the implementation of its policies and programs and to the process of government decision-making in order to achieve greater social justice. Some of our objectives are to create greater fairness in the access to economic resources and power; to protect, extend and ensure the effective exercise of equal legal, industrial and political rights; to ensure greater equality of access to essential goods and services-it does not sound like the Menzies years-and to ensure expanded opportunities for genuine participation in decisions which govern their lives. Typically economic disadvantage is linked with disadvantages in many other areas that out society considers essential for a satisfactory quality of life. That is why economic disadvantage is one of the greatest injustices in our society. This legislation targets those with the greatest economic disadvantage and those are families with children.

The first injustice is the lack of means. The Opposition's attempt to improve the lot of the community seems always to be related to tax concessions, to rebates, for those who already have an income at least able to be taxed. So much of this legislation, particularly the family allowance supplement which goes to working families, is for those whose income is too low even to attract tax at all.

Many of my colleagues will discuss many other aspects of this legislation which is before us today but there are a couple of points I want to mention. First I refer to the child disability allowance. It will be brought in at a uniform rate of $112 a month free of income test for all disabled children covered under the current categories. Another point I am sure my colleagues will speak more about is the pensioners' earnings credit scheme which will allow eligible pensioners to earn up to $1,000 each from casual jobs without losing their fringe benefits or having their pensions reduced. This new scheme will mean a fair go for pensioners who do not have regular part time work.

Another area I would like to touch on is the carer's pension. As the House knows, the carer's pension was introduced by this Government in 1985. With this legislation the eligibility will be extended although the requirements will be tightened. It will extend eligibility beyond the closest relatives. One aspect of modern living which has highlighted the need for this particular carer's pension is that of people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). So often people with AIDS are unable to be cared for at home by a relative close enough to attract a carer's pension. Under this more generous eligibility, people caring for people with AIDS will be able to receive a carer's pension. It is just one of the many improvements to the quality of life of Australians dependent on government help which is in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment moved so ably by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). In response to the comments made by the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), I will deal with the Menzies years for a moment. I remind the House and the nation that it was in the Menzies years that there was a rising standard of living. It was in the Menzies years that there was full employment and economic growth. We did not have falling standards of living as we have had in the last 4 1/2 years under this Hawke Labor Government. We did not have record levels of unemployment. I know there are international economic reasons associated with some aspects of this decline but the clear message is that if our house had been in order the collapse on the stock exchanges, the economic crisis of most recent times, would not have impacted so heavily on Australia or on the standard of living of Australians, including veterans, ex-service personnel and war widows.

SPEECH.PARA: If the honourable member for Phillip dares to criticise the Menzies era, if she brings this aspect into the debate, let her be balanced in her approach-she normally is a thoughtful contributor to debates-let her be reminded of the high standard of living that existed and was recorded over many of the Menzies years.

In addressing the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) I point out to the honourable member for Phillip and others that there is growing anger among veterans, among ex-service personnel generally, among war widows, over the range of cutbacks and changes which have been imposed by this Hawke Labor Government contrary to the original commitment given by none other than Ben Chifley when he told the Parliament that the right thing should be done by the veterans. Here we are looking at further budgetary measures. I remind the House that it was in May 1985 under the then Hawke Labor Government mini-Budget that travel allowances were reduced by half, that subsistence allowances were sharply reduced, that there was a $300 limit imposed on the dental scheme for many categories of veterans and eligibility for certain categories of service pensioners to obtain assistance under the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme was eliminated entirely. On top of that we have had the impact of the assets test. Thousands of veterans have had there service pensions eliminated or reduced. The Veterans' Entitlements Act was introduced which sharply tightened up the criteria associated with the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension. I will return to the TPI in more detail in a moment.

To be fair, some improvements have been introduced under the Veterans' Entitlements Act but there have been a series of cutbacks and changes culminating in the Federal Budget of 1986 which saw the access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme by war widows eliminated. The social security component of the war widows' pension package associated with both social security and veterans affairs was frozen at $60.05 per week. Let us be fair when looking at this whole area and let us consider both the good and the bad which has been brought forward by this Government including the 2 per cent permanent cutback on the defence force retirement benefits scheme recipients which I know rankles very strongly in the electorate of Phillip and many other electorates including the electorate of Fairfax. I know the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) will expand on aspects particularly relating to the TPI later in the debate.

In addressing this measure which embraces the provisions relating to verterans affairs I want to draw the attention of the House to the fact that there has been both good and bad brought forward by this Government. I warn the House and the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) that there is a great deal of concern across the veteran community. I do not seek to add to that concern unduly. I am very careful not to do that given the age of many of the veterans and how easily they become very upset. I am pleased that this measure, as its centre-piece, provides for the continuation of the payment of the TPI beyond the age of 65 years. That provision is welcomed. It is supported on a bipartisan basis.

In looking at the detailed provisions relating to this aspect of the legislation I draw the Minister's attention to a change in wording which exists between clause 65 of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) and section 24 of the parent Veterans' Entitlements Act which has caused some last minute concern in the veteran community. I know that the Minister has been apprised of this concern. I invite the Minister in his summing up-or to arrange for it to happen in the Senate-to provide some assurance in the Hansard record that this alteration of wording between the amending Bill and the principal Act is not some surreptitious move-and I do not believe it is-to wind back further on the TPI pensioner. The particular words in question relate to the top of page 29 of the Act. Section 24 says, on lines 3, 4 and 5:
. . . to render the veteran incapable of undertaking remunerative work for periods aggregating more than 8 hours per week; and . . .
On page 45, line 9, of the amending Bill, proposed new section 24a (c) states:
In the case of a veteran to whom section 24 applies-the veteran is undertaking or is capable of undertaking remunerative work for periods aggregating more than 8 hours per week.''.

On the one hand in the parent Act we have the word `incapable', and on the other hand in the amending Bill we have the word `capable'. I believe that change is due entirely to the thrust of the introductory phrases associated with the drafting of the Bill, and it was necessary to make that change. But in the scheme of things the Returned Services League and many other organisations have expressed concern about that, and also about why there was a need to introduce the application date as the relevant date in the assessment of the TPI. I understand that, in a sense, the reason is to eliminate that portion of the Federal Court ruling which determines that there should be a continuing test for the TPI pension. If the Minister could clarify both those aspects, I think that would be welcomed by the veterans' community. On an overall basis the TPI pension represents compensation for war effort on behalf of this country. It is something that has been understood to have been awarded for life, unless there is a fraudulent or other aspect involved, and this is what this measure provides for and this is why I am happy to say that the Liberal and National parties strongly support these provisions to put to rest the concern that existed with the Australian Federation of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Ex-Servicemen and Women and so many other organisations in the veterans field about where they stood in terms of the TPI pension.

I add that the TPI ground rules have been tightened up dramatically by the Veterans' Entitlements Act. There are other concerns, such as the guide to assessment of rates and pensions. All of these are being addressed by the independent monitoring committee, which is still in session, and we look to that committee to produce a worthwhile report which will address some of the very real concerns of veterans on these aspects.

There are three areas of omission from this measure which I should address. Firstly, the Budget decision to impose a statutory patient contribution on nursing home veteran patients is a bitter pill for many veterans, and some 750 will be affected by this measure. It is not addressed in this legislation. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and others have large nursing home facilities in their electorates and have highlighted the fact that these veterans are now being hit with this statutory patient contribution ranging to over 80 per cent of their pension income. In effect, this amount is being confiscated for their well-being in those facilities. As I said, it is not addressed in this legislation. I wish to advise the House, the veterans and the nation that it is going to be introduced administratively. It is a matter of concern and it represents a further cutback on the veterans, and that is why I have raised it in the context of this legislation.

In addition, I should mention to the House that the defence service home loans situation is another key omission. I know that in addressing this measure, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would wish me to stick to what is in the legislation, but I wish to make passing reference to these omissions because I want to highlight to the Minister that it was this Minister, in one of his most honest moments, who told the House and the nation that he would have, by 1 January 1988, an announcement of new provisions relating to the defence service home loans scheme. This Minister and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) said to the nation at large that they were pushing on with a revision of the Budget announcement to introduce a non-taxable, non-repayable grant as an alternative to the defence service home loans scheme. Yet here, with just nine full sitting days to go for the lower House this year, we have not yet had such a statement in this historic chamber. The Minister might like to assure us again that he will produce such a statement between now and the December recess of the Parliament. Because if he does not there is going to be continuing concern amongst veterans, amongst ex-service personnel, and amongst serving personnel, whose morale has been shattered over recent years as further concern has been created for them and their families by the continuing saga over defence service home loans. God alone knows it was in May 1985 that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the transfer of the Defence Service Home Loans Corporation to the private sector. But here we are, 2 1/2 years later, after a further Budget announcement, and the thing is still a great mess and causing resignations amongst our Air Force, Navy and Army personnel. I highlight that omission but equally, to be fair, I welcome the inclusion, as recommended, of provisions for medical treatment for World War II service women as this represents a great victory for some very valiant women, including Trish Kennedy and others, in veterans' organisations. But the 150 women-a minuscule number-who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam will not be picked up by this one long overdue and welcome gesture by the Government. To put it in perspective, it is true that those service women who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam were on a fundamentally better basis than their predecessors from World War II. They had better conditions, allowances and schemes applying to them. Nevertheless, in going through this very important exercise of finally picking up these World War II service women who have been discriminated against, surely this Parliament should go a further step and comprehensively embrace those still outstanding-the women who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. I put that to the Minister so he can provide further clarification to the House when he speaks to this measure.

There are many other budgetary measures implemented by the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2). It is a matter of continuing concern that veterans' affairs on this occasion have been lumped in, once again, with social security concerns. The fear is that ultimately the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security will be merged, and that is a very genuine fear and one which should not be allowed to come true during this decade and beyond, given the large numbers of veterans reaching critical ages and who need the support of a departmental structure. One of the measures includes alterations to the deferred interest investment schemes to provide new provisions from 1 January 1988. That has particular reference to Victoria and Queensland, where there are friendly societies and other deferred interest investment bodies, but I am satisfied that they do provide a more consistent approach than that which has existed.

The assets test has been covered in part by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield and will be addressed in more detail by the honourable member for Fairfax. The remote area allowance has been altered, but not to pick up Norfolk Island. It does pick up Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. As such, that is in accord with the general pattern of provisions in the relevant area of social security. Nevertheless, it is an area of some concern to veterans' organisations. In addition, there are provisions for the recovery of overpayment of pensions, which I think is a very satisfactory tightening up of the situation of payments associated with the death of a veteran or pensioner. Once again, these are in part mirror provisions of the social security legislation.

All in all this veterans' affairs section of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill implements the majority of decisions flowing from this year's Budget. By and large they are welcomed. The centrepiece, once and for all confirming the payment of the TPI pension to veterans beyond the age of 65, is also welcomed. But I sound this note of concern to the Minister, to the Government, to the Parliament and to the nation: we have an obligation to look after those who served their country in time of war, and that just because more than four decades have passed since World War II and well over a decade has passed since the most recent conflict, Vietnam, and because the veterans numbers are dwindling, especially World War I veterans, that does not absolve this Parliament of its obligation to take proper care of the veterans, of the ex-service personnel generally and of our war widows. The Minister ought to be aware, as I am sure he is, of the very real concern that exists in many veterans organisations over the general thrust and direction of change-some confusing changes and some very complex changes-that has taken place in recent years. I appeal to the Minister to look very long and hard particularly at the defence service home loans scheme to ensure that before Christmas we get a comprehensive, definitive statement covering that scheme.

Finally I should also mention regarding the repatriation area that during the most recent recess week there was a carefully stage-managed leak of the Hogg report. The previous week I put out a release calling for its publication. It has now been published not in the Parliament but by the media. The Hogg report is a report on the report of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. There is a report on a report but that was necessary given all the circumstances. However, it is now well over two years since the Royal Commission report was presented to the Parliament. We are again looking for an action program and an attitude declaration by this Federal Government, preferably before Christmas, as a consequence of the release of the Hogg report.

I realise it is a very difficult area and, to be fair, that many aspects proved too difficult for the previous Government and are proving very difficult for this Government. Equally, in accordance with our obligation to look after the veteran, the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam and the Hogg inquiry have now been around for some time. The whole of the veterans' community looks to the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Government to make a definitive statement to the Parliament before much longer so that we will know exactly what is the attitude of the Government and what will be provided for the veteran arising out of the agent orange issue. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2).

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Moore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I preface my remarks by congratulating you on your elevation to the rank of Deputy Speaker and Deputy Chairman of Committees. The purpose of this debate is to look at the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) and it gives me very great pleasure to support this Bill. It is quite clear from the comments of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) that generally speaking the Opposition supports and welcomes the Bill. I too welcome that support. Of course there are many good and positive reasons why the Opposition should support it. I am sure that it would have found it very difficult to oppose it.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bradfield raised the issue of those widows whose children have turned 16 years of age who, under the legislation, would lose their entitlement to the widows' pension. It is important for the House to pay some attention to that issue. The honourable member accused the Government of forcing these women back into the work force. Certainly it is the policy of this Government to encourage women to enter the work force and I emphasise the words `encourage women to enter the work force'. However, they are not being forced into the work force. It is a very sensitive area and I was conscious of the sensitivity of this area to the extent that some six or seven weeks ago I arranged a seminar for women in my electorate who would be likely to be affected by the proposed legislation. I asked the Department of Social Security (DSS) to send one or two officers to the seminar so that we could deal with the understandable concern of these women. The concerns were there; there is no doubt about that. I feel that the concerns were based on a misunderstanding of the issue that these women would be forced into the work force. However, it is quite clear that the DSS officers had been told to treat sympathetically those widows who are in their early forties and lacking any training or experience to fit them for entering the work force. It is clear that these women will be allowed to receive a widows' pension.

Several of the women said in the seminars that they would like to return to the work force but that they needed training or re-training and this is what the issue is all about. We are trying to encourage those women who need to enter the work force to do so. The Government's proposals in respect of training certainly cover this area. I refer to my parliamentary colleague the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) who made the point that this package of measures is very much part of the social justice strategy of the Government. There is no doubt that it is a step towards achieving a social justice strategy for people in this country.

My support for this Bill arises from the fact that it is a serious attempt to tackle the problem of child poverty in Australia. No government and no political party can ignore the fact that child poverty is a problem which, if not tackled now, will lead to even bigger social problems in future years. It will lead to a widening of the gap between the haves and the have nots, greater expenditure on health and increased social security payments.

The measures contained in this Bill are being introduced at a time when there is a need for financial restraint. That point must be emphasised because I am sure the Government would have liked to have gone much further than it has at this stage. However, it was constrained by the circumstances about which every honourable member is aware. In that light it is a courageous measure but a very necessary one, as I will attempt to explain to the House.

The disadvantaged members of our community are already suffering more than anyone else from our national economic difficulties. In the submission of the Economic Planning Advisory Council to the Government in April 1987 the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) made it clear that it considered increasing financial support for families, especially low income families, a high priority. In that report ACOSS pointed out that over three-quarters of a million Australian children, or one child in every five, were living in poverty. More importantly, the number has doubled over the past decade. Levels of poverty are especially serious among single parent families, large families and families in private rental accommodation. These facts have been known for some time but it is important for an organisation such as ACOSS to emphasise the facts and also to put pressure on the Government to meet the needs of the people that it represents. These groups have been targeted by this Government-I will explain this later-in this Bill. If children are Australia's most valuable resource, to allow so many children to be raised in poverty is to squander that resource. This Bill is an attack on child poverty. The family package is an historic commitment for two reasons. Firstly, it substantially increases the value of child payments available to families on low incomes. Secondly, it promises for the first time to increase child payments in line with pension indexation. The family income supplement is being replaced by the family allowance supplement. By any measurement, the latter is a much better scheme. It pays more money for each child, and it allows parents to earn more money and still qualify for child payment.

Let me compare the old system with the new. The family income supplement paid $17 a week to each child and one was unable to get full payment unless one's average weekly income was $257 or less. Under the family allowance supplement, a parent or guardian is paid $22 a week for each child, but the payment for the 13-, 14- and 15-year-olds, the teenagers, is $28 each per week. Families on a gross wage of $300 a week or less can receive full payment if they have one child. The bigger the family, the more money that family can earn and still receive some payment. It must be emphasised-and this is important-that the family allowance supplement is tax free. In other words, it is better than a pay rise. I will take the example of a family on an income of $400 a week with two teenagers, and paying rent. That family will receive $27 a week. Because the payment is tax free, that family allowance is equal to a pay rise of $45 a week. This is a great and necessary social advance. I am sure that honourable members on both sides of the House are very supportive of it.

There is another section of the Bill to which I want to refer briefly. This relates to the child disability allowance. As honourable members know, previously the handicapped child allowance was split into two categories-the severely disabled and the marginally disabled. Those two categories will now be dispensed with and there will be a uniform rate which amounts to $112 a month, free of income test, for all disabled children covered under the current categories. As a person who has worked with disabled children and has met many parents of disabled children, I am sure that this will be received very gratefully by all those persons. Time has run out on me, but I wish to re-emphasise that this is a measure which is largely supported by both sides of the House. I strongly support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a cognate matter today relating to legislative amendments in two areas-namely, the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Although I wish to make some comments in both areas, I have a shadow ministerial responsibility to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). This legislation brings some welcome changes to the pharmaceutical benefits arrangements that the Government has in certain areas. In fact, it is consequential on other legislation that has come forward because of changes that have been mentioned in other legislation and changes to the status of certain welfare beneficiaries.

SPEECH.PARA: For a change, here we find that there is some government expenditure involved in terms of the delivery of health care to ordinary Australians and, of course, in particular in this case to disadvantaged Australians. We have been advised by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) that the total cost of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) would be about $200,000, all of which would go to persons previously categorised as A class widows. As I said, this is something of a difference because in all the legislation with which I have dealt recently in this place, the Government has been pulling back on its expenditure in the area of health delivery.

More importantly, the other day we dealt with legislation relating to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee when the Minister pointed out that the Government had managed to achieve savings of $100m. Although the Opposition always applauds a government cutting its expenditure in appropriate areas, we expressed our concern during that debate because we found that the newly structured Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee would be obliged to take alternatives into account when looking at the benefits that it would list. One of the alternatives listed was surgery. I am not really sure what that means, but apparently it could be considered that, where a certain treatment by drugs was considered too expensive compared with, say, an amputation, one might wonder which course to take.

More importantly, in recent times we have seen an attack on the Medicare schedule in a similar way, with items being removed because the computers have identified too much money being spent in a particular area. It is very significant, this being skin cancer week in New South Wales, that the Government has just removed certain items from the medicare schedule which related to the treatment of warts and keratosis. Keratosis is a form of wart which is well known as a precursor to skin cancer. Other warts that have also been removed from that schedule are venereal warts which the Government has more recently declared a notifiable disease. They are the precursor to cancer of the cervix-one of the more serious killers of women. This has been done for cost saving reasons. When we see this more sensible legislation coming forward today, in which the Government has chosen to spend some additional money to rectify problems that have occurred as a result of other decisions it has taken, some of which the Opposition has supported, we might wonder why the Government has chosen to make cutbacks in an area as sensitive as skin cancer for the pure reason of saving money. We might wonder how much the Government will save in the long run when it looks at an issue such as keratosis, which now has to be dealt with in a general practitioner's surgery. I am not for a moment criticising the skills of general practitioners but if a GP decides that he has some doubts about whether the keratosis is a skin cancer and decides to refer that patient to a specialist, the patient must gain the next treatment at his own cost. Of course, that will deter some people from going for further treatment.

It is interesting that articles published this week supporting skin cancer week have pointed out-and I have not yet been able to confirm these figures-that 125,000 Australians have skin cancer and do not know it, and that 1,000 a year are dying from it. We presently have great concern about acquired immune deficiency syndrome, but skin cancer is a greater killer than AIDS. It is with us and we are trying to educate people about it, but in the meantime I think it is very poor economy to cut down on treatment in that area, and especially that of specialist diagnosis. In the town of Geraldton in my own electorate, a voluntary survey has been conducted of 5,000 people. Of the first 3,000 who were screened, 300-10 per cent-were identified as having skin cancer or other skin diseases necessitating treatment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It now being 12.45 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 101a, the debate is interrupted. The debate will be resumed at a later hour and the honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
