TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Staples, will be absent from Question Time today and tomorrow. He is attending a conference of consumer affairs Ministers in New Zealand on behalf of the Government. In his absence questions normally addressed to Mr Staples should be addressed to the portfolio Minister, Mr Bowen.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will be aware that his Ambassador to the United Nations has declared that in future his Government will not condemn resort to force and violence by those struggling in South Africa against apartheid. Does this policy apply to force and violence by blacks against blacks? Does it apply to force and violence against so-called soft targets such as children, women and other civilians? Does it apply to murder? Does it apply to the practice of necklacing, when a rubber tyre filled with gasolene is placed around the neck of a bound victim, who is then burnt to death?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that the apartheid system in South Africa is the root cause of the violence in South Africa. There is no informed person on the tragic situation in South Africa who disputes that fundamental point. I make it clear that the Australian Government does not condone the use of violence, whether by the South African authorities or by their black opponents. It may be recalled that I made this point on 1 April 1987 in answer to a question without notice concerning the visit of the African National Council (ANC) President, Oliver Tambo, and the statement by Ambassador Woolcott was consistent with my statement. Despite our opposition to the use of violence-an unqualified opposition which embraces all the sorts of situations that have been referred to-we understand that the South African Government's persistent refusal to dismantle apartheid and negotiate fundamental reforms with the majority black community has led to a situation in which black frustration is expressed in increasingly violent ways.

ANSWER.PARA: I note a statement by the Leader of the Opposition that Ambassador Woolcott's remarks to the United Nations indicated my Government's moral bankruptcy. If there is any organisation in Australia which is morally bankrupt on the issue of South Africa, it is the Liberal Party under the leadership of the honourable member for Bennelong. His statement this morning equates the violence of the oppressed people of South Africa with that of the Irish Republican Army (IRA). He is apparently unable to distinguish between the democratic societies within which the IRA perpetrates its terrible acts and the violent, racist nature of the apartheid regime which denies elementary rights to its black majority and maintains its supremacy by force.

The statement by the Leader of the Opposition hypocritically reiterates the coalition's purported abhorrence of apartheid and calls for its dismantling. However, whenever this Government has taken action aimed at promoting the dismantling of apartheid by adopting sanctions or by urging Australian sports men and women to stay away from South Africa, the Leader of the Opposition has found some pretext to oppose us. The Leader of the Opposition is in favour of anything against apartheid, except action. What has he ever done other than wring his hands about it in a mealy-mouthed and hypocritical manner? As I have had reason to say before, the hypocritical, mealy-mouthed attitude of the Leader of the Opposition stands in stark contrast to the high moral principles and position of positive action embraced by his predecessor, Mr Fraser. As I had cause to say, by comparison with Mr Fraser the present Leader of the Opposition is a moral pygmy.

Let me make it quite clear that this Government, as I have said in this place, is opposed to the use of violence. We abhor violence by whoever it is used. Not only have I said that in this place but also I have said it to Mr Tambo as representative of the ANC. I have said that what this Government is about is to try to remove from South Africa the cause of violence, and that is apartheid. That is the fundamental reason why there is violence in South Africa. Everything that this Government has been about is to try to bring the parties together, to bring the South African regime to the negotiating table with representatives of the blacks so that the greater tragedy that faces not only South Africa but also the rest of the world will be averted.

Let there be no doubt that the apartheid regime in South Africa will go; it will not last. Those who are committed to it will not be able to withstand the tide of history. The only question is: how will that regime go? It can go in one of two ways. It can go as a result of peaceful, meaningful negotiation entered into between the South African Government and the representatives of the non-white population, which will lead to a situation in which the resources of the Europeans-the capital, the investment, the people-will be able to be used and be part of a democratic, non-discriminatory South Africa. Change can come in that way. Alternatively, as Mr Fraser said as a member of the Eminent Persons Group, if it does not come in that way-the way that we want it to come-it will inevitably come by way of violence. Nobody's interests will be served if the change comes in that way. The best interests of the blacks, and certainly the best interests of the whites, will not be served.

We on this side of the Parliament will not be dissuaded from doing everything that we possibly can to get to peaceful negotiation and to see the elimination of violence on all sides. That is what we have been about since we have been in office from day one. In pursuing that course, I am pleased to say that we have pursued the course and principles espoused by Mr Malcolm Fraser, the honourable predecessor of the current Leader of the Opposition. As I have said, Malcolm Fraser stands high not merely in physical stature compared to the present Leader of the Opposition. Every time that this Leader of the Opposition opens his mouth on South Africa, he reveals himself by comparison with his predecessor as a total pygmy.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I said to the House yesterday that I expected a better standard of behaviour today. I hope that the House will take note. I am speaking to the House generally. I expect a better standard of behaviour.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the honourable member for Mackellar not do that again.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support been drawn to reports in this morning's Brisbane Press indicating that the so-called low tax National Party State Government intends to impose a 4c to 5c per litre fuel tax on Queensland motorists? Further, is the Minister aware of the feeble and grossly misleading attempt by the Queensland main roads Minister, Mr Hinze, to lay the blame for this National Party initiative at the feet of the Federal Government instead of the National Party's own economic mismanagement? Will the Minister inform the House of the facts relating to the question of general road funding to the States, and in particular to Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in this morning's Brisbane Press indicating that the Minister for roads, Mr Hinze, that well-known Queenslander, had hinted at the idea of a fuel tax. The context in which it was raised was particularly interesting. He seemed to be hinting that as soon as the Government got rid of Joh in August it would put a fuel tax into its budgetary structure. He went a little further than that and suggested that the reason the Government was going to have a fuel tax was something to do with the way Queensland had been treated by the Federal Government in regard to road funding. Queenslanders have nothing to complain about in terms of the amount of Federal fuel taxes that has been expended on roads in Queensland. I see a couple of Queensland members nodding their heads. Everybody knows that that is the case.

ANSWER.PARA: For the Queensland Minister to suggest that in any way Queensland is not getting its fair share of road taxes is a complete and utter fabrication of the worst type. If the Queensland National Party Government had spent a fair and appropriate amount on road funding for the past 20-odd years Queensland would have a much better road system than it has now and would not need to receive more than its per capita share of Federal road funds or need to apply a fuel tax. Everybody in this nation knows that the Bruce Highway and other roads in Queensland are not up to the standard of the rest of the nation. That has been the case historically.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever been on the Queensland roads?

—I have. I am going to Queensland again in December. I am looking forward to my visit. Since Federal Government funds have been expended on Queensland roads one can see some significant improvements. Those improvements will continue as a result of moneys expended under the bicentennial road program and other Federal programs. But we will not cop any of the blame for the Queensland Government choosing to introduce a road petrol tax in Queensland. Queensland is the only State that does not have one. All the other States have long had petrol taxes. It is not the responsibility of the Federal Government that Queensland now has to impose a road tax.

ANSWER.PARA: Queensland motorists should ask Mr Hinze for a concrete guarantee that any road taxes imposed in that State be spent entirely on roads. If the Queensland Government wants to introduce a tax to assist its financial position generally it ought to have the guts to say so. If it wants to impose taxes on motorists for expenditure on roads, likewise it ought to say so. The Federal Government makes it clear that a portion of the fuel taxes it raises goes to general revenue. The Queensland Government ought to have the guts to say likewise. It should not try to push the blame for the tax raising measure it is proposing on to the Federal Government. None of the blame is ours. It is entirely a matter for the Queensland Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Are the Parliament and the nation to assume from the previous answer he gave to the honourable member for North Sydney that in future his Government will remain totally silent in the face of acts of violence by groups opposed to the South African Government in South Africa, no matter what the ferocity of violence, the nature of the act perpetrated or the innocence or otherwise of people against whom that violence is practised or targeted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question is no. It follows from not only all that I have said in my previous answer but also all that I have said before in this House and outside it that neither I nor the Government condone violence. We deplore it. That was made quite clear to everyone in this House who wished to listen to what I had to say. I deplore violence. I said that I did. I have consistently said it in this House, and I have consistently said it outside the House. So it is a deliberate perversion on the part of the Leader of the Opposition to try to imply otherwise. All this has arisen from the reported comments of the Ambassador to the United Nations. My friend and colleague Mr Hayden has put in front of me his exact words which, he reminds me, were also used last year. Mr Woolcott said:

ANSWER.PARA: In the face of this continuing oppression and massive disregard for human rights it is important both to note and to pay tribute to the efforts by South Africans of all races to challenge their Government's policies and to call for fundamental change. In the face of the violence meted out to them some of them have felt compelled to resort to violence. My Government does not condone resort to force and violence as a matter of principle but it will not condemn them for doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely.
—At least get what he said into the whole of its context. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: We understand the frustration and bitterness that they must feel in South Africa's repressive and unyielding political, social and economic climate. Indeed, it would be surprising if those who were being repressed failed to take a determined stand against their misguided rulers.

I ask the Leader of the Opposition not to giggle and laugh but to listen to the question I put to him. If he were a black person in South Africa and his child had been shot in the back or had been beaten up in gaol by South African police and the Government which had practised these policies and produced that situation had consistently refused to sit down at the table and negotiate, does he say in all honesty that the thought of the exercise of violence would not occur to him?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: What are the latest developments in the continuing crisis in Kampuchea? Does the Foreign Minister envisage a further initiative by Australia to bring the various parties together?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that at least the Government will direct questions on foreign affairs to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It gives me a chance to answer questions on these matters, although I must say that the way in which the Prime Minister answered the last couple of questions demolished some of the misunderstanding, if not misrepresentation, which has taken place on the matter. I commend the honourable member's continuing interest in Kampuchea. He has compiled a rather compendious document on the situation in Kampuchea which includes a number of suggestions for possible initiatives in the future. What we need in the West, where we share a concern about the need for a resolution of the problems in Kampuchea, is creative thought which will respond to some of the hitherto intractable difficulties which have arisen. What is encouraging in recent times, however, is the degree to which dialogue is taking place or is about to take place. For instance, Hun Sen, the Prime Minister of Kampuchea, according to quite reliable reports, is about to engage in dialogue in Paris with Prince Sihanouk. This will be a major breakthrough.

ANSWER.PARA: On top of that we have the initiatives which have been undertaken by Foreign Minister Mochtar of Indonesia. These have been aimed at trying to get together the representatives of the various groups from the Kampuchean factions-Democratic Kampuchea and the other members of the coalition forces or whatever-for the purpose of trying to sort out whether there is the prospect of putting together a set of principles which can lead to a resolution of this problem. There has been talk about so-called cocktail parties, unofficial meetings and so on.

The Australian Government, for its part, has made its contribution. We have made contact with various groups from time to time. We have sought to encourage dialogue to take place across differences, whether on the side of Indo-China and its supporters or on the other side. I recall that at the first post-Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) conference I attended, in Bangkok in 1983, I pointed out that, militarily, time was on the side of the Vietnamese and that the fires of hell would freeze over before they withdrew as a result of military pressure. I pointed out that there would have to be a political solution. Three post-ASEAN conferences back in Kuala Lumpur I listened with fascination as Foreign Minister Siddhi of Thailand said exactly the same thing-that time was running out for those of us in the West who were concerned to see a resolution of this problem if we believed that resolution could depend on military measures alone; that it had to be a political solution. This loosening up, in a relative sense, which is now taking place is encouraging, because it indicates that a political solution may be established and may be pursued-I trust successfully. The honourable member may rest assured that the Australian Government will continue to play an active and constructive role in this area.

Earlier we were subjected to a range of criticisms, including some from people on the Opposition side, for the initiatives we have taken in this matter. In 1985 there was some misunderstanding in the media about contact I made with Prime Minister Hun Sen of Kampuchea when I met him in Ho Chi Minh City. I then engaged in extensive discussions with him about the prospects of political processes being put in place. I think it was worth persevering with those things. I think it was worth putting up with the discomfiture which took place in the wake of some of them-in particular the last one which I mentioned. I think they were important contributors-with many other sources of contribution-to the evolution of developments which we are now seeing.

I repeat: I sincerely trust that what we are now seeing will result in formulas being brought together which can bring about the essential and sustainable ingredients to bring about, in turn, a peaceful settlement of the situation in Kampuchea. But it must be understood that a peaceful settlement must involve as a sine qua non the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces, the setting up of a freely and independently selected system of government by the people of Kampuchea, and guarantees for the security of countries of the region.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WESTERN AUSTRALIAN STATE GOVERNMENT INSURANCE COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to recent Press reports that the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission--
—Who wrote it-John Elliott?
—Do you want him to give you some more money, or what? In what way does the Minister want to use the funds--
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will ignore the interjections. The honourable member for Melbourne will cease interjecting.

—I refer the Treasurer to recent Press reports that the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission has purchased seven properties plus a parcel of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) shares for a total of nearly $500m from the Bell Group. I also refer the Treasurer to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 November concerning the exposure of some Australian banks to the Bell Group. I ask whether the Treasurer was informed of these purchases and whether he was informed of any borrowing by the Commission to finance the transactions. Furthermore, without reflecting on the financial position of any corporation, commission or bank, I ask the Treasurer whether the Reserve Bank of Australia, under its procedures for the prudential supervision of the banking system, was informed of these transactions, and also whether it has taken any action recently to monitor the risk exposure of banks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it has been the policy of the Government from the outset of the dramatic fall in stock market prices to keep the Australian financial system liquid. We have seen that occur in these last three weeks; particularly when the exchange rate moved down a week or so ago, the Government chose not to tighten up monetary policy unduly to defend the rate against that market change for the purpose of keeping the system liquid. The Reserve Bank, in doing that, also has, I think, undertaken to talk to the individual banks in Australia about their exposure. Certainly it has been the Governor's view and the Board's view that the banking system ought to be kept liquid so that lines of credit are not withdrawn with companies being put into difficulties as a result of that. Also, I think arrangements are in place for the major trading banks to let the Reserve Bank know if any particular client of any bank is in difficulties. So far that has not happened.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the State Government Insurance Commission in Western Australia is concerned, I did notice a Press report today that it has purchased 2 1/2 per cent of BHP stock. I do not know whether this would be a normal or an abnormal transaction for an insurance corporation of this dimension. Its purchase of property in the last week or so was, as I understand it, one of a strategic holding within the city of Perth-which, again, is a commercial matter for the State Government Insurance Commission. Certainly as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, this purchase neither implies nor begs any addition to the borrowing authorities to be exercised by Western Australia under the Loan Council arrangements. I might say that even if such requests were made or needed to be made they would not be granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is it a fact, as reported in the Australian newspaper of last week, that the Minister ordered changes to the naming of some approved Australian research grants projects for 1988 in order to avoid political embarrassment from the outlandish nature of some of the projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that in recent times I have had the recommendations from a number of research granting bodies, particularly the Australian Research Grants Committee, before me and, in approving all of the recommendations which were made to me for research grants, I did take the opportunity to discuss with the Committee the short titles that some of the projects had been given. These short titles are not so much the creation of the individual applicants, but rather the creation of the Committee itself. I took up with the Chairman the suggestion that he might review some of those short titles in order to avoid any possible misrepresentation.

ANSWER.PARA: I did this because last year and earlier this year the Opposition tried to make some very cheap capital out of some of the descriptions which were given to these research grants. The Opposition has not been prepared to tackle the merit of these research grants or the proposals which they support. Rather it has tried to make some cheap political capital-very irresponsibly, I think-out of some titles which were apparently, at least to it, quite amusing. I thought that under those circumstances, in order to avoid the possibility for that kind of irresponsible political behaviour, I would take up the matter with Professor Aitkin, Chairman of the Research Grants Committee. He has agreed with me that it is a relatively simple matter for the Committee to review some of the short titles in order to avoid what he sees as the opportunity for beat-up merchants, as he mentioned on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program the other day. So he is proposing that a proposal for research into the mating habits of the red kangaroo should be entitled `The reproductive behaviour of the Macropus rufus'. Maybe the Opposition is able to make something out of that. I dare it to try. I would make the point that in considering these recommendations I have not made any attempt, as was suggested in some quarters, to interfere with the actual recommendations of the Committee. All the recommendations have, in the normal course of events, been approved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Does the Minister still maintain that no contract was ever made between the Australian Government and Mr Bob Rogers's company for its work on the theatre in the Australian pavilion at World Expo 88? If so, will he tell the House why Mr Rogers's company is entitled to compensation if no such contract was ever made? Thirdly, will he also explain why several Australian companies which responded to his invitation to make proposals for this project, and which have also made claims based on the same expectations as Mr Rogers, have all had their claims rejected? Finally, is it a fact that at a meeting with Mr Rogers the Minister, without any authority to do so, committed the Australian Government to give this contract to Mr Roger's company and that this, and only this, is the real explanation for these obvious conflicts?

—I will answer the fourth part of the question first. At the meeting on 7 December I was given a unanimous recommendation by my advisory committee that Mr Rogers should be given the contract for the theatre at Brisbane's World Expo. The nature of that agreement was that he would be a sub-contractor to AAV Australia as the chief exhibitory contractor.
—So there was a contract.

—No contract was ever formally entered into or signed. Mr Rogers is seeking reimbursement of expenses incurred between that date, 7 December, when he was given permission to proceed with preliminary work, and the date in February when a decision was made not to proceed with a contract.
—There is no inconsistency.

—No, I do not think there is anything inconsistent in what I said. No contract was entered into. Mr Rogers is seeking reimbursement of expenses incurred in that period in anticipation of a contract that was never consummated, never formed and never signed.
—So it is an act of grace.

—It is not an act of grace. Negotiations have been proceeding between the Attorney-General's Department and Mr Rogers's solicitors as to whether he does have a claim and, if he does have a claim, what the amount should be. I do not think I should comment further on that matter because it may in some way prejudice the position of either the Commonwealth or Mr Rogers.

—I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. You will recall that I asked the Minister, in addition to the matters he has covered, whether Australian companies had made similar claims and had them rejected. Madam Speaker, I ask you to direct the Minister to answer that part of the question.
—I do not think the Chair can do that.
—Madam Speaker, I cannot recall any Australian company making any specific claim, but I will check that and provide the honourable member with the information.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer noted comments by the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia that Australia's exchange rate should be held at US61c or US62c? What would be the impact of holding the exchange rate at that level? What is the Government's position about those calls?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite sure that the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia is directing a bit of gratuitous advice to the Government on where he thinks the exchange rate ought to be. In fact, he is in a practical sense directing such gratuitous advice to the market because, in case he has forgotten, the Australian dollar was floated in 1983. It is the market that makes the judgment about where the exchange rate ought to be from time to time.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting to note that in just the last two days we have had proclamations-they are indeed proclamations-by the Federal President of the Liberal Party in respect of budgetary policy. He has urged precisely-he is quite precise about these things-a $3 billion Budget surplus, in the face of the Liberal Party's policy of an outcome which would have been basically near a deficit of $3 billion. Now on the issue of the exchange rate we have had another proclamation about where policy ought to be directed. It leads one to the obvious conclusion that, while he is entitled to speak as the chief executive of Elders IXL Ltd, bearing in mind his recently assumed responsibilities, he has decided blithely to ignore his chastisement more recently at the hands of the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition about his prerogatives in respect of policy and pronouncements about policy. He has decided that he can best speak for business and the Liberal Party's interests. Therefore one can only assume that these references by him to major areas and tenets of policy are his view of how the Liberal Party ought to be conducting economic policy if it were in government, and where the Liberal Party's or commercial Australia's-he obviously sees them intertwined-interests ought to be. That just renders further the impotency of the Leader of the Opposition in having an impact upon Liberal Party policy. I notice that in his Press conference this morning the Leader of the Opposition said very quickly, referring to the dollar:
. . . I don't make it a practice, nor does the Liberal Party, of nominating at a particular level.

He may not do so. In a general sense, that is good sense. But Mr Elliott has decided that he now speaks with authority for the Liberal Party. He is the one who will be making any statements. He has flicked off very quickly the so-called rap over the knuckles that he received and has got back to the main business that he thinks he is good at, which is telling others, including the Liberal Party, how to run their affairs. The only room one can provide him for this exercise in indulgence in speaking on his part is that, given that he is organisational President of the Party, he has to suffer the current leadership of the Opposition and I suppose he thinks, `Why shouldn't I?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is it not a fact that despite his claim in answer to an earlier question that `no contract was formally entered into or signed'-those were the exact words used by the Minister-he has in fact been advised by the Attorney-General's Department, despite that claim of his, that the whole of his conduct in this matter has created a legal obligation on the part of the Government to the Rogers company and that it is on the basis of that legal obligation that the negotiations to which he referred in his answer are now proceeding?
—Stand aside, Brownie.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member stood aside; he is up on the back bench where he belongs. In answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question, that is not the advice that has been offered by the Attorney-General, as I understand it. There was preliminary advice offered last August by a Government solicitor that Rogers could make a case. The solicitor thought that he might be entitled to reimbursement of expenses incurred--
—On the basis of the contract.

—No, not on the basis of a contract. He might be entitled to reimbursement for expenses incurred in planning for the World Expo. There is no contract. There was never any contract. Negotiations are proceeding between Mr Rogers's solicitors and the Commonwealth's solicitors as to whether he has a claim for the expenses incurred and, if he has, of what amount.

—I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. The Minister has just quoted from preliminary advice from the Crown Solicitor. Presumably it is in the papers that he had in his hand. I ask that he table that in the House.
—Was the Minister reading from a confidential document?
—I was reading from nothing except some written notes of mine.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. Has the Minister seen reports in today's Press of the financial outcome of Qantas Airways Ltd's activity for 1986-87? Can the Minister provide the House with details of that? Further, in light of the fact that there is a current crisis concerning seating capacity on flights into Australia provided by Qantas, in particular into my home State of Western Australia, can the Minister outline the activity that Qantas may take to try to overcome that difficulty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am sure that honourable members know of the keen interest he has shown over the years in increasing the number of international seats into Perth. It is certainly the case that Qantas performed very strongly in 1986-87, with a record profit of $104.3m-the highest figure ever recorded by the company and an increase of over 133 per cent over the previous year. Its revenue earnings were $2.6 billion-an increase of 27 per cent. It earned 65 per cent of that amount overseas. A very creditable $1,672m was earned by Qantas and that was a direct contribution to our balance of payments. The dividend that Qantas has paid to the Government is $20.2m and that reflects the initiatives that the Government has taken to place Qantas on a firm, sound commercial footing. I am very pleased to advise the House that during the past year Qantas, for the very first time, carried over three million passengers, which was a very good effort.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the current international airline capacity situation, October of this year saw a large increase in Australians wishing to return home, plus increases in foreign visitors, to which the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has referred on previous occasions. That caused a very heavy demand for seats, particularly into Australia but also out of Australia. To meet that, Qantas has arranged to operate 162 supplementary flights between now and February. Also, some 80 supplementary flights will be provided by foreign airlines into and out of Australia. I note in passing that Qantas has only 42 per cent of the normal capacity into and out of Australia. Those figures-it will operate 162 supplementary flights and all of the other 32 operators into or out of Australia will operate only some 80 flights-are a clear demonstration not only that the current arrangements are flexible enough to meet the needs but also that Qantas is operating in the nation's interests and is undertaking the sorts of responsibilities that all honourable members would want it to undertake as a great Australian national asset.

As to the longer term, the Government intends taking steps to ensure that capacity is available for the longer term demand. I can tell the House that negotiations are currently under way with Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, the United States of America, Canada, Yugoslavia and Austria. Since the 1983 election, an additional 800,000 international seats have been introduced. By the middle of 1988, the bicentennial year, the figure will have risen to 1.25 million. This represents a permanent increase of over 36 per cent in inbound capacity over a quite short period. I think that the story Qantas has to tell clearly demonstrates the fact that not only Qantas but also the Government has been responsive to the needs of the nation. We have been concerned to ensure that proper and effective steps are taken to ensure that adequate seating is available for tourists and others wanting to come to this country. We will continue to do so. In closing I mention that Qantas is planning major aircraft acquisitions over the next few years, amounting to $4 billion over the next five years, to ensure that anybody wanting to come to this country will have the opportunity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the undertaking he gave yesterday to get a report on the matter involving the Rogers company and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the Attorney-General received that report? Will he table all legal advisings provided in the matter, including the legal advising referred to explicitly by the Minister in his last answer, and will he table those documents today?

—The answer is no, for this reason: yesterday I said that I was not aware of any advice that was given and I would make inquiries as to whether advice was, in fact, given. I can tell the House that advice was given at the request of the Minister's Department and, in accordance with negotiations that are now taking place between the Australian Government Solicitor and the solicitor representing Mr Rogers or Mr Rogers himself--
—Have you read the advisings?
—I have read the advice and, on that basis, it would be inappropriate at this stage to tender anything because there are negotiations.
—Can the Minister for Resources inform the House of the reaction to the Government's announced coal industry assistance package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The honourable member and the House will be aware that over some considerable period the Government has been putting together a package which involves this Government, the State Government, the mining unions and the mining companies with a view to outlining a longer term strategy for the industry and to developing means of improving the efficiency of the industry, its reliability and, most of all, its competitiveness. Honourable members will be aware also that in that period there have been some pressures on the industry from abroad, with the general overcapacity that exists in the coal mining industry. That pressure has borne upon prices as well as the operations of some of the mines. In all of that process, there have been continuing negotiations. The arrangements that have been developed between this Government and the State Government provide for a contribution of some $20m by this Government over two years and $20m by the State Government over two years. That is linked to improvements in the productivity of the mines. The negotiations that are under way are linked to a commitment by the industry on the future of its operations.

ANSWER.PARA: All of those matters are under way. I believe that the response has been positive. There has been some reaction from, for instance, the Leader of the National Party of Australia, who, I thought, would have had an interest in the continued operation of the mining industry. It surprises me that the Leader of the National Party has seen fit to decry the efforts of all involved to improve that industry's efficiency and competitiveness and, most of all, to try to improve the outlook for certainty of employment. We will continue to work towards that strategy in consultation with all the parties involved. I retain a confidence that the positive outcome for which we are looking will be achieved.
