DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received advice from the Government Whip that he has nominated the honourable member for Eden-Monaro to serve on the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for the purpose of any inquiry into proposals for modification or variation of the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; HALVERSON; JENKINS; KENT; MILTON; SCOTT
PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Halverson,Mr Jenkins,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Cobb and Dr Harry Edwards.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Maranoa Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Dawson electorate respectfully shows that:
The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal, and that the card will not stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject Labor's ID card proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Peak Downs electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal and that the card won't stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject Labor's ID card proposal as the Australian public haven't given the Government a mandate to introduce it.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled-The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate select committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lionel Bowen and Mr Ian Cameron.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Business Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose plans by Telecom Australia to close many of the Telecom Business Offices (TBO's) and replace them with a reduced service to be co-located with the District Customer Services Office. We believe the public should be able to make telephone bill payments, applications for new services, selection of telephones and complaints, in person at a convenient and easily accessible location. Telecom Business Offices provide this service, and therefore it is wrong that their contribution and performance will only be assessed on their sales revenue.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House or Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: instruct the management of Telecom Australia to immediately cease all action to close any Telecom Business Offices, and to re-establish the services provided by TBO's already closed,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Crawford and Mr O'Neil.

PETITION.TITLE: 24-hour Telegraph Service, East Block, Canberra
PETITION.PARA: The speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned wish to draw to the attention of the House that `Telecom plan to reduce the 24-hours-service at the telegraph office at east block in February 1988 and completely close the office in November 1988'.

In view of the `hundreds of thousands' words of public telex messages transmitted for politicians and journalists at Parliament House, the hundreds of after-hours customers using this office-the large profit made at this office-we request that Telecom be asked to retain the 24-hour until July 1989, when communications will be transferred to Australia Post.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The honourable, the speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:
about the evil caused by the fact that x-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence, are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra.
And your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
The laws regarding obscenity in the media should also be revived and enforced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small business and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Post Office Agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland Artists for World Expo 88
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

After discussing with many professional artists just how they were being employed during Expo 88 and the Bicentennial Celebration, I find that emphasis is being placed on engaging professionals from overseas rather than from our Brisbane and Queensland performers. Even the arranging of the concerts at the cultural centre has been `farmed out' to a Sydney group. Again, this attitude still persists `that locals can't be as good'. I fully support visits by famous international groups such as the Bolshoi, but surely the overseas visitor wants to see our local culture and seeing that we have to `foot the bill' eventually, at least let us make sure that our professional artists are employed, The Expo 88 authority responsible for entertainment should publicly seek the services and suggestions from the professional in all the performing arts.
We the undersigned suggest that the Expo 88 authority and the Bicentennial authority make sure that local professional artists are engaged during this most important international event.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Expo 88 authority and the Bicentennial authority make sure that local professional artists are engaged during this most important international event.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal;
Is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud,
Will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private matter,
Will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the tax payer, and
Cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows-
We object to the proposal of Telecom to charge for each three minutes of a local call, as we feel this would disadvantage the elderly and people who are unable to leave their homes.
The telephone is often the only contact relatives can have to check on the safety and well-being of those they care for.

The inordinate time span which elapses between connection to a business premises and speaking, as the caller holds the line or is transferred between departments, would also disadvantage subscribers who can ill afford it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Telecom abandons the proposal to time charge local telephone calls as we believe that the charges Telecom makes at the moment are quite adequate.

PETITION.TITLE: Opportunities for the Young
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
We are concerned that-
(a) the proposed changes in legislation to Unemployment Benefit for young people adds to the already ill-conceived and over-bureaucratic welfare system
(b) the abolition of CEP and the inadequacy of other training programs and
(c) cuts in funding for education, public housing and other welfare areas
mean that young people's needs are being neglected by the Government.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government immediately takes steps to:

(a) establish an anti-poverty level of income for all young people regardless of whether they are in training, retraining, education, employment or unemployment. The first step in achieving this is the full reinstatement of Unemployment Benefit for sixteen and seventeen year olds with automatic indexation linked to CPI increases.

(b) increase educational opportunities for all young people. The first step in achieving this would be to create 120 000 new places in higher and further education. This would make up for the 100 000 people turned away from TAFE courses and 20 000 people from universities and CAEs this year.
(c) establish a long term job creation program. The creation of 53 100 jobs for those young people who have been unemployed over 12 months is required immediately.
Your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gymea Bay Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Gymea Bay be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels, cash Pension cheques and transact banking. Many of us are Pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Office is 2.3 kms away with no convenient transport.

We maintain that the purpose of the Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Gymea Bay Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear-Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

We consider that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.
We therefore ask the House to take action to prevent the implementation of this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bans on Smoking
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
1. That we are totally opposed to the Government's discriminatory Anti-Smoking legislation in the workplace bans and on Domestic Airline travel.
2. Note that so called Environmental Tobacco smoke has not proved as a major pollutant either in the workplace or on aircraft.
3. This legislation will discriminate against thirty per cent of the citizens of Australia, and
4. Call upon the Government to lift all bans and not proceed with any discriminatory smoking legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Closure of Macksville Army Reserve, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

The decision by the Department of Defence to close down the Macksville Sub-section of 41 Battalion, Australian Army Reserve, is of grave concern to the unit members and citizens of the surrounding districts. The decision to direct unit members to Coffs Harbour, some 60 km distant, would impose sufficient hardship to prevent many continuing in the reserve and be a major deterrent to potential members.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to: Intervene to stop the proposed closure and sale of land at Wallace Street, Macksville, and initiate action to have a permanent Depot built on the Army's Macksville land.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

There is inadequate provision in the Constitution for national referenda and the people are therefore denied sufficient opportunity to oppose or introduce legislation of national importance or consequence.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to:
Amend the Constitution to provide for the holding of national referenda in the following cases:
1. If four per cent of the electors petition the House of Representatives and/or the Senate with regard to proposed legislation.
2. If four per cent of the electors petition the House of Representatives and/or the Senate with regard to existing legislation.
3. If eight per cent of the electors petition the House of Representatives and/or the Senate with regard to introducing legislation proposed by the electors.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respect- fully showeth that:

The Hawke Government's Australia card will be an attack on the civil liberties and privacy of all Australians, will not achieve the claimed results, will provide a boost to organised crime and will be an enormous burden to the private sector, especially small business, already snowed under with government charges, taxes and red tape.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to:
Abandon legislation for any type of national identity system and work towards building a society based on trust not suspicion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating tax evasion, illegal immigration or social security fraud;

That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax evasion and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life;
That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's veterans.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of veterans and their families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nationals General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertilizer in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Maranoa respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to time local telephone calls gravely concerns all country people. Isolation and communication was the second biggest problems facing rural women according to the ``Survey of Rural Women'' questionnaire and any attempt at timing local calls will add to this problem, not decrease it.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to: Ensure that Telecom do no proceed with the timing of local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed New Taxes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Parkes electorate respectfully showeth that:

An $8 million wealth inquiry proposed by all three factions of the Labor Party and the ACTU will give the Hawke Labor Government the information it needs for a Wealth Tax and the reintroduction of Death Duties.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to: Reject any plans Labor has to conduct a wealth inquiry and impose two new taxes on the Australian people and businesses, already struggling under 16 new Hawke Labor Government taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to add to the answer I gave to the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) in Question Time.
—The Minister may proceed.

—He inquired whether any Australian companies had been refused reimbursement of costs. I have been informed that one other company, Greg Taylor Productions, has also sought costs incurred with the preparation of the second submission-that is, the second tendering process. All tenderers were provided with $3,000 to assist in the preparation of the first tendering process. The Greg Taylor Productions claim has been referred to the Attorney-General's Department, which has advised that the payments for costs incurred in the production of the second tender were not warranted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to lead Australia's tourist industry to achieve its full potential, resulting in the loss of job opportunities and income for Australia's economy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Incompetence' is a word that Australians are increasingly associating with the Australian Labor Party in Canberra in government. More than just associating that word with a Labor government in Canberra, they are associating it with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown), who is at the table. In 4 1/2 years of Labor administration we have had a litany of examples of incompetence, maladministration, sloppy technique and poor administration, and there has been no greater champion of all of that than the Minister. We are tired as Australian citizens and as parliamentarians of seeing examples such as this being trotted out by this Minister. Not only are the people of Australia tired about that but also they are becoming increasingly tired of this Minister making statements that mislead one of the Houses of Parliament. That is what we have seen not only in the last 24 hours but over the last 4 1/2 years.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. If the honourable member for Gilmore wants to accuse me of misleading the House, he should do so by way of a substantive motion under the Standing Orders. If he wants to move a censure motion, that is up to him. As far as I understand it, this is not a matter that should be canvassed in a matter of public importance.

—The honourable member for Gilmore should be aware that if he wishes to accuse a person of misleading the House, as I had occasion to remind him the last time he proposed a matter of public importance, it can be done only by substantive motion. If the honourable member for Gilmore wishes to proceed along the lines of claiming misrepresentation he should do it in the way in which it should be done; otherwise he may continue with his contribution.
—Stop protecting your factional mates.
—Stop protecting your mates.

—I raise a further point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I hope you overheard the two interjections, that you, in the chair, are protecting your factional mates. It is a direct and incredible slur on your integrity.

—Order! Honourable members on my left were a bit worried about the time of the honourable member for Gilmore being used up. They now seem to be interested in using his time. I did not hear the interjections. I would think that if they were made they were rather stupid because the Minister is more than able to look after himself.
—Yesterday the Minister was caught with his pants down.
—On the table?

—In the House. He is the Minister at the table. This has happened not just on this occasion. To substantiate that I will quote from yesterday's Hansard, from a question asked by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) and answered by the Minister. The honourable member for Menzies asked a question about Mr Bob Rogers and a $5m contract that his firm had been awarded to build facilities at Australia's pavilion at World Expo 88 next year. The Minister said, `Bob Rogers has applied for recompense, when a verbal agreement was made with him and my committee to have a contract, with me, if you like. Does that suit you? I was there; I have never denied that'. In other words, yesterday the Minister told the House, and he repeated it here today, that there was a contract between himself, as a representative of this Government, and Mr Bob Rogers, representing a United States firm, to carry out a $5m contract at World Expo on Australia's behalf. I repeat that yesterday he admitted that that was the case. It was a verbal agreement for sure, but we all know that in business practice, when a Minister of the Crown gets up and says, `You can go ahead and do it, spend the money, get the job on the way', that person has at least to expect that the word of a Minister of the Crown is worthy of what it says, that it will be carried out and that it is honourable. Unfortunately, Mr Bob Rogers has found that that was not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: To point out where statements that I referred to earlier were correct: on 20 February of this year, in answer to a question about Bob Rogers and the contract, asked by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who at the time was the shadow Minister for sport and tourism, the Minister said, `. . . there is no contract so the question falls down'. That is straight out of Hansard. That is exactly what the Minister said on 20 February; it contradicts what he said yesterday and it contradicts what he said in the House today. I would put to the House that that is a gross example, at the very least, of incompetence, because I would say that the most serious act of incompetence a Minister of the Crown can engage in is not to tell the story as it really is. As a result, the taxpayers of Australia are going to have to pay $250,000 to overcome the mistakes that this Minister has been involved in. Now $250,000 is a lot of money. Do honourable members know that it takes 2,471 average Australian wage earners, sweating, working and paying tax to this Government for a whole week in order for the Government to get $250,000? This Minister has wiped out the contribution that the 2,471 average wage earners have made to this nation in one fell swoop of incompetence. That is costing us all very dearly. It is the sort of example of the cost that this country is having to wear because of the incompetence of this Minister and, indeed, of this Government.

The cost of this Minister is well known. He is well known for being the Minister for good times. In 1984 it cost $15,800 to hire two Mercedes Benz cars for a lovely jaunt across Europe. He needed two because he could not possibly travel with all his luggage and he had to have another car for that. That is an example of the sort of incompetence that is costing this country dearly, and it is costing this tourist industry, the shining light in Australia's economy at the present time. Yesterday we had that example of the sort of incompetence that the Government is engaging in and that this Minister is engaging in. The Hawke Ministry is full of lots of examples like that. We have only to think of the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd scandal, one of the grossest examples of maladministration and incompetence that this Parliament has ever seen. It was carried out by Senator Gareth Evans; the present Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan); and the former Minister for Transport-incompetence on a gross scale. Do honourable members know-I am quite convinced-that this Minister could not even run an ice cream stand on a hot day, he is so incompetent.

The list of incompetence goes on and on. A view that is increasingly growing in popularity around the community is that this Minister at the table is an accident waiting to happen. Everywhere he goes something goes wrong. I guess we could say that this Minister is the Sergeant Schultz of Stalag 13, and if he is the Sergeant Schultz of Stalag 13, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is the Colonel Klink of Stalag 13. There is no doubt that if there is to be a Colonel Hogan in this Parliament, it has to be the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), because he is the sort of person who has the right views. The Government is bumbling around the countryside, mucking things up and costing the taxpayer an incredible amount of money through its own incompetence. Of all of the Ministers in this Government who are incompetent, this Minister has to take the cake. There are lots of examples of ministerial impropriety that we could use to show just how bad this lot is. I want to draw the attention of the House to something that fell off the back of a truck and came my way recently. It is a transcript of a conversation by car telephone between John Brown and Don somebody or other, which took place at 7.20 p.m. on 6 April 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point or order. I knew that the Opposition could stoop to pretty low depths, but to start quoting an unauthenticated version of an alleged car phone transcript in this House is scraping the depths of depravity, to which I thought even those opposite could not approach, and I object very strongly.

—Order! The honourable member might be aware of statements that the Speaker has made in the past about using privilege as a mechanism to slander people. The Minister has taken a point of order and raised some objection to what he thinks the honourable member is going to say. It is not within the Chair's purview to know what the honourable member is going to say. I am sure the honourable member will bear in mind what I have said when he continues his point.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I refer to this alleged document, and I do say that it did come my way off the back of a truck. But I want to draw it to the attention of the House because I believe all honourable members of the House should have a copy of it as it is a great indication of the way in which this Government carries out its affairs. I would suggest that all honourable members read it, and if they are going to read it, they should read a comment made by somebody called Don, who refers to the fact that he had boffed--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is quite clearly going to talk in relation to something that fell off the back of a truck. The responsibility of an honourable member to authenticate his statements in this House, when speaking under the privilege of the Parliament, should not be abused in that way. If it fell off the back of a truck he should name his source and put it on the record.
—Order! It is not within my understanding to know what the member is going to say before he says it.

—I just want honourable members to take note of the comment of Don, who claims that he had boffed a female journalist. For those who do not know what the meaning of the word `boffed' is, an analogy can be drawn with what this Government is doing to our economy. That gives honourable members a very good idea of what the word `boffed' means in relation to a female journalist. If honourable members are going to read it, I want them to read the first page and the last couple of lines, because that will be of great interest. I just want to quote from it, if I may. It states that Don-this is the alleged Don-says, `I have boffed her, so that is all she knows'. The person purported to be Brown says, `Oh, good for you. Big tits?'. That is the sort of business that is engaged in by this Minister. What they were discussing at the time was the contract with Bob Rogers in relation to the World Expo pavilion for Australia.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Quite apart from degrading his own image, if he has one, to allow this sort of unauthenticated drivel to be used in this House in a serious debate is beyond my comprehension. How the honourable member can stand here as a decent member of this House and quote from some document that has allegedly fallen off the back of a truck, is allegedly a transcript of a car telephone conversation of mine, is beyond my comprehension. He is below disgust.
—Order! Members are not required to authenticate documents.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Groom is walking out of the chamber in disgust at the action of his colleague and he told me that that is what he is doing.

—Order! The honourable member for Gilmore has brought into the debate material which only he knows where it came from. It is not within the purview of the Chair to require him to do anything other than continue his remarks.

—In the time I now have available to me I will substantiate the claims of incompetence of this Minister. I will run through a list which he can call the top 40 if he likes and it goes like this. The sorts of things which the Minister has suggested and championed are measures such as the Ayers Rock monorail which he mentioned just the other day and the Christmas Island fiasco. Honourable members will remember that that was mentioned in the last couple of weeks. The Minister promised that the 300 miners who work on Christmas Island would have work for the next 2 1/2 years, but within three weeks of that promise being made it had been broken. The mine will now be closed down. A racehorse breeding syndicate was endorsed by the Minister.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really feel that I should not dignify the speech by the `honourable' member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) with a response or an answer. However, given the forms of this House, I will respond. Like the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), I am entirely disgusted with what the honourable member for Gilmore, who I thought had some talent, has put forward in this debate to support a matter of public importance which he supplied to Madam Speaker and which was accepted by her as being a matter of such importance that it should be debated in this forum. I am sure that any Australian who has the opportunity to read the transcript of the speech of the honourable member for Gilmore will lose what little respect he or she might have had left for this institution. This person has been put up by the Opposition as a serious shadow Minister; yet for a quarter of an hour he used such arguments to back up a matter of public importance that states:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to lead Australia's tourism industry to achieve its full potential, resulting in the loss of job opportunities and income for Australia's economy.

All that he provided in his speech by way of employment was a couple more headlines for the Eye or Truth, a couple of dirty, filthy magazines which I have no doubt he reads if the level of his reading approaches the level of his debate. I am surprised that more honourable members on the other side of the House for whom I have great respect did not follow the honourable member for Groom out of this place today.

I am quite happy to answer, in serious terms, the matter of public importance which has been placed before the House today and dignified by Madam Speaker with a place on the blue sheet. I hope Madam Speaker has listened to the contribution of the honourable member for Gilmour so that in future when he puts up a matter of public importance for debate it will be treated with the scorn, disregard and disgust with which it should be treated.

This Government's record in tourism is beyond compare throughout the world. Two weeks ago I was in Melbourne and I addressed the Society of American Travel Writers, which was having a convention there. It was the largest convention it has ever undertaken outside America and it was attended by 400 very serious American travel writers, the top of their profession. In answering my welcoming remarks the President asked, `How have you done it? How have you managed to get a 30 per cent growth in international tourism in Australia when the rest of the world is labouring along with a growth of 2 per cent?'.

I would have thought that every honourable member, in a bipartisan fashion, would have been pleased to support at least one line that was offered by the honourable member for Gilmore, namely, that tourism is the glowing success of the Australian economy. I hope that some honourable members opposite will have the decency to look back in honest introspection at the performance of the previous Government in tourism. The product has not altered. Australia is still the beautiful, bountiful country it was when the government changed in 1983. Its beaches are as lengthy, as beautiful and as unpolluted, the skies are as blue, the people are as friendly and there is still the same safety and security in this country under this Government as there was under the previous Government. But what was lacking under the previous Government was any form of promotion.

Under the previous Government, in seven years the budget for the Australian Tourist Commission languished. It went from $7.5m to $10m in seven years. In four Budgets and in the five years of my being responsible for the tourism portfolio the budget for the Tourist Commission has now reached $40m. The reason Australia has had this stunning tourism success is simply that we have managed to properly market the great product we have. To some extent God has given it to us and we have embellished it. In 1983 Australia had 800,000 international visitors. This year we will have 1.9 million. Next year 2.25 million people will visit Australia. This is an extraordinary growth of 200 per cent in four years. If anything stands to the credit of this Government it is the effort it has made in tourism. In 1983-after the Opposition's last year of government, after seven years of inactivity-the turnover for tourism in Australia was $8 billion. This year it is $27 billion, approaching 9 per cent of gross domestic product. It is easily the biggest industry in Australia.

The honourable member, in his matter of public importance, talked about Australia not achieving its full income potential. How could one possibly answer that assertion in any responsible fashion? How could he possibly put up this matter of public importance and believe in it if he did not expect it to be a vehicle to use some filthy muck to denigrate me? The honourable member spoke about the loss of job opportunities. In 1983 employment in tourism in Australia was 200,000 people. This year it is 450,000 people. If that is not achieving our employment potential I do not know what is. It is to the honourable member's discredit that he seriously offers himself as a shadow Minister.

One thing this Government has is great respect from the tourism industry. That fact was exemplified last week when 20 members of the top echelon of tourism in Australia, across the full spectrum of its activities, went with me, a Minister of this Government, to Japan. Only this morning one participant called me to tell me that today he had received a cable from the Japanese, who are anxious to invest $100m in a development in Australia, details of which he took to Japan last week as a member of that mission. This morning I mentioned to the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) that the people who were most delighted with the success of that mission were the Tasmanians and the Tasmanian Tourist Bureau. The Liberal Premier of Tasmania, Robin Gray, provided a pamphlet. With the co-operation of a group of developers, tourism has had amazing success in Tasmania. People cannot believe the success of that mission simply because of the close co-operation and the close respect between this Government and the private entrepreneurs in tourism. If only we had the same co-operation between governments and industries across a wider spectrum how much better off we would be.

I will not bother to list all of the things we have done in tourism but they have all been positive and, despite what criticisms are offered per se about governments, very rarely does the Press or the industry offer a criticism of this Government about its efforts in tourism. This makes us all the more entitled to laugh about the honourable member putting forward this matter of public importance.

There are a few things honourable members may not know but are entitled to be made aware of. When I came to this job in 1983, in order to get statistics about tourism into Australia, I had to look back to 1979. The figures were four years out of date. After a long period of patient negotiation with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Foreign Affairs we got the gap down to four months. I am happy to tell honourable members that tourism figures are now available to the Australian industry in a fortnight, and that happens to be the lowest waiting time in the world. Figures are available to our tourism operators more quickly in Australia, because of the efforts of this Government, than they are in any other country. As I mentioned in the House yesterday, last week I was invited to Egypt by the Egyptian Minister for Tourism. If ever there was a country whose income has depended for two centuries on tourism, it is Egypt, with its incredible array of antiquities. How flattering for Australia to have its tourism Minister invited to Egypt to advise the Egyptians on how to improve their numbers of tourists. The success of Australia in developing a tourism product, which is now the envy of the world, is something of which we should all be proud.

It grieves me no end to find my shadow Minister-the alternative Minister for tourism-coming in here today with this sort of flimsy matter of public importance and putting it up as a matter for serious debate in this House. I am sure that he must be embarrassed. To find his Leader sitting behind him making no attempt to stop his outpourings of gutter filth really amazed me. I would have thought that this House was entitled to a better standard of debate than that which we have just heard from my shadow Minister. It is no wonder that the Opposition is held in absolute disrespect, not only by the tourism industry, but also by the people of Australia generally. If ever the Opposition had an opportunity to win an election, it was last July. But what happened? We increased our majority. If ever a government threw caution to the wind, it was this one in going to an election when it did. But the Opposition could not even win then, and thank God it did not. We heard the ragbag promises that the Opposition made about tax cuts. Can honourable members imagine the effect on the Australian economy at the moment had the Opposition been sitting on this side of the House prior to the stock exchange crash? Can they imagine the disaster for Australia?

The Opposition's efforts on tourism when it was in government were fairly representative of its understanding of business or promotion-they were deplorable. The Opposition had the opportunity of a lifetime. This country had more to offer the world as a tourist destination than any other country in the world. But lacking imagination, wit or any form of business knowledge, the Opposition let the opportunity slip; it let it slide away. We have not, and I am very proud to stand here as Minister for Tourism in this Government and stand on our record of achievement. How the Opposition could put up a matter of public importance which mentions `failure . . . to achieve its full potential, resulting in the loss of job opportunities and income for Australia's economy' as a serious matter for debate, is absolutely beyond me.

I have already mentioned the figures. We have more than doubled the employment and we have trebled the turnover. We have trebled the number of international tourists coming into Australia. We are now the only country in the world that has the problem of too many tourists. What other country in the world has a national airline that has difficulty bringing in the number of visitors who wish to come? A veritable torrent of people want to come to Australia simply because it is recognised as a haven for tourists. That is because it is safe. We have managed to keep it safe and I will not claim credit for that for this Government alone-it is a credit to previous governments that Australia is the safest country in the world. We have a stable economy and a stable political system. We have everything going for us. All the Opposition failed to realise was that we had to tell the world about it. Why should Australia have been the best kept secret in the world? The Opposition has learnt nothing from its years in opposition. One would have thought that my fourth shadow Minister for Tourism would have learnt something positive about the tourist industry. Given the opportunity to come here in a serious debate, what do I find? I get personal abuse, absolute invective, unsubstantiated claims of misleading this House-not in a substantive motion-and quotes from some filthy farrago that someone has purported to put about as the alleged transcript of a phone conversation that I allegedly made to someone called Don. That is the serious contribution that the shadow Minister makes to a debate on tourism. We do not have too many such debates. I would have thought that the honourable member for Gilmore would have known better than that. I thought better of him. I hope that he takes the opportunity at the end of this debate to apologise.

I do not propose to go on any longer. It is not a matter of running out of things to say; I have said them all before. I think that I have done more than I should have by dignifying this motion with a response. I am quite happy to rest on the laurels of this Government. They are there for everybody to examine. Australia is the tourism success of the world, acknowledged by every legitimate traditional tourist country. None of them has even approached our record. We have had a 32 per cent growth in international tourism. The average growth of the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which embraces all the traditional tourist countries-Greece, Spain, Britain, France and Italy-is 2 per cent and ours is 32 per cent. Yet the honourable member for Gilmore has the gall to come in here and put up this matter of public importance that purports to criticise this Government for failing to use Australia's potential. Our case rests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I have been reflecting on the speech I made at the beginning of the debate on the matter of public importance. I wish to apologise for not reflecting the House in a good light. I wish to withdraw statements that I made in relation to an alleged car phone conversation among two people. I apologise to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I get to the substance of this particular matter of public importance, may I put on the record this House's deep and heartfelt thanks for the contribution that has been made to the development of tourism in this country by the entrepreneurs of the industry-the State tourist bodies, the inbound tourist operators of Australia and the many thousands of people who battled against all odds prior to 1983 to make sure that Australia had the nucleus of a tourist industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to denigrate what this Government has done, but I am fed up with hearing in this House all the time that the magic tourism tap was switched on by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) in 1983 as soon as he came to government. That is not the fact. At a time when Australia is suffering the greatest foreign debt problems in its history and at a time when the balance of payments position of this country is in dire trouble, there is only one industry that is in a growth mode and that is tourism. There is only one industry that has the capacity to provide long term jobs for young Australians and that is the tourist industry. At a time when we should be doing absolutely everything we can to help that industry, to help our balance of payments and to encourage people to come to Australia, we have in fact an incompetent government that is trying to turn off that tap just as hard as it possibly can.

I am fed up with reading the articles that have been put out by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) and the answers he has been giving in this House in the last few days about the real situation of inbound tourist seats to Australia on Qantas Airways Ltd and other international airlines. The plain facts are that there has been a complete and utter failure of any sort of real planning for the tourist industry in Australia by members of this Government. The Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories must take their share of the blame. It is bilge to claim that this crisis of inbound seats to Australia has been caused, as we heard from Qantas today, by an increase of 17 per cent in the number of Australians travelling out of the country in September and coming back in October. The bilge, the garbage and the dish water that came out of the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support this afternoon in Question Time are sheer evidence of that. He has admitted that there has been a 30 to 40 per cent increase in the number of international visitors coming to Australia this year.

Let us look at the real situation-not the panic moves by Qantas with 162 supplementary flights over the next two months, not the panic moves by the Department of Transport and Communications to let 80 supplementary flights by foreign carriers into Australia. Let us look at the real records. Last Friday I took some random samples from the international airlines coming into Australia. These are the real stories. Air-India is not noted as one of the major carriers into Australia. One would think that one would be able to get a seat on this airline. One cannot get a seat until mid-February 1988. One hundred people are wait-listed on all flights. With regard to Alitalia Airlines, we are getting inbound tourists out of Rome. The next available seats are in early February and wait lists are very heavy. The next available seats on British Airways are in late February and wait lists are very heavy, with most of them closed. The next available seats on KLM Royal Dutch Airlines are on 24 February. Wait lists for December and January are impossible but there is an outside chance that a seat might be available on a wait list in February. Lufthansa, the German airline, brings in the biggest spending tourists and we want to get them in. The next available seats on that airline are in mid-February 1988. It has very heavy wait lists, with no chance of getting on. With the Malaysian Airline System, the next available seats are in mid-February with heavy wait lists. The next available seats on Olympic Airways are on 19 February. On Thai International the next available seat will be on 3 March. On United Airlines the next available seat will be on 20 January, but that is a rarity. On UTA French Airlines the next available seat will be in early March. On Singapore Airlines the next available seat will be on 15 February.

Is the Minister saying that this growth has been brought about purely by the bubble that suddenly burst? Is the Minister saying that the excuses now being made are being put up by the Government to get it over this interim period? The plain fact is that Australia is entering its bicentenary year next year and we have World Expo 88, but for four years the Minister responsible for tourism has been telling us in this House that we are to have two million visitors. He told us this afternoon that there were to be 2.3 million visitors. The unofficial estimate is 2.6 million. However, the truth is that there are not enough airline seats on aircraft coming into Australia to handle the increased traffic. That has been brought about by the lack of planning and lack of direction provided by this Government to the Department of Aviation, to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and to Qantas itself. In the tourism industry, our only growth industry, the only industry able to provide jobs for young people, we are hearing excuses all the way down the line.

We heard recently that Qantas was allowing supplementary airlines to come in if they wanted to. But let us examine the facts behind the applications by some of these foreign airlines. Those airlines will make money out of tourism into Australia; they will be bringing people into this country. Those airlines initially have to talk to Qantas to see whether Qantas will allow them to come in. That is why, whenever one has a question on notice about applications for air rights, one is told none have been laid. The reason is that, when most international carriers go along to Qantas, they talk and talk but nothing ever happens, and the airlines give up.

Let me give the House some examples. Korean Air has been trying for five years to get into Australia; the matter has even reached the diplomatic level, but nothing has happened. Scandinavian Airlines Systems applied every year for 16 years to come into Australia, but gave up in frustration. Aerolineas Argentinas-and the Argentineans are some of the biggest travellers in the world-has been flying into Auckland for 10 years. The passengers hop off the 747s, hop on to the Air New Zealand 747 and off they go. That airline has been trying to come into Australia for 10 years, but Qantas has said no, because it has no interest in operating on the South American route. Then it hit the Press that Cathay Pacific, equal partners on the Hong Kong-Australia route, with seven services a week, said to Qantas, `There is too much traffic; neither of us can handle it. Let us have another one each'. Qantas said, `No, we will have two to your one'. This is what is going on. The Government may not be aware of it, but it is happening and must stop.

A few years ago the Government said, `Let us bring in the charter operators', but the restrictions meant that a charter operator could not operate over an established Qantas route, despite the fact that with specialist tourist traffic the ground content must be bought here. But Qantas said no. What happened? There was one application from Denmark. Six months later the carrier still did not have approval, and had six weeks in which to sell 2,000 seats. It could not do so, and pulled out in disgust. All Nippon Airways operated services out of Tokyo into Cairns. What happened there? Sure, it got its charters, but as soon as that happened Qantas blackmailed again, went straight in on the route and knocked off the opportunity for any further charters.

We continually hear from this Government the line that there are not enough hotel rooms in Australia. In only one city is there a major shortage of hotel rooms, and that is Sydney. It is interesting to analyse the relationship between flights into Australia and where people want to go. One sees from the figures that 81 per cent of the direct airline seats and flights come into Sydney. But what percentage of visitor nights are spent by international visitors in New South Wales? The answer is 32 per cent. Let me relate that to the position in Queensland. Queensland has a total of 16 per cent of all international flights, only 12 per cent of seats available, but 38 per cent of the total number of international visitors coming into Australia want to go to Queensland. Based on the figure of 16 per cent, Queensland gets 24 per cent of visitor nights. One can go through every State of Australia and see that story.

The problem is that there has been no co-ordination, no planning and no leadership from this Government or from this Minister. There has been no leadership from the Department. Even last week, on November 11, when the emergency conference on seat availability into Australia was called, the contribution made by the Minister's Department, according to my information, was minimal. We had very little in terms of leadership from the Australian Tourist Commission. For the sake of our international financial position, for the sake of long term jobs for our young Australians, this Minister must take the lead. He must make sure that we have colleges that can provide staff. We should be sure to avoid the present position of having to import 3,000 people to work in the tourist industry because we have not enough trained staff. This is what leadership is all about. This is the way in which we shall get our economy a little better than it is now-through tourism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of the matter of public importance are an attempt to reflect on what purports to be a failure of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) to promote Australia's tourist industry to achieve its full potential. It also purports to suggest that there has been a loss of job opportunities and income for Australia's economy because of the policies of this Government. Judging by the contributions of the two Opposition speakers in this debate, one would hardly think that they had substantiated that claim. The Minister has already responded to the remarks of the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and I do not propose to add anything, other than to say that I share the view of many members on both sides of this House that that contribution was outrageous and that there was no need for it whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a couple of points in emphasising that the terms of the matter of public importance are nonsensical. If the facts are examined and taken point by point, one can substantiate the view that this Government, through its leadership and that of the Minister, has contributed to the growth of tourism. It is a fact that $14 billion-worth of development is taking place right around Australia at this minute aimed at the tourist industry.

The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) made great play of the failure of Qantas Airways Ltd and the necessity to create opportunities at colleges of advanced education to train people for the tourist industry. In my electorate of Macarthur we have under construction and almost completed a brand new tourism and food school as part of the technical and further education college at Wollongong. That will do exactly what the honourable member is asking the Government to do, that is, to provide opportunities to train people in the hospitality and tourist industries. That goes side by side with the other tourist courses already being offered in institutions in the Illawarra. This Government paid for the establishment of those facilities.

The honourable member for Fadden sought to compare Qantas with Cathay Pacific in respect of additional routes to Hong Kong and said that the position involved a two for one arrangement. Surely there is nothing wrong with that. The arrangement will improve opportunities for Qantas to fly people on Australia's airline, which we all wish to see prosper. The honourable member also spoke of Qantas protecting its own territory. What happens, for example, in countries such as the United States? Qantas has been endeavouring for years to get into markets in the United States and has been refused entry. It can fly to the West Coast and nowhere else, and the honourable member knows it. As for the other airlines, I agree that there was a modicum of truth in the honourable member's remarks. I support entirely the proposition he put forward that lack of planning, not only by Qantas but by many air carriers throughout the world, has contributed to the problem of getting people in and out of Australia. I also agree that events such as Expo 88, the Bicentenary and so on will contribute to the desire of people to come to this country. But I also make the point, as I think the honourable member will concede, that this upturn in tourism into Australia has been increasing gradually over the last few years. It is not a phenomenon that happened all at once. It has been increasing over a few years because of the fascination of a number of people with Australia as a tourist destination for a variety of reasons. Australia is a safe destination. It has some magnificent scenery and facilities, which people now want to see. I agree with the honourable member that locations around the country such as the Whitsunday Islands, the Gold Coast, central Australia, Sydney, Melbourne and even Canberra-when the new Parliament House is complete Canberra will improve even more as a tourist destination-are all attracting people more and more to this country. We have to facilitate that.

I hope that the honourable member and the shadow Minister will talk to their people about the question of Qantas's future. Discussion has been taking place on all sides of the political arena about the future of Qantas regarding privatisation, and whether half of it, some of it, all of it or none of it should be privatised. A view being run at present is that honourable members opposite are looking for 100 per cent dispersal of any equity the Government might have in Qantas. I suggest that that should be looked at very carefully. I hope that the Opposition will support a massive capital injection for Qantas in the future to enable it effectively to upgrade its services and to take advantage of its expanded requirements to fly overseas and to bring people back here. I hope that we get a bipartisan approach to this matter.

The honourable member for Gilmore and the honourable member for Fadden talked about the incompetence and lack of leadership of this Minister and this Government in terms of the tourist industry. In 1983, 250,000 people were employed in the tourist industry. In 1987, the figure is 450,000. It is growing all the time. Every place in Australia is looking to tourism to supplement its economic base. My own area of Illawarra and, as the shadow Minister at the table well knows, the Shoalhaven area further south in his electorate are endeavouring to capture the tourist market-the day trippers and the extended stayers. We should be encouraging them to do so.

In Wollongong we are seeing a massive expansion in the provision of tourist facilities. We have seen what has happened on the Gold Coast and in the Whitsundays. Proposals for massive development are being put forward in these areas. I agree with the honourable member for Fadden that the entrepreneurs in the tourist industry have to be congratulated. This Government does congratulate them. It provides the incentives through taxation concessions and other measures that encourage them to get involved in the tourist industry and to promote it even further. We need to do that. Australia as a tourist destination is increasing in popularity all the time.

It is quite interesting to look at the employment levels in restaurants, hotels and clubs. It is estimated that 214,000 people were employed in those industries in 1985. In 1987, 255,000 are employed. That is despite the claims that were made, which have been revived in debate in this House, that the fringe benefits tax and a range of other incentives were going to decimate completely the restaurant industry. It simply is not so; it is not a fact, and the statistics support that view.

A set of statistics which I believe is quite relevant to this debate centres on trying to work out a methodology of comparing the export earnings equivalent of Japanese tourists, for example, coming to Australia with what primary industries contribute to the Australian economy. In 1986-87, a Japanese tourist spent approximately $1,406 per trip in Australia, excluding his air fare. If one uses that as a basis and considers the amount of revenue that is earned by a variety of commodities in Australia some very interesting statistics can be thrown up. If one considers the average export price for wool, sugar, alumina, wheat, coal and iron ore and then takes the figure for how much each Japanese tourist spends in Australia, it can be seen that the rounded result is that there are three tourists for one tonne of wool, one tourist for five tonnes of sugar, one tourist for seven tonnes of alumina, one tourist for 10 tonnes of wheat, one tourist for 25 tonnes of coal-that should interest people in my area-and one tourist for 59 tonnes of iron ore.

That is the value to the economy of the tourist influx into this country, which we should be supporting. We were considering the statistics and the contribution that has been made by and the leadership that has been given to the tourist industry by the Minister and by this Government. Some criticism was levelled recently at the Minister leading a tourism investment mission to Japan. It is worth quoting once again what Mr John Haddad, the business group leader who went with the Minister, had to say:

The members were impressed by the Minister's involvement in all aspects of their activities, and his availability at all times to support individual member's needs throughout the conference was particularly appreciated. I know that the Mission has created a new level of sophisticated negotiation within the market in Japan which will be of enormous benefit to the future of our expanding tourist industry. We can look forward to the benefits of this Mission well into the future.

That is what a man in the business community and the tourist community had to say about this Minister and this Government's approach to tourism activity. We on this side of the House totally reject the form of this matter of public importance. We certainly reject the personal attack that has been levelled on the Minister by those opposite today. We reject the Opposition's criticism out of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973, which is the legislative basis for the provision of student assistance under Austudy and for the grant of post-graduate awards. The proposed measures are designed to facilitate the prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments under student assistance schemes. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) recently announced the outcome of the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth. The main thrust of the Review's findings was that agencies affected by fraud should have the principal responsibility for its prevention and detection. It is intended progressively to implement measures to prevent, detect and recover moneys which have been wrongfully paid under programs administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

As a first step towards making student assistance schemes less vulnerable and to assist in recovering overpayments, the Government is proposing that the Student Assistance Act be amended to bring it into line with the Social Security Act in matters relating to the gathering of information, and the recovery and write-off and waiver of overpayments in relation to the schemes. It is reasonable and proper that the powers provided to the various Commonwealth authorities for the administration of income support schemes should be similar, to the extent that this is feasible. At present the Department obtains information from educational institutions and Government authorities to verify particulars provided by students in their applications. The proposed new section 31d will give legislative support for such arrangements and will facilitate the acquisition of information to ensure that the income tests are applied correctly and that the funds to support students, which are provided at considerable cost to the community, are directed to those for whom they are intended. Recovery will be strengthened by the introduction of measures similar to those already provided in the Social Security Act, to recover overpayments from money owing to a debtor. The proposed new section 31a will allow overpayments of student assistance, social security or veterans' benefits to be offset against an entitlement under the Student Assistance Act. The Bill will also amend the social security and veterans legislation to extend their recovery provisions in a similar manner.

The Bill provides for the maximum penalties under the Student Assistance Act to be increased. At present the maximum penalty for offences under the student assistance legislation is $100. This has little deterrent value for people who might consider attempting to obtain money fraudulently. The maximum penalties as outlined in the proposed new section 31h are to be increased to $2,000 and/or 12 months imprisonment for individuals who make false or misleading statements or otherwise seek to deceive in order to obtain benefits unlawfully. There is a proposed maximum penalty of $10,000 for corporations which refuse to co-operate in arrangements to verify entitlements and to recover payments which should not have been made. The proposed penalties are in line with those prescribed under the Social Security Act.

The waiver and write-off powers to be provided in proposed new section 31c are similar to those applying under the Social Security Act. At present, these powers in relation to student assistance schemes are exercised by the Minister for Finance under the Audit Act. It is considered more appropriate that they be exercised by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training as part of the overall responsibility for the administration of student assistance programs. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
