DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes a series of amendments to the principal Customs Act 1901 and Excise Act 1901, the most important of which are the amendments to the valuation provisions of the Customs Act 1901, division 2 of part VIII, and the introduction of consequential enforcement and penalty provisions. Their purpose is to effect the second instalment of the Government's strategy to combat commercial practices designed solely or predominantly to understate the value of imported goods, so as to minimise or avoid customs duty.

With respect to the proposed amendments to the valuation provisions of the Customs Act, which are contained in clause 12 of this Bill, honourable members will recall that the Government announced at the second reading stage of the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill last sittings that it would be introducing further amendments to the valuation provisions of the Customs Act, to augment the reforms of that first Bill. The focus of the valuation amendments in this Bill is the rearrangement of the various provisions in division 2 of part VIII of the Customs Act into a more logical and easy to follow sequence, and the highlighting of the various types of costs, charges and agreements relating to goods which will be included or excluded for the purposes of assessing the customs value of the goods. There are also some important new provisions and amendments that are designed to combat minimisation and avoidance practices used by some importers in valuing goods for duty purposes.

Once again, I should emphasise that the Government is not accusing all importers of engaging in avoidance practices. However, experience has shown that some importers have entered arrangements that are designed solely to reduce assessable customs value and thereby reduce duty liability. The Government is therefore of the view that any opportunity for abuse must be removed as soon as it is discovered.

The extent to which minimisation and avoidance practices erode the revenue and existing assistance levels is reflected in the many submissions and complaints received from local manufacturers and producers concerning the commercial advantage which some importers enjoy as a result of their avoidance of correct duty. Investigations and inquiries by the Australian Customs Service into the activities of importers regarding the valuation of imported goods often lead to the imposition of additional duty and/or litigation being commenced by either the Customs Service or the importer.

Allow me to demonstrate some known avoidance practices which this Bill will eliminate. The inclusion of inland freight charges in customs value is presently being avoided through the payment of these charges by the purchaser to a third party. Because the vendor invoices the goods to the purchaser at an ex-factory level, the inland freight charges under the current provisions of the Act are not included in the customs value, as only payments from the purchaser to the vendor are presently dutiable. It is important to note that investigations of the Industries Assistance Commission into appropriate levels of industries assistance are based on free on board prices; that is, the price of the goods at the point of exportation.

Proposed new section 154 in clause 12 of the Bill extensively redefines `place of export', `foreign inland freight' and `foreign inland insurance' to eliminate the practice of using third party forwarders to avoid duty on inland freight charges.

Another area of avoidance is in overseas freight charges. To achieve the correct customs value for duty purposes, particularly on `cost insurance and freight' invoices, the Australian Customs Service must be sure that the actual overseas freight paid or payable is deducted from the invoice price. It is the experience of Customs that freight costs are being manipulated in various ways to decrease the customs value, by overstating freight, or to increase the customs value, by understating freight, in order to avoid dumping duties. There are also practices which indirectly affect the amount of duty paid or payable. The main method here is the payment of rebates by shipping companies to the overseas vendor or to purchasers in Australia. The result is that true duty liability is effectively concealed until after importation, resulting in a substantial loss to revenue. The new definition of overseas freight is designed to give Customs the power to question freight costs shown on invoices and commercial shipping documents to establish the actual freight paid or payable.

A third practice which I will mention briefly is the deduction of so-called buying commissions. Buying commission is an allowable deduction from the price if it is genuine. The problem being experienced by Customs in this area is the difficulty in determining what is a true buying commission. The proposed new section 155 in clause 12 of the Bill is designed to specify situations which preclude agents from holding themselves out to be genuine buying agents. It is the intention of this legislation to eliminate these practices, and others, which have provided opportunities for avoidance of duty through the minimisation of the value of imported goods. An integral part of these reforms which was foreshadowed last sittings is the inclusion of appropriate information gathering and auditing powers for Customs, to verify information supplied to it, together with new and tougher sanctions for the provision of false or misleading information.

Proposed new section 159 in clause 12 imposes a clear responsibility on persons entering goods which are required to be valued to estimate the customs value of the goods, and to provide details on how the value was determined. If Customs is not satisfied with the assessment or supporting information it can seek additional information or undertake an audit of the transaction. The focus on self-assessment for customs duty purposes was begun in 1985, when the Customs Service introduced streamlined procedures for the entry and clearance of imported goods. These procedures now result in almost 90 per cent of cargo arriving in Australia by either air or sea being cleared from Customs control within four hours of the entry being lodged with Customs. In many instances the cargo is still being discharged from the aircraft or ship. Further enhancements to the computer system and procedures are planned or being developed, and it is anticipated that in approximately two years the process will be fully automated.

The streamlined procedures provide for the balance-some 10 per cent-of the import transactions to come under close scrutiny. The transactions are selected using `risk assessment techniques' and `profiles'. This process, similar to that used by the Australian Taxation Office, will require Customs audit officers to visit importers and closely study commercial documents relevant to the import transaction, to ensure that the goods have been correctly valued for customs purposes and the appropriate duty paid.

Clause 22 includes a new power for Customs officers to enter premises on which commercial documents relating to information that was supplied to Customs for purposes connected with the entry of goods are kept, to inspect, examine and so on those documents, for the purposes of verifying that information. Clause 25 introduces a new requirement for importers to keep the commercial documents relating to the goods which they have imported for a period of five years. The Government believes both these new provisions will enable the auditing process which I have outlined to be carried out effectively. The Bill also provides in clause 26 for automatic penalties to be imposed in instances where duty evasion has been detected. These provisions, which again are similar to those in taxation legislation, will be used in lieu of the seizure of goods and the costly and protracted litigation which inevitably follows such actions.
Financial Impact Statement

The financial impact of the valuation amendments contained in this Bill is considerable. While it cannot be quantified to any exact degree, I will endeavour to show by example that the loss to the revenue by use of such practices cannot be ignored.

In regard to third party inland freight agreements, if the motor vehicle industry of one exporting country changed to ex-factory contracts, and its Australian purchasers employed third party forwarders, the loss of duty receipts would conservatively amount to $5.2m in one year, seriously affecting the local motor vehicle industry. Exact quantification of duty shortfall caused by manipulation of overseas freight charges cannot be achieved, due to the various methods employed to manipulate freight amounts. Rebates given by shipping companies to preferred customers are the most common cause of duty shortfall but, because the practice is widespread and most often occurs overseas, it can only be said that the loss to the revenue could amount to many millions of dollars per annum. I do not know whether the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) wishes to comment on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will leave it until later.

—By claiming a deduction for a buying agent's commission where the agent is related to the vendor, it was estimated early this year, one major importer had saved about $4m customs duty in a year. If all the major importers adopted the practice, there would be a revenue loss of $90m per annum. The new section 155 proposed in clause 12 lists various things that a genuine buying agent cannot do, and it is estimated that this provision will eliminate many commissions currently being deducted from customs value as buying commissions under the current provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat the statement I made on the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill in the last sittings, that the effect of these practices on local industry has not been quantified, but it is obvious that any erosion of assistance levels by avoidance and minimisation practices can only be detrimental to local industry and employment. These measures are designed to remove this erosion and restore a stable valuation base. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, principally to incorporate into that Act various excise tariff proposals tabled in this Parliament during the last sittings and early in the current sittings, and to give effect to changes to the excise arrangements for crude oil that follow from the Government's decision to deregulate crude oil marketing with effect from 1 January 1988. The proposed deregulation arrangements contained in clauses 8 to 10 inclusive of the Bill amend the Excise Tariff Act to change the basis of calculating the excise due on the production of crude oil from Bass Strait from one based on the import parity price to one based on the volume weighted average prices realised for crude oil sales by the Bass Strait producers, as determined according to the provisions of the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill 1987, of which my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has carriage.

On 21 June the then Minister for Resources and Energy, now Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), announced the Government's decision to deregulate completely crude oil marketing with effect from 1 January 1988. This will permit refiners and all crude oil producers to negotiate freely the quantities and prices of crude oil they buy and sell without government involvement. The Government believes that moving to a free market for crude oil will optimise Australia's future crude oil self-sufficiency consistent with the efficient allocation of resources. This move will enable the Australian crude oil industry to develop strongly in future for the benefit of the Australian community.

From 1 January 1988 the Government will no longer determine import parity prices (IPPs) as the basis for transactions of domestic crude oil and the determination of excise. Clause 8 of this Bill provides for excise to be determined on the basis of volume weighted average of realised prices for sales of Bass Strait crude oil, known as the `volware' price. These prices will be determined each month by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy under the provisions of the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill. The initial excise liabilities of the crude oil producers for each month will be calculated on the basis of reference prices notified to the producers and the Australian Customs Service. These prices will be based on recent volware prices and other factors such as movements in world oil market prices for crude oil and changes in exchange rates. Interim volware prices for the month will also be calculated on the basis of sales information provided by the producers and notified during the following month. The producers' initial excise liabilities will be adjusted from those calculated using the reference price, and thereafter interim prices will form the basis of excise liability until final volware prices are determined.

The provisions of this Bill introduce arrangements which will allow adjustments to be made to the producers' crude oil excise liability which result from using reference, interim and final volware prices. These arrangements will mean that the adjustments to the producers' excise liabilities will be affected automatically following the determination of the volware prices, and thereby avoid the situation whereby excise liability could have remained outstanding for long periods.

The import parity price adjustments, at clauses 13, 15 and 16 of the Bill, continue the Government's policy since 1 March 1986 to offset fully changes in revenue from crude oil excise and royalty by across the board changes in excises payable on petroleum products. The net result of this policy is that as crude oil prices change government revenues remain the same overall and petrol price changes are kept to a minimum.

On 1 May 1987, the IPPs of indigenous crude oils were decreased to reflect an appreciation of the Australian dollar against the United States dollar, and the excise rates on refined petroleum products were correspondingly increased with effect from 16 May 1987, as in clause 13. On 1 July 1987 and 1 August 1987 the IPPs of indigenous crude oils were increased to reflect upward movements in world oil prices and, consistent with the Government's policy, the excise rates on refined petroleum products were reduced with effect from 18 July 1987, as in clause 15, and 15 August 1987, as in clause 16, respectively. Clauses 6, 8 and 14 of the Bill give effect to the Government's decisions, following its review of new petroleum taxation arrangements, to remove distortions and disincentives to petroleum exploration and development in Australia.

The review follows the Government's undertaking at the time of the Energy 2000 Conference in September 1986, where the oil industry pressed strongly for the removal of all secondary taxation on petroleum production, arguing that the existing taxation regime was making Australia an unattractive place in which to invest in exploration and development. The Government's review established that some changes to the existing arrangements are necessary, given the reduction in the level of world crude oil prices and continuing uncertainty in their future levels, to ensure that Australia can continue to attract oil exploration and development investment.

The package of concessions will apply to both existing crude oil production and new projects where excise and royalty apply-namely, Bass Strait, North West Shelf and on-shore areas. Elsewhere off-shore, the resource rent tax regime announced in 1984 will continue to apply. The key elements in the new excise package are as follows:

confirmation that the maximum rate of `old' oil excise will not be restored to 87 per cent of the import parity price and that there will be a progressive lowering of the top marginal rate of excise on such oil from 80 per cent to 75 per cent over the next three years;
exemption from excise of the first 30 million barrels of crude oil production from new off-shore projects where excise and royalty apply;
exemption from excise of the first 30 million barrels of crude oil produced from on-shore fields;
exemption from excise of condensate marketed separately from crude oil; and
exemption from excise of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) produced on-shore.

Clause 14 of the Bill also includes an increase in the excise duty rate on aviation gasolene. This follows extensive consultation with the general aviation industry on the most appropriate cost recovery and charging arrangements to apply in 1987-88, and the Government's decision to adopt a suggestion made by the industry to place a surcharge on aviation gasolene-avgas-fuel excise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Avgas.
—Nobody knows more about avgas than the Minister for Resources. This proposal, which sets the surcharge at 3.9c a litre, has the full support of all the major general aviation organisations.
—He has his pilots licence now.

—Yes, he will have to declare an interest. The surcharge replaces the previous fixed annual air navigation charges which had been payable by general aviation aircraft. In addition to the surcharge, general aviation avgas aircraft will pay landing charges at the major airports scheduled for transfer to the Federal Airports Corporation. General aviation aircraft using aviation kerosene-avtur-will pay landing charges for all operations on the same basis as airline aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: The final major inclusion in this Bill, at clause 5, effects a change to the operation of section 6a of the Act, relating to the automatic indexation of rates of duty. Presently the Act provides for rates of duty to be adjusted on 1 February and 1 August in accordance with movements in the consumer price index. This is dependent, however, on the Australian Statistician publishing the index number at least seven days before these dates. If this does not occur, which has been the majority of cases, the new rate is determined by Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice. Uncertainty concerning the commencement date of the new rates is causing undue disruption to business involved with implementing the new rates. To simplify procedures the proposed amendment will provide that in cases where the Australian Statistician does not publish the index number at least five days before 1 February or 1 August, the new rates will take effect five days after the Australian Statistician publishes the index number.
Financial Impact Statement
(A) DEREGULATION OF CRUDE OIL MARKETING ARRANGEMENTS (CLAUSES 8-10 INCLUSIVE)

The financial impact on crude oil excise receipts resulting from the proposed arrangements for the deregulated or a free market for crude oil will depend on the extent to which crude oil prices vary after deregulation. In the current international climate and in a deregulated market, average Bass Strait crude oil prices could be expected to fall between $A1 and $A4 a barrel from what they would have been under import parity pricing. On the basis of a price fall of $A2.50 per barrel, the drop in Government revenue in 1987-88 and 1988-89 is expected to be about $100m and $168m respectively. There will be no offsetting product excise adjustment to recoup revenue forgone by the Government as a result of any drop in crude oil prices following deregulation.
(B) IMPORT PARITY PRICE ADJUSTMENTS (CLAUSES 13, 15 AND 16 (b to g))

The increase in refined petroleum product excise rates due to the changes in the import parity prices effective from 16 May 1987 is expected to result in an increase in revenue of about $20m in 1986-87. The decrease in refined petroleum product excise rates effective from 1 July 1987 and 1 August 1987 is expected to result in decreases in revenue of about $7.2m and $82.7m respectively in 1987-88. The changes in the excise rates following changes to the import parity prices exactly offset the forecast changes in revenue from crude oil excise and royalty.
(C) NEW PETROLEUM TAXATION ARRANGEMENTS (OFF-SHORE AND ON-SHORE) (CLAUSES 6, 8 AND 14 (b to d))

The introduction of the new excise concessions on crude oil and LPG from 1 July 1987 are forecast to reduce Commonwealth and State government revenues by $18m in 1987-88 and by $297m in the five years to 1991-92. Higher production levels as a result of the new concessions will generate additional excise and royalty receipts which are expected to more than compensate for the cost of the concessions based on previous production forecasts by the producers. In 1987-88, the Commonwealth is forecast to receive an additional $670m, and in the five years ending 1991-92 the higher production levels will generate an additional $3.2 billion in excise and royalty collections for the Commonwealth and State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wow!
—If the honourable member gets her hands on it there will not be much left.
—Order!
—I shall continue:

SPEECH.PARA: (D) AVIATION GASOLENE SURCHARGE (CLAUSE 14 (a))
It is estimated that the surcharge will raise around $3.9m in 1987-88.
(E) AUTOMATIC INDEXATION CHANGES (CLAUSE 5)
The amendments proposed by this clause have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The principal purpose of this Bill is to provide for using the volume weighted average price for sales of Bass Strait crude oil as the price basis for levying excise on crude oil produced from the Bass Strait from 1 January 1988, the date on which Australia's crude oil market will be deregulated. This Bill should be read in conjunction with the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1987 which is within the portfolio of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). The introduction of this Bill and other associated legislative amendments is an essential step in implementing the Government's decision to deregulate crude oil marketing in Australia with effect from 1 January 1988. Deregulation will permit all of the Australia's crude oil producers and refiners to negotiate freely the quantities and prices of crude oil they buy and sell without government involvement. The Government believes that this freeing of the crude oil market will optimise Australia's future crude oil self-sufficiency consistent with the efficient allocation of resources.

The deregulation decision means that the allocation scheme for crude oil and import parity pricing will be abolished, and the Bass Strait coastal freight adjustment scheme, used to compensate refiners remote from Bass Strait for their higher costs of transporting allocated crude, will then be terminated. Except in times of emergency and subject to other relevant policies, such as the prohibition of exports to South Africa, Australia's crude oil producers will have complete freedom to export as an alternative to selling on the domestic market and refiners will have the freedom to import crude oil.

This decision followed a six-month review of the present import parity pricing and market allocation arrangements. The review took into account the views of State governments, producers and refiners, trade unions and consumers. It also looked closely at the impact of a free market on crude oil and product prices, government revenues and the balance of payments. It was concluded that, in the light of changed circumstances in the overall marketing environment, the benefits of deregulation would now outweigh the costs. The changes included a substantial decline in world oil prices, substantial changes in the Australian exchange rate and balance of payments situation and, above all else, the start of the long anticipated decline in Bass Strait production which, in the absence of major new discoveries, will mean a steady rise in the volume of imported crude oil.

The financial impact of moving to a free market for crude oil will depend on the extent to which crude oil prices fall after deregulation. In a deregulated market, average Bass Strait crude oil prices could be expected initially to fall between $A1 and $A4 from what they would have been under import parity pricing. A price fall in the middle of this range of, say, $A2.50 per barrel would result, when passed through to the consumer, in petrol prices falling by around 1.3c per litre. Although this could mean a drop in Government revenue from the crude oil excise of about $100m in 1987-88 and $168m in 1988-89 the Government is committed to not offsetting this reduced revenue by compensating adjustments to petroleum product excise, so that the full benefit of any crude oil price reductions is passed on to the consumer. This potential drop in revenue was, of course, taken into account as part of the Budget considerations.

In reaching the decision to deregulate the crude oil market the Government considered the previously expressed concerns of the parties affected. Small producers, with production of less than 5,000 barrels per day, were concerned that they would be disadvantaged after deregulation because of their small production volumes, remoteness from infrastructure and lack of marketing skills. It was decided that the best way of providing support for the existing small producers was to obtain assurances from refiners that they will continue to lift the output of small producers in a timely manner and at fair market prices. Responses have been given by refiners that indicate these conditions will be met. In addition, small producers will now have options other than to sell to refiners. These will include selling to large producers and pipeline owners or having them act as marketing agents, using the services of commodity brokers or trading companies, or exporting their oil. Indeed all producers, small or large, may well find opportunities in a free market which were not available or considered in a regulated market.

Assurances have also been obtained from refiners that deregulation would not result in the closure of any Australian refinery and refiners will maintain their existing arrangements for Australian flag shipping, albeit with some changes to shipping patterns. Although it is not possible to be sure of the balance of payments effects of deregulation in advance, it is likely that the net effect on the value of imports of crude oil is likely to be either neutral or positive. Major refineries have argued that deregulation will give Australian refiners access to different grades of imported crude oil suitable for their technologically advanced refineries at prices significantly below current domestic rates. Consequently, some higher quality Australian crude oil will be exported, but this should be at higher prices than the imports, resulting in a net balance of payments gain.

Other opportunities that oil industry analysts have identified as potentially flowing from deregulation are in the export of refined products based on Australia's sophisticated refineries and excellent local gasoline feedstock. Also deregulation could open the way for further foreign investment in Australian oil exploration and development.

As part of moving to the free market and at the same time maintaining the flow of revenue to the Commonwealth, an excise system for crude oil based on prices achieved in the free market is required rather than one based on the Government imposed import parity price. This will ensure that the final price base for excise will not be higher than the average prices received by the procedures. The crude oil excise rates will be unchanged from those currently in force.

This Bill sets out the system of calculating those prices. It is directed towards oil production from the Bass Strait as this is currently the only production area producing excisable oil. Production from areas on-shore will become excisable in the event that production exceeds the 30 million barrel excise-free threshold. The price basis for excising such on-shore oil production will be considered at the appropriate time.

The basic principle of the proposed new crude oil excise system is that excise will be levied on crude oil from Bass Strait using the volume weighted average of realised f.o.b. prices of all sales in a calendar month-referred to in the Bill as `volware' prices. The basis for volware prices will be the realised price of oil at the point of entry for home consumption. This is the price of the oil as it is loaded on a ship at Long Island Point and Crib Point. For pipeline transactions, it will be the realised pipe inlet prices at Long Island Point. The price will be based on payment within 15 days, with an allowance for extended credit terms in excess of 15 days. Where the contracts for the sale of oil include shipping costs incurred after the point of entry for home consumption and to be borne by the producer, those shipping costs attributable to actual shipments will be deductible from the contract price. They will include freight, insurance, wharfage and other port charges at the port of destination, demurrage at the delivery end which falls to the producer under a c.i.f. contract and is clearly not caused by the producer, lightering at the port of destination, cargo inspection costs, heating of the cargo on the ship and bunkers.

The Bill makes provision for the determination of three prices for each month of sales. The first, the reference price, will be an estimate of the volware price made before the beginning of the month in question and will be used to calculate the producer's initial excise liability and payments for that month. This price will be based on the most recent interim volware price that has been set, and adjusted for other appropriate factors such as movements in world market prices for crude oil and changes in $A-$US exchange rate. The second, the interim volware price, will be calculated not later than one month after the end of the month in which the oil is sold, based on information provided by the producers about their sales in the month. Once determined, it will replace the reference price as the basis for excise calculations. Third, as some of that information may still be provisional, after six months, or earlier if final information is available, a final volware price for the month will be determined. Once determined, this final volware price will replace the interim volware price and will be the basis of the producers' final excise liability. The method of calculating the transaction prices for use in establishing volware prices will be set out in regulations.

Each of these prices will be notified to the producers and the Australian Customs Service, and the producers' excise liabilities will be adjusted as appropriate in subsequent excise payments. Because of their commercial sensitivity the prices will not be published. As a result of the progressive adjustments to the producers' excise liabilities and payments following the determinations of volware prices, there should not be substantial amounts of excise rebates or additional excise liability outstanding for long periods of time.

The Bill contains provisions requiring the producers to provide the Department of Primary Industries and Energy with the information required to calculate these prices within a time limit to be specified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. There are also provisions for auditing of the information.

Basing the excise on an average price gives the producers an incentive to maximise the price they receive above the average and therefore to reduce their effective excise rate. However, the Bill also has provisions to give Ministers the power to determine the price for any sale when any part of the sales transaction is considered not to be at `arm's length' and a price has been arranged which would reduce the revenue due.

This Bill provides for an effective and equitable system of collecting excise on crude oil production. It is a major component in the implementation of the Government's decision to deregulate the Australian crude oil market. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mrs Kelly, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill should be seen as part of the implementation of a series of decisions involving defence shipbuilding activities which the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced on 1 April this year. In that statement, he said:
. . . the Government has decided to offer for sale to commercial organisations a controlling interest in (Williamstown) Dockyard.

The rationale for this decision was that, notwithstanding substantial improvements, the dockyard's performance has continued to fall short of its own commitments and even further behind what might be expected from comparable yards. Operating under public sector constraints, Williamstown Dockyard is not well structured to remedy these deficiencies and to compete for the full prime contractor role for the new surface combatant or even project Anzac.

Two consortia are on the short list of tenderers to buy the dockyard. They are the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation, a consortium comprising Australian Shipbuilding Industries (ASI) of Western Australia, Eglo Engineering of South Australia, ICAL of New South Wales and Thorn EMI: and Williamstown Dockyard Consortium, a consortium consisting of Tecnav Pty Ltd-a group of employees at Williamstown Dockyard-Byvest Pty Ltd, a management buyout consultancy firm and McConnell-Dowell, a New Zealand based subsidiary of Inter Pacific Ltd.

Following the evaluation of their bids, the Government will decide which of them is to become the new owner of Williamstown Dockyard. This will be the most significant sale of Commonwealth assets so far undertaken in Australia. It will be significant because it will bring about a major restructuring of defence shipbuilding industry and it will have long term benefits for the Defence budget. The new owner of Williamstown Dockyard will take over the task of completing the two FFG7 class frigates that are being built there. They are planned for delivery in 1991 and 1993. With the four FFGs that were built in the United States of America, and the guided missile destroyers, they will form the first level of capability that was mentioned in the defence White Paper which the Minister tabled in March this year as able to contribute to a wide range of operations in both low level and more substantial contingencies.

In the same White Paper, the Minister discussed a second level of capability and the proposal for a new class of vessel-a light patrol frigate or as it is now known, the Anzac ship-to meet this requirement. This program of 12 ships is a collaborative one between Australia and New Zealand. It is expected that it will give rise to a resurgence in warship building in Australia and, like the submarine project, provide a continuing work load to Australian industry for many years to come. These two multi-billion dollar projects demonstrate the Government's resolve to support local industry and to bring new technologies to Australia. Expressions of interest have been called for both the design of the Anzac ship and for the role of the prime contractor for the construction of the ships. The Government's strategy is to have the overseas ship designers join Australian consortia in tendering for the construction of these new ships. The Minister hopes to be in a position to announce the name of the new owner of Williamstown Dockyard and the tenderers for the prime contractor role in the near future. The Anzac ship project represents the largest shipbuilding program undertaken in Australia since World War II. It demonstrates this Government's commitment to the defence of Australia and its willingness to make the decisions necessary to implement the commitment.

Williamstown Dockyard's work force of some 1,600 are employed under both the Public Service Act and the Naval Defence Act. Neither of these Acts makes provision for mobility between public and private employment. This Bill recognises that there is continuity of employment in this case. It is designed to facilitate the handover of the dockyard to the new owner without the absurdity of making employees eligible for large redundancy payments where there is continuity of employment. This could result in savings to the Commonwealth of between $4m and $13m, dependent on the number of employees involved.

There has been an exhaustive program of consultation with the unions and staff associations at Williamstown Dockyard under the aegis of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The Bill before the House enshrines the agreements reached between the Department of Defence and the Department of Industrial Relations, the Public Service Commission and the ACTU and dockyard unions. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987]
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering the Bill and the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the lunch break I was bemoaning in this debate on the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) the Government's inability to come up with more of the right sorts of approaches to the health problems of Australians. These pieces of legislation deal with pharmaceutical benefits in particular, and extend the rights to pharmaceutical benefits in certain circumstances. I was pointing out some of the areas where the reverse has applied and particularly to the area of appropriate assistance for people suffering from skin cancer and some of the associated precursors of cancers, treatments for which have recently been struck off the Medicare benefits schedule. I think this is a very tragic move that we will regret as time goes by. It is only evidence of a government which is now deeply concerned about the cost of its universal health scheme and which is discovering the problems associated with that, particularly in the delivery of pharmaceutical benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is also finding other problems in its delivery system, such as the number of people who are unable to get into public hospitals and the rapidly escalating cost of private hospital cover as a consequence of the shift to public hospitals and the drop in bed occupancy rates in private hospitals. All this will require considerable consideration in the future. I can assure the Australian people that the Opposition parties will not leave the system in its present state.

The Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) makes three basic moves. Firstly, it addresses a problem that has arisen for people who were originally categorised as class A widows. These were people who received a widows' pension when in fact a number of them were not exactly widows as we would understand it-people who have had a spouse die-but were the subject of a marriage breakdown and things of that nature. The Government decided to move these people on to unemployment benefit instead of a widows' pension. In that process it discovered that free pharmaceutical benefits were no longer available under that arrangement. In fact, they were available only at the concessional rate. This legislation seeks to correct that for the time being-and I stress `for the time being'. The legislation extends the privilege of free pharmaceutical benefits only to persons who qualify or who did qualify as widows, but who are now on unemployment benefits and women with full time dependent students in the 16 to 24 years age group. The problem is that apparently on 31 December 1988 this arrangement will be considered complete, and these people on widows' pensions from then on will be expected to carry on as strictly unemployed people. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) may have some remarks to make on that, but that is the best interpretation I can make from the documents such as the second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum. I hope that in that time these people will be able to adjust. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) raised some questions about their ability to cope under these new circumstances.

The second point deals with the search arrangements. The Government has now quite wisely decided that there are better ways of treating 16- and 17-year-olds than keeping them on unemployment benefit. Part of those arrangements is to grant a job search allowance, which can range from $25 to $50, depending on a parental means test. This legislation also extends concessional and free pharmaceutical benefits to people in that category, the difference being, as I understand it, that if a person who is otherwise eligible for the job search allowance becomes sick, instead of being placed on a sickness benefit he will remain on the job search benefit but will have the pharmaceutical benefits extended to him as a free concession compared to the $2.50 concessional rate.

Steps are also taken to adjust the entitlements of people who are considered to be disadvantaged in our community-frequently working people who have an income which is insufficient to sustain them, particularly if they have a family. The Opposition welcomes the family allowance supplement, but reminds the House that the original family income supplement scheme was a child of a previous Fraser government, which also identified the fact that working people in particular could be in severe financial difficulties, and in fact could be better off on unemployment relief. That would be a tragedy in our society and steps have been taken to avoid that. We welcome the Government's move to add concessions there, and naturally we are pleased to see that pharmaceutical benefit concessions will also be made available to these people on the same formula arrangements as would otherwise apply, namely, that their income must be less than that calculated on a formula using the unemployment cut-out rate, which is $237 for a family, plus $20, plus $34 for each child. The rate for single persons is 60 per cent of that figure.

We must remember that many of the problems now confronting Australia regarding the poverty of young children are very much a consequence of other efforts that we have made to try to assist the community. They have not all been successful. Unfortunately, I blame a lot of the poverty of young children today on our attempts to help single parents and others. Probably in a number of cases the assistance of government has contributed to people deciding to break up their homes and the great losers have been children. It does not matter what our feelings are about the rights of people to walk away from a marriage. It is a tragedy for young children and I am deeply concerned about every aspect of that matter. I just hope that we will all agree in the end that we cannot fix the problem with money. We certainly cannot leave young people in poverty. It seems an ever- increasing problem.

I remind the House that the first year when the supporting parent's benefit was introduced it cost some $40.6m in 1975 dollars and today it is costing some $1,300m plus. On information provided to me that figure is only half of what the amount really is because the figure would be nearly double if we added in widow's pensions. It is a huge amount of money. It is not only the cost but also evidence of the tragedy in our society. Since Australia decided to be more generous in that area children, the product of that arrangement, are the ones in real poverty. Previously this matter was a family responsibility and the family seemed to be able to contain the problem somewhat and the beneficiaries were the children. That concludes my remarks on this legislation.

I refer to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2), which is being debated cognately. In particular I give very strong support to the amendment of the honourable member for Bradfield in which he raises the question of whether we should continue with our discriminatory treatment of pensioners and others and continue to allow the Department a discretion. Under the hardship provisions of the legislation-honourable members should remember that this is an omnibus-type arrangement-2.5 per cent income will be deemed to have been earned from all property irrespective of the circumstances. That will be a tragedy for many people, particularly people in rural areas. This tragedy is certainly not confined to people in rural areas. The previous arrangements, whereby the Department and the Minister could exercise discretion, were much more satisfactory.

We have to be reminded that in this legislation the assets test for pensions is now extended to the unemployed. Fundamentally, I do not object to that particularly in the circumstances. If I have any bias in life it will be towards the elderly. The Government was first going to deem that an income of 10 per cent had been earned from assets. Of course, that was ridiculous and it demonstrated the Government's complete lack of knowledge of the sorts of returns one might get from even a developed and highly producing property. The 2.5 per cent is probably a more realistic figure but there are many circumstances in which it is irrelevant. The only way one can prove that point is to go before the Department or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and prove one's case. One cannot have a formula that is as solid and as inflexible as this new arrangement. Consequently, the Opposition has criticised it in its amendment.

In my electorate as many as three mature generations and some young children are dependent on one farming property. Unfortunately, many of those farming properties are not very large any more. Before they were sub-divided many years ago they were large enough but as they have been handed down from father to son or to other members of the family they are no longer sufficient to maintain, for instance, three families. The most elderly have to go on the pension. Unfortunately, it has also been found that in nearly every one of such cases the title deeds of the property are in the name of the most elderly. There is a good reason for that. They would quite willingly pass the property free of charge to younger members of their family who are now gaining a living on it. If they were not gaining a living from it they would very likely be receiving the unemployment benefit or some other benefit. This is not done because State governments demands for revenue have increased. Transfer fees and stamp duty on property are such that most people cannot afford to pay them out of their ordinary revenue. Of course, such fees are not so expensive when the owner dies. Property can be transferred much more cheaply. Consequently, farming families are forced to wait until that unfortunate event occurs.

Many properties cannot support people, particularly in recent times with the rural downturn. These people have been enjoying a pension just the same as many other people in our society who have made a contribution during their working life. However, they are now being told that they are deemed to be earning 2 1/2 per cent of the valuation of their property. That represents another problem because on many occasions the valuations in no way reflect the valuations the Department uses or the types of cash sale values that could be got for those assets.

By this means the Government will not be putting an elderly couple into a position in which they will have to sell a property. Under this change to the legislation, a change to the rules, there will be wholesale reviews of the situation. By doing this we will encounter many problems because not just one elderly family will be affected. I can give examples where up to three families will be affected by the one circumstance. All of these matters were taken into account previously and it is our argument that this should continue. We beg the Government to reconsider this issue. We know that it has lost a few cases in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and I presume that it has lost them on their merits. Many of us have been involved with constituent matters in this area and we and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal know the just and unjust claims. They become pretty obvious. We are only standing up for fairness in our community and this Government frequently makes claims to be doing that.

The situation gets even more ridiculous. Recently I wrote to the Minister-I hope he will use the discretion which I think he still has-on behalf of another of my constituents. For the reasons I have just given, a father and son had an agreement to transfer a property in 1977 but because of the huge burden of stamp duty they merely stamped the agreement-and I add that that cost them $2,465. They stamped the agreement in 1977 when there was not a whisper of assets testing. There could be no suggestion that in some way they conspired to defeat the assets test. Because they never got to a point at which they were able to transfer that property until the advent of the assets test, the bureaucracy is arguing that the elderly person involved is not only no longer entitled to a pension but also has been getting a pension dishonestly. That is a ridiculous situation. There was no doubt about the intent of the transfer in 1977 or of the eventual disposal of the loan in 1984. All action was taken well before the assets test was introduced and yet there is that sort of difficulty.

This situation will be compounded because of the total inflexibility in this area. It is a tragedy and I really hope that the Government will reconsider this point. When the 2 1/2 per cent figure was used as a guideline this measure was quite adequate. That was the rule of thumb that was applied and it could be checked. But where people had a reasonable case they had the opportunity to appeal and to get fair treatment through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and other tribunals and that was an excellent arrangement. It allowed people a second chance to get fair treatment and it allowed people to stay on farming properties. The situation is quite ridiculous. People living on 150 acres in a part of my electorate were obliged to move out of a family home that they had occupied for 70 years. They had to buy a house in a town, put money in the bank and then they got their pension back. That exercise did not prove very much but it is a classic example of how, when one makes rules that are too inflexible, the Government is unable to take notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confine most of my comments to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2). Firstly, I wish to devote a few minutes to the implications of this legislation for Australia's veteran community. Shortly after the election I was contacted at my local electorate office at Wyong by several members of The Entrance Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Association who were very concerned about the implications of a recent judgment of the Federal Court of Australia on the rights of the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) veterans to continue to receive that compensation after they had reached the age of 65. In addition I was contacted by the Hunter Valley and Central Coast sub-branch of the Vietnam Veterans Association, which, of course, does not have members over the age of 65, but which nevertheless has a significant interest in this Federal Court judgment. In the first sitting week of this Parliament I addressed a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who, in his answer, publicly advised the House that this Government would introduce legislation to overturn the Federal Court judgment which had placed TPI pensions for those over the age of 65 at risk. The Minister has already developed an excellent reputation for consulting the veteran community. He had detailed discussions with the national TPI Association and as a result of that he was able to convince Cabinet that it should introduce legislation to overturn that Federal Court judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) has made some comments in the debate today, expressing some concern about the interpretation of parts of this legislation. In fact, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has today received a letter from Mr Ian Gollings, the National Secretary of the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL), expressing a concern about the amendments contained in the Bill. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has asked me to make a few comments in reply on his behalf. The concern is caused by the new paragraph 24a (c), which it is thought will introduce a new concept not previously contained in the Veterans' Entitlements Act-that is, the words `is capable of undertaking remunerative work'. However, those words do appear in the existing legislation in section 24 (1) (b). Mr Gollings expressed the RSL's concern that there is no guidance in the legislation as to what constitutes `remunerative work'. Section 28 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act specifically deals with the criteria to be used in assessing capacity to undertake remunerative work. There is clear guidance in that section. In addition, clause 67 of this Bill makes a minor amendment to section 28 to ensure that the criteria specified in that section also apply to the new section 24a about which the RSL is concerned.

On page 84 of the explanatory memorandum is an explanation of this amendment to section 28. On behalf of the Minister, I assure the RSL and the Parliament that the Government is not introducing a new surreptitious measure to reassess all these pensioners. The sole intention of the amendments is to overcome the undesirable outcome of the Federal Court decision in the McGuire case, which was that a TPI pension may not be payable for the life of the veteran. The amendments restore the situation to what it was before that decision.

Finally, the RSL is concerned that the amendments do not include all applications for intermediate and TPI pensions in the determining system pipeline at the moment. This is not the case. The Minister has advised me that the purpose of backdating these amendments to the commencement of the Veterans' Entitlements Act-that is, 22 May 1986-is to ensure that all such applications are covered. Any cases that are still in the determining system and that were lodged with the Department before the commencement of the Veterans' Entitlements Act are, in effect, brought under the Act by section 17 of the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986. The honourable member for Farrer has requested an assurance from the Minister that the distinction between the existing section 24 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, which is expressed in the positive sense, and the new section 24a, which is expressed in the negative sense, will not change the way in which these provisions are applied. Section 24 is a test as to whether certain criteria apply to a veteran. The new section 24a is a test whether the criteria do not apply. On behalf of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I assure the honourable member that this will not change the way in which these provisions apply.

Returning to my own personal comments, I wish to commend the Government for introducing this legislation, which clarifies the position of these TPI veterans. In all normal circumstances, TPI veterans will not lose the payment of their TPI pension for their lifetime. The only exceptions, which have been stated quite clearly, are if a veteran obtains a TPI pension by making a false or misleading statement or if a veteran returns to the work force. I think those two exceptions are quite understandable and valid.

I wish to raise two other matters affecting the veteran community. The first affects the Concord Repatriation General Hospital, which provides assistance to a large number of veterans in New South Wales. Recently, because of a gap between the wage rate which was payable to nurses who are employed in New South Wales State Government hospitals and that payable to nurses employed at the Concord Repatriation General Hospital under a Federal award, the Concord hospital lost a large number of nurses to the New South Wales hospital system. Of course, that was largely due to that gap in the wage rate between the Federal and State awards. Much to my regret, as a result of that, the management of Concord hospital had to take action to close a number of wards. A large number of Vietnam veterans in my own electorate have expressed concern that one of the wards which was closed was one which had developed a great deal of special expertise in assisting Vietnam veterans who were suffering various traumas as a result of their service in Vietnam. While perhaps anyone could understand that hospitals sometimes have to take a hard decision and close wards when they have lost nursing staff, it has been many months now since the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission took action to get rid of that gap which was causing the loss of nurses from the Concord repatriation system. I think it is time that the Minister considered whether the Concord repatriation system is building up the numbers of nurses to ensure that wards, such as the ward which was looking after Vietnam veterans, are reopened as soon as possible.

I turn now to the implications of this legislation for the Department of Social Security. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) at the table because I wish to make a few comments about some statements which he made in this debate. To a large extent this legislation deals with the family assistance package in which this Government can take great pride. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Farrer enter the chamber but I have to apologise to him as I have already finished my comments on the amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I hope he will read them with interest in Hansard.

Returning to the comments made by the honourable member for Bradfield, I take it that he had recently visited a St Vincent de Paul Society crisis centre for families and believed that that entitled him to become an instant expert on poverty in Australia and in Sydney in particular. Perhaps the depth of his knowledge was demonstrated by his comment that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had launched the family assistance package at Campbelltown. I have bad news for the honourable member for Bradfield: the Prime Minister's package was not launched at Campbelltown; it was in fact launched at Mount Druitt. I can understand that since he represents an electorate on Sydney's North Shore--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not invited. I watched it on television.

—The honourable member said he was not invited and that he watched it on the television. But if he had watched television he would have heard that the launch was at Mount Druitt, not at Campbelltown. Since he represents a North Shore electorate in the northern suburbs of Sydney, I can perhaps understand that he does not get much of an opportunity to visit the western suburbs of Sydney. In fact, Mount Druitt is 30 kilometres north of Campbelltown. Since the Liberal Party of Australia is always claiming that it hopes to make inroads into the Australian Labor Party's base in the western suburbs, I would be happy, if he is interested, to provide him with a map of Sydney-the western suburbs of Sydney in particular-so that he can see that Mount Druitt is a very different place from Campbelltown.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the honourable member's comments that poverty has increased under the Hawke Government, I think he knows that these claims are totally ridiculous. We have had 700,000 new jobs created. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has colourfully remarked in Question Time previously that those people are not Martians; they are real people. Seven hundred thousand Australians who were not in employment when this Government was elected are now in employment. We also have to look at the level of pensions as a percentage of average weekly earnings to see what contribution this Government has made to alleviate proverty. When the Opposition left government in 1983 pensions were only 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings. That was an absolute disgrace. From December, when the single base rate of pension will be $116.10 a week, pensions will be almost 24.8 per cent as a percentage of average weekly earnings.

The great benefit that those near the poverty line will receive is the family package which this Government, under Prime Minister Bob Hawke, promised during the election campaign. I am proud of the fact that this Government has met that commitment with honour. It is important to compare what this Government is delivering with what the Opposition promised in the election campaign. The Opposition promised to cut government expenditure by 3c in the dollar every year, which somehow or other added up to 10c in the dollar. Opposition members would not tell people exactly where they were intending to cut back government expenditure, but we all know that would have been in areas such as veterans' affairs, social security, health and education. The Opposition would have used cuts in areas that would have hurt the less well-off in order to abolish the assets test so that millionaires could get a pension again. The Opposition wanted to cut back welfare, education and health in order to reintroduce deductions for the business community for its long lunches. It wanted to cut back pensions so that businesses could claim as a tax deduction the provision of BMWs and turbocharged Saab motor vehicles for their business executives.

That is the choice in this chamber. The choice is between the Labor Party that is delivering the family package to very poor constituents and the Liberal and National parties, which were to cut back pensions to those on social security and to veterans in order to deliver tax cuts to the rich and to re-introduce all the rorts which this Government has fought so hard to abolish. The family package is worth $500m, which will be targeted to those who are in real need. That is unlike the Opposition's proposal which would abolish the assets test to provide money to those who are in least need.

This family package can be divided into two elements. First, it will give cash to working families and, secondly, it will provide increases for pensioners with children. Working families will continue to receive family allowances; they will be unchanged. In addition, they will receive a tax free family allowance supplement, which will replace the family income supplement (FIS). I acknowledge the comment made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) that that program was brought in by the Fraser Government. I do not criticise that program because it delivered cash to low income families. The problem was the very poor take-up rate of FIS. Few people who were entitled to FIS approached the Department of Social Security and applied for it.

Under the family income supplement those people received $17 a week. Under this Government's legislation, by the family allowance supplement they will receive $22 a week per child for children under 13 years of age, and $28 per week per child for teenagers between 13 and 15 years of age. In addition, there will be for the first time $15 a week for those who are renting privately. Not only are the payments per child significantly higher, particularly for teenagers, but of special importance is the fact that the incomes test has been relaxed. Let me quote two examples. A family with a gross income of $400, and with two teenagers, who are renting privately will receive $27 a week tax free, which is equivalent to a pay increase of $45 a week. The second example involves an equivalent family earning only $350 a week. That family through the family allowance supplement will receive $52 a week, which is equivalent to a pay rise of $86 a week. That is something working class families greatly need and appreciate. I hope that the take-up rate of the new family allowance supplement is much higher than was the case with the FIS. I am sure that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) will ensure that this program is publicised so that every possible eligible person qualifies. I have great pleasure in supporting the legislation which takes a great step forward in seeking to allow every child the right not to live in poverty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the remarks of the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) on the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2), one would think that unemployment had disappeared, but I remind him that the unemployment rate now exceeds 8 per cent. There are more than 650,000 Australians out of work. The claim by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) earlier that the Australian Labor Party in government had created poverty was justified. The Labor Party in government has not-I repeat `has not'-rectified the economy to the extent that, if one were to listen to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) each day, one would be led to believe. I am sorry that the honourable member for Dobell is leaving the chamber, having just delivered his address. That leaves opposite at present the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding) on his own. It indicates the level of interest in this legislation in the Labor Party, unless Labor members are having another meeting in the Labor Party Caucus to decide whether privatisation is a goer.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of matters require attention. I refer first to the speech made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who said:

The family package is the centrepiece of this Government's attack on child poverty, not only for families where parents depend on social security because they are sick or unemployed, but for working families who have carried the burden of economic adjustment over the past few years.

That speech is a frank admission that since Labor has been in power it has ignored the plight of the working family. I suggest to the Minister that it was only as a result of the policy approach by the Liberal and National parties at the last election to do something about those people in the work force whose income was not that high that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) suddenly dreamed up this idea to promise to eliminate all child poverty by 1990. It was a promise that was driven out of the Labor Party by the approach of the Liberal-National party coalition.

As I said at the beginning, Labor has been a creator of poverty. Therefore, one cannot be in any way critical of the measures which are being taken to try to correct that situation. Nevertheless, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) in the last day or so has applauded the Government on its approach in redirecting income. I believe philosophically and most strongly that there is a limit to what government should be doing in terms of how much it takes out of some people's pockets and puts into the pockets of others. I believe in support for the poor, but I also believe that the Labor Party's approach can accidentally-if I may be extremely generous, inadvertently-lower the level to which people aspire because they know that the Government will look after them. We are reaching a position in Australia where many so called middle income families are carrying a greater and greater burden to a point where their aspirations are diminishing because they think, `Why should I try?'. The Government took the family allowance away from people whose children had reached 16 years of age. Prior to that there was an almost sacred approach to the allowance for 18- to 25-year-olds paid to people whose children were going on to higher education. But when the Labor Government came to office it knocked that group off. It has a history of pulling back here and there. It has defined wealth as anything over about $22,000 or $23,000 a year. It is the creator of poverty in this country.

A number of Bills are being debated today. The Minister claimed in his speech that the family package was based on the basic principle that every Australian child had the right to an adequate standard of living. Nobody can argue with that. It is also based on the solid Labor tradition of help for people in need of support. That is not a Labor tradition alone. It is our philosophy as well. The Minister then went on to say that it was the Lang Labor Government which introduced the world's first child endowment scheme to recognise the extra costs of families with children. Piffle! It is about time the Government learnt and spoke the truth. The reality is that Australia's first child endowment scheme was introduced by the Commonwealth Government in 1920. In 1920 Billy Hughes, in the non-Labor Nationalist Government, introduced a scheme for Commonwealth public servants, with the costs being borne by the Government via a direct addition to wages. It was not until seven years later that the Lang Labor Government introduced the New South Wales State scheme. Honourable members opposite have the view that if they repeat a lie often enough people will believe them. They are taking credit for something that is not true.

From 1923 until 1941 the cost of the Federal scheme was met by the officials themselves from a fund provided by all-round flat rate deductions. Child endowment was often in the news before 1927. An attempt was made to introduce it as early as 1919 in New South Wales by the Holman Nationalist Government. The Bill was passed by the Legislative Assembly but was rejected by the Legislative Council. The same thing happened to the Storey Labor Government in 1921.

In 1941 the Menzies Government-a non-Labor government-introduced the Child Endowment Act. A payment was made directly to the mother at a flat weekly rate for each child after the first child under the age of 16. The endowment was financed through payroll tax. The Curtin Labor Government, to its credit, built on the achievements of the Menzies Government by extending payment to children who were institutionalised, to Aboriginal children who spent six months a year on a mission and to orphans. In 1950, after Labor had had nine years in power, the Menzies Government took the step of providing child endowment to the first child under 16 years and continued with payments for second and subsequent children. So honourable members opposite should not try to parade themselves in this place as the only party that cares about families. When it comes to traditional family values, the coalition parties have a greater claim to caring and to policies directed to the support of families than the Australian Labor Party.

The Bills before the Parliament affect everything from social security and veterans affairs to health. I am glad that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has come into the chamber. As the Minister well knows, the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital is in the Federal electorate of Moreton. To the shame of the Minister and his predecessor, the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital appears to have been in utter shambles for the last six or seven months. It can be said that it all started with the specialists' strike. Things reached a point where specialists in the veterans' own hospital in Queensland-and they have only one hospital in Queensland-withdrew their services. This is a shameful reflection on the Hawke socialist Government. Since 1 May there have been no visiting specialists at the hospital. All services have been withdrawn as the result of an industrial dispute over a number of things, including the level of salaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. Whilst I do not want to disturb the honourable member for too long, he should relate to the legislation. I do not know how the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital or any other hospital is concerned with the legislation before the House. I am happy for the honourable member to carry on as long as he does not carry on for too much longer. I know that you will correct him, Mr Deputy Speaker, if he keeps going.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will keep to the contents of the legislation, and not excite the House so much!

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the principal Bill is entitled the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. Veterans, particularly older veterans, have an entitlement in their latter years to feel secure that if they take sick and are whipped off to a hospital at least there will be a hospital bed for them. For the last six months the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital has been functioning at 75 per cent of its capacity, not because the staff have been going slow but because over 100 beds have been empty because the hospital did not have the ability to run with a bed utilisation rate of 100 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the Minister's sensitivity about this situation. No wonder he tries to shut me up on this subject. Every day lately there have been stories in the newspapers about the matter. On 12 November this year an article appeared in the Courier-Mail headed `Doctors to cut back on operations'. Another article, which appeared in the Sun on 26 October, was headed `Ex-serviceman alleges bias to Viet vets'. Another article in the Courier-Mail was headed `Hospital turned away veteran in pain-doctor'. A litany of such articles has been going on for weeks. I do not necessarily accept that all these articles are accurate in content.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has nothing to do with the legislation.
—Order! I ask the Minister to stop interjecting.
—I will be finished on this matter very shortly and the Minister can relax.

—The Minister will realise that we are debating Bills cognately on this occasion. The Chair is cognisant of the fact that the three Bills are related. The subject matter of this speech is within the bounds of the debate in general terms. But I ask the honourable member to be more relevant.

—If the Minister gives me a go I will get on to another subject shortly. I was saying that I do not necessarily accept the veracity of all these newspaper reports. Nevertheless, the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital is in so much turmoil that the Press is in such a mood that it writes almost anything. That tells its own story. I plead with the Minister. There are one or two other aspects I will not touch on which have also been most unsatisfactory. The Minister knows what they are. If the Minister wants to make his name as a Minister, I suggest that he make it by getting Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital functioning properly again and taking a personal interest in the hospital. The administration is probably being bled of funds but is being expected to make ends meet and to make everything function on what is almost a shoestring budget. I will leave my references to the Greenslopes hospital at that. At long last I have been able to say these things in the presence of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. When one sits on this side of the House these days it is impossible to ask a question. In the last five minutes I have made up for a few questions that I have not been able to ask.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point of concern about the legislation before the Parliament is the approach the Government is adopting in applying the assets test in relation to a host of benefits. We have heard references to this subject from other members on this side of the chamber, particularly shadow Ministers. The Government is saying that anybody who is over 25 years of age will be subject to the assets test in terms of unemployment benefits and the like. There are also hardship provisions for people who are excluded by virtue of assets, and those hardship provisions will be applied. Unfortunately, time does not allow me to go into what exactly are regarded as hardship provisions, but I have here some 23 pages which represent an extract from the pensions manual of instructions of the Department of Social Security. All these 23 pages do is concentrate on the applications of the hardship provisions. They are extremely complicated, and I guess they seek to take into account any possible situation.

What I am raising with the Government today is its widening of the application of the principle of the assets test. This side of the House has been consistent in its opposition to the assets test, but in this legislation we are seeing a widening of those provisions. I put it to the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs, who is at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs sitting behind him and, indeed, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), sitting at the back of the chamber, that none of them are very young any more, even though the honourable member for Forde would be a good 20 years younger than the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

Let us say that the people who will be affected are single and own their own home. If their assets exceed $75,000 and they go out of work, those assets will be looked at in terms of their eligibility for a future benefit. That is what honourable members opposite will be voting for today. Not for one moment do I subscribe to those who are rolling in money receiving benefits. But let us take the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is about 50 years of age. I can tell him that, if he loses his job next time around, he will be 52 weeks out of work on average. He has a few assets. He will be off to the dole queue to apply for a benefit. He will be asked what his assets are. He will list his assets and he will be told, `Sorry'. He will say, `I might be asset rich, but I do not have any other money'. Of course, he will have another little form of income which excites people but which I will not mention here.
