The Department will want to know the Minister's assets and he will be faced with either getting nothing or perhaps taking steps to borrow on his assets. Let us say that he is 55 and worried about whether he will ever get a job again-which is quite possible. He will have to borrow on those assets. If nobody will lend him any money, he will have to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure to speak in support of the Social Security and Veteran's Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. The family package is the major initiative in this Bill. This Bill sets out to provide for the introduction of that family package, which is the centrepiece of this Government's attack on child poverty. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) has claimed that it is only the Opposition which is interested in families. Good heavens! The honourable member should know that we as a government are committed to families. It is not only the families which are dependent on social security because someone is sick or unemployed that are addressed in this Bill; rather, it is working families who for too long have carried the burden of economic adjustment over the past two years. This Government recognises that those people and their children and families are the very focus of our community. Those children are our future and it is imperative, if we are to pursue the principle of equity, that we provide for these families and their children. This Bill sets out to do just that.

SPEECH.PARA: The family package sets out to enable families with children to receive allowances and rent assistance, and this will commence from 17 December 1987. Everyone knows that families in our community have felt the pressure of Australia's economic readjustment. Well may the honourable member for Moreton speak of the Menzies years. We are bearing the brunt of those years now and we have to make these kinds of economic readjustments simply because of the years we spent under the Menzies regime. Workers have been playing their part in exercising wage restraint. We support the principle that every member of our community has a right to live with dignity, so it is the children in our community who come first in this commitment under the family package.

This package, then, is based on the solid Labor tradition of help for people in need and those deserving of our support. While the honourable member for Moreton claimed to have dispelled all the myths of the Labor tradition of child endowment, pensions and so on, he failed to point out that, of course, the initial introduction of these measures was well in line with the Opposition policy of the user pays principles. Labor tradition has in fact meant that child endowment was universal-not simply for those who happened to be in highly paid jobs and who could afford to pay the prerequisite amount.

Indeed, what we are now seeing under this family package is cash money-C-A-S-H. It is cash in the hand, as the brochure says. It will then be for the families themselves to make a decision about where it will be spent and the kinds of needs which they as particular families have. It means that people will not have the indignity of the vouchers which the Opposition so often espouses and attempts to pursue. Indeed, members of the Opposition are very interested in all those sorts of things. They fail to recognise that within the family structure human beings have dignity and know very definitely the way in which they can and will spend their money. We as a government are committed to the maintenance of that dignity, and this package will put cash into people's hands.

The family allowance supplement replaces the family income supplement. It will pay $22 a week for each child. However, if children are 13, 14 or 15 years old, the payment will be $28 a week. One may well ask why. This is a recognition of the cost of education, of clothing and of feeding children who are in their teenage years. This is often when a family's budget is most stretched. We as a government are flexible enough to acknowledge that. Families on a gross wage of $300 a week or less will get full payment if they have one child. The reality is that the bigger the family the more money it can earn and still receive some payment. Because it is tax free, the family allowance supplement is better than a pay rise. We are acknowledging that families are central to our community. These children are our future. It is their education that we are looking at and also the strain which financial overstress often places on such families.

Despite the protestations of the honourable member for Moreton, we as a government are committed to the maintenance of the family and the children within the family structure. The family assistance package sets out to do that. Because the family allowance supplement is tax free, it is the equivalent of a pay rise in the vicinity of $45 a week. The work force would simply not be able to sustain such a pay rise. One may well ask where these benefits are coming from. Indeed, it is very important to acknowledge that most of the money for these benefits has come from the tax and welfare cheats. This distribution of income represents equity on a very real scale. Those people who for too long have ripped off our system and who have not participated and contributed to the full community have now been caught. We as a government are not shirking our responsibility to dispose of that income to those people who are most in need. This is without doubt the most exciting legislation which has been introduced into this Parliament for a long time in the pursuit of social justice and the removal of children from poverty. A part of this package is the introduction of a new child disability allowance which will replace the old handicapped child's allowance. Many of us who know families with handicapped children understand the very real needs and the financial strains that are placed on families with such children. There are often extra medical expenses and there are bills and requirements which other children do not have. There are often babysitting costs to be met, and so on. We have acknowledged those costs.

Our commitment is to all the children in our society. We acknowledge the role that the family plays in the support of a handicapped child. If it is at all possible, it is important that handicapped children remain within their family structure. Hence, we have increased the payment for handicapped children and done away with the means test altogether. Irrespective of how much money people have, we are saying that all children have needs and we acknowledge that. Indeed, 10,000 additional disabled children are expected to qualify for the payment as a result of the removal of the income test and, we hope, due to the improved take-up resulting from publicity associated with the family package. We know that there are very many people within our community who are entitled currently to payments within our social security system who have not yet taken them up. We are hopeful that these people will now be made fully cognisant of their rights and so be able to participate fully within this scheme.

Measures contained within this Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) also reinforce our Government's commitment to the many pensioners and aged citizens in our community. After all, they are the people who have served our community. It is important that we acknowledge them and do not allow them to fall into poverty traps. The responsiveness and flexibility of this new system, with the introduction of the earnings credit scheme, means that many pensioners will now be able to take up part time jobs. It will offer them an incentive to go out and supplement their income. This earnings credit scheme, which came into effect on 1 November 1987, means that pensioners with a limited private income can take up short term jobs. For example, with Christmas coming up, we know that there are many people who will wish to become Father Christmases. People who have been unable to do so earlier because of the earnings requirements associated with their pension will now be able to earn up to $1,000 each from a casual job in the course of six months and still be able to have their pension. This is very important. It enables people to have the stimulus of working, to have the joy and the pleasure of going out and feeling that they are still able to make a very real and and worthwhile contribution to our community. The flexibility of this system is one of its most exciting aspects.

Also in this legislation eligibility for the carer's pension has not been restricted to close relatives. This will apply from 1 February 1988. My colleague the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) has already suggested that many of the people who are caring for victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome within our community fall into this category. We as a government have worked towards a policy which hopes to keep people in their homes for as long as possible, should they so wish. The carer's pension is simply part of this approach and it will enable people to be best served and will meet their needs at home rather than their going to an institution. We have a humane approach to pensioners and we acknowledge that they must and should have a choice over their lives.

The legislation also provides for the transition from a benefit to Austudy, if this is necessary. This transition will commence on 1 January 1988. This is a very important consideration because for many of our pensioners the long term solution to their poverty and to their poverty traps is the pursuance of study. We as a community need the kinds of skills that study and training can bring about. We urge and encourage people to pursue such skills. Hence, the transition from benefits to Austudy is being made easier. We as a government have become much more flexible. We are attempting to meet the very real needs of a very wide range of people within our community. We do not stereotype people. We do not want a system of one for all. We are talking about all sorts of individuals within our community.

Another important aspect of this Bill relates to youth. I am the first to acknowledge, as I have the largest Commonwealth Employment Service office in Queensland, that there are far too many unemployed youth in our community. It is not only they who are the losers; we as a community lose very much by failing to use their skills to the fullest advantage. Hence, from 1 January 1988, 16- and 17-year-olds will qualify for $50 a week for the job search allowance. This is subject to an activities test which means that they could be required to attend courses. Of that $50, $25 will be affected by parental income. This is an attempt to acknowledge that the youth within our community must be skilled if they are to participate fully in our work force. The kinds of skills that are required now within the work force are those of a high order. We cannot afford to have our youth leaving school and moving on to the unemployment benefit without acknowledging that there is a very real need for skills and skills training. We are committed to their being part of our work force and this job search allowance attempts to do that.

Another part of this Bill relates to veterans within our community. Our Government, and particularly our Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), has a very high commitment to veterans in our society. We acknowledge their contribution and the very real debt which we owe to them. They have helped to create the kind of society in which we now live. This entitlements legislation will mean the postponement of the cancellation of fringe benefits. Very many of our service pensioners choose to work part time and they have at times been subjected to the loss of certain fringe benefits-pharmaceutical benefits, telephone rental and other such benefits often provided to pensioners by State and local government. Previously, when a service pensioner who received fringe benefits notified the Department of Veterans' Affairs of an increase in income over the allowed limit, the Department would notify the pensioner of the immediate loss of fringe benefits if the income was more than 25 per cent over the limit. This change means that a pensioner's income will be able to rise up to 25 per cent above the fringe benefit income level with a period of three months grace before the fringe benefit will be withdrawn. This will take effect from 1 January 1988. There are some 2,000 service pensioners whose income fluctuates. This is due to short periods of casual earning, indexation of superannuation and, of course, overseas investments which some of our service pensioners have.

This decision relates to the fringe benefit eligibility only and the service pension will not be affected. The fringe benefit eligibility will still be granted automatically and the three-month period of grace is being extended to avoid the inconvenience that is experienced by pensioners who lose their fringe benefits for short periods because of short term fluctuations. Once again, I would suggest that we are showing an incredible amount of flexibility. It makes sense to be flexible and it helps people.

Another aspect of the amendment to the Veterans' Entitlements Act will mean an extension of full treatment benefits to all Australian returned service women of World War II. This was part of an election promise. I, as a woman, am delighted that these women will now be provided with repatriation, medical and hospital treatment for all the injuries they suffered, in addition to treatment currently being provided. The Government has taken this step following a study of returned Australian service women undertaken by the Repatriation Commission. It is estimated that there will be over 3,000 surviving returned service women of whom close to 1,000 will not have had an entitlement to full medical treatment under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Those service women have experienced very difficult conditions. They have endured physical hardship and have faced the hazards of diseases, poor diet and climatic excesses. It is an acknowledgment by a government that is committed to equality that these service women are now being accommodated.

The family assistance package will also, of course, cover those people who are currently covered by service and veterans pensions. What will happen is that means testing of parental income for educational allowances will not be introduced. All children whose fathers died as a result of service to their country or who were severely incapacitated through service will continue to receive guidance and financial support through the Veterans' Affairs Department. That is a further acknowledgment of the commitment which our service people have made to our community and it is their children who will continue to be part of our society. It is through education and training that this can be done.

I have great delight in speaking to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. It puts in place not only the promises made during the election but also the promises which are inherent in the Australian Labor Party's platform and to which this Government has been committed. It is a very real commitment to equity. It is a commitment to the children in our community. It is a very important step along the path to removing every child from poverty by 1990. The family assistance package and, with it, the entitlements which go to pensioners and veterans in our community reinforce our view of creating a fairer and more just society. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 cognately with the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The first Bill, to which I shall speak particularly, gives effect to a number of announcements made by the Government, including the provisions described as the family assistance package. In those amendments to the Social Security Act, the main proposals are the introduction of a family allowance supplement, certain increases in additional pension and benefit for children in line with the family allowance supplement rates, rent assistance for low income earners with dependent children under 16 years and the introduction of a child disability allowance. Those measures have bipartisan support and are in no way opposed.

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of unemployment and sickness benefits, the Bill introduces an assets test for beneficiaries over 25 years of age. Although I want to concentrate my remarks on other parts of this legislation, nevertheless, I would register some concern at the application of the assets test to recipients of sickness benefit. On a number of occasions I have condemned the application of the wretched assets test and have always said that an income test is far more equitable and sustainable than an assets test. I repeat that assertion. Sadly, I have seen many service pensioners caught up and losing all or much of their pension because of this test. They have assets which cannot be liquidated, yet there is no income. The hardship test, more often than not, does not help. However, the philosophical debate on the assets test is perhaps not the real thrust of this legislation. Certainly, its application to sickness benefit recipients, as in the past to service pensioners, could raise considerable anomalies and difficulties. I hope that at least the Government will keep this under some sort of scrutiny and monitoring.

Other aspects of the legislation include the introduction of a pensioner's earnings credit, some benefits with regard to the fringe benefits car retention, and changes to treatment of certain investment income. They are quite unexceptionable and quite bipartisan support is afforded to them. The only substantial comment I want to make about the social security portion of the legislation relates to the job search allowance and the general youth unemployment issue. Once again, it is not by any means a condemnation. This aspect applies to young people in the 16- and 17-year-old bracket. The assets test mentioned earlier does not apply to the under 25-year-olds. I do not criticise the addressing of a very grievous problem in our nation, and other nations, which is of bipartisan concern and which transcends partisan politics-that is, the future of our young people.

We all recognise that our school leavers face a very uncertain employment future. In today's world, it is no longer possible to ensure that many of them will be able to enter the livelihood on which they have set their sights and ambitions. We all recognise the very sad effects which can result from the dashing of those aspirations and ambitions, the heartbreak of the fruitless search for employment and the damage that results from continual rejection of applications for employment. The permanent and deep damage resulting from the `not wanted' feeling is only too plainly seen in the number of drop-outs and even youth suicides. I suspect that it is also a factor in the increasing problem of the wretched drug trade. Therefore, there is bipartisan desire to alleviate these problems.

Unfortunately, in our community, as in every community, there are some, hopefully a very small minority, who cannot be helped and whose philosophy is that there is no reason for them to work or make any contribution to the nation while government and community benevolence is available to subsidise self-chosen idleness. The sad aspect of this is not so much that those people exist; it is because of this undesirable attitude in a few that all young people are often smeared by the taint of dole bludging. That is wrong, unfair and tragic. We all see in our electorate offices the repeated tragedy of young people who have trodden the streets, tried every avenue and, in desperation, come to us in the hope that we can find them a job. They want neither unemployment benefit nor charity; they just want a chance. I do not criticise anything that can be done to restore their dignity and give them some hope for the future.

Combined with these initiatives, the Government's Austudy-before that, the tertiary education assistance scheme-is designed to assist young people in enabling them to stay at school and to go on to secondary and tertiary education. I endorse that package too. I think these things have to be worked together. But I point out one omission which I hope the Government will consider seriously. I am pleased that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is in the House this evening because I think he knows that what I say, I say seriously. I see it as a sad anomaly. I do not allege that it is deliberate, but it does exist and I hope that my appeal will be at least considered. This educational help through Austudy is not available to students in theological colleges even when they are studying for a degree. They have no income. They are like other students equipping themselves for their future and for employment. They should not be treated differently from any other young person who is studying for a profession. They cannot apply for unemployment benefits because their consciences will not let them do such a thing. That seems to me to be sad and unfair. I hope the Minister at the table will at least see whether the situation can be redressed and in some way rectified.

In looking at the legislation relating to youth unemployment, job search and other initiatives, I urge the Government not to overlook another very worrying problem. I refer to men and women of early or late middle age who have been retrenched or whose businesses have folded leaving them without work. The Minister has seen them and I have seen them. These people find that they are consigned to the scrap-heap. They are regarded as too old and all doors are shut to them. The tragedy and the frequency of this situation and the hopelessness it causes is of great concern. It must be of great concern. It must be addressed specifically and with great urgency. I am not drawing attention away from the problem of youth unemployment. That too is a matter of great concern. Honourable members will be familiar with the situation of constituents in that category who come to their offices and break down, totally demoralised. This crisis of youth unemployment is of great concern.

I turn to the veterans affairs section of the legislation. I am very pleased that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has spent quite a lot of time in the House during this debate. I have a great deal of respect for him. I think he is very concerned with the lot of veterans and I commend him for that. I am pleased that the anxiety of the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) veterans emanating from the court decision which put at risk the permanency of the pensions has been removed. That caused a lot of heartbreak and many problems. I welcome the provisions which ensure that the preservation of the rights of veterans to the payment of special TPI intermediate rate pensions for life is now guaranteed. There is real concern in the veteran community and the court decision exacerbated that concern.

I have expressed concern in this House on previous occasions about changes in the philosophy of TPI pensions. I point out to the House-the Minister who is in the House will know-that this is not something new. It is not something that I started to do since being in Opposition. It is a principle I tried to establish, strengthen and enshrine when I was the Minister responsible for veterans' affairs. Over the years, the words of the Act have been more and more literally and stringently interpreted. I am distressed about that. More and more the TPI has been regarded as a pension or a substitute for earnings. I do not, and I never will, accept that view. TPI intermediate and disability pensions are not pensions; they are compensation. They are ill-named. That is why I believe the Government's view of it being almost impossible for a pensioner to apply for and receive a TPI pension is very wrong.

The philosophy which so strictly interprets the Act and maintains that a TPI is paid in lieu of the capacity to earn a wage and that alone, and that when a person reaches normal retirement age he can no longer qualify, is wrong. It completely ignores the reality that a veteran may have had to take a lesser paid job throughout his lifetime because of his disability. It ignores the fact that that decision has cost him dearly in medication to enable him to work. It ignores the fact that perhaps he cannot get the insurance cover and the superannuation that others can get. It ignores the fact that he has tried to make a contribution to our way of life rather than lean back and apply for a pension to which he would be entitled. It ignores the fact that the veteran's wife and family have made many sacrifices and have been under very great strain supporting the disabled veteran in his determination to work and not to drop out. It ignores the fact that advancing years increase the pain and the disability, sometimes causing great distress. So for all his sacrifice and endeavour the veteran is ruled out from obtaining the TPI pension after 60 years of age. His wife who has sacrificed so much and has been denied so much is also denied the possibility of some compensation by way of qualifying as a war widow if her husband dies.

I deplore the subtle change over the years which regards such compensation as a pension. I deplore the departure from the recognition that it is nothing of the sort. It is compensation earned and promised. We ought not seek to avoid that. At least in this legislation if a TPI pension has been granted it cannot be taken away except under special circumstances and there is no contest about those. In the interest of veterans who have suffered so much, who have been promised so much, I appeal for a rethink of other recent legislative changes and a return to the recognition of the TPI pension not as a handout, not as a substitute for earnings, but as compensation. It was this philosophical change which so increased veterans worries when the court decision was handed down. To them it looked like the last straw. I am very pleased that that has been remedied. The Government said it would remedy the situation and it has done so. I commend it for that decision.

The previous tightening up of TPI pensions, which disqualified people or made it impossible for people to get the pension after 60 years of age, saved the Government $70m a year. That is not much but it was achieved, I believe, at the expense of veterans who feel that they have been betrayed. It was false economy. I am not happy about the provisions in this legislation which would deem 2.5 per cent of the value of the asset owned by the veterans to be income irrespective of whether income to this value is capable of being earned at all. This just adds to the growing feeling among veterans that promises made to them are now being diluted and that they are being singled out to accept a disproportionate share of the sacrifices at a time of economic stringency.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the sacrifices they made.

—Yes, after the sacrifices they and their families made. Additionally, this will particularly and unfairly impact on country veterans who may have land that is farmed by the family but who get no monetary benefit from it at all. They battle to get a few assets together and, on top of all the other attacks on their benefits, they now suffer for that also. I am very unhappy about that provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again the Government has shown some wisdom in adopting one policy pronouncement which the Opposition advanced as policy at the last election. That is the extension of full treatment entitlements to World War II ex-service women. That is desirable and that is to be commended. It still excludes ex-service women who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. Their numbers are not great. For a minimal cost of about $65,000 a year they could also be covered by this provision. I urge the Government to remove this restriction because it seems an unfortunate and unfair discrimination in the light of the steps that it has already taken. These ex-service women should also be included.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why were they excluded?

—They may have been excluded because of the cost. I ask the Government to take another look at that because we are not talking about a very big sum of money and we are not talking about very many people. In addition, this provision does not refer to ex-servicewomen who embarked for active service but who did not actually serve in a theatre of war. There are not very many of them either. Perhaps the Government could see whether and when those ex-service women also could be brought into this concession. The Returned Services League has brought these omissions to the Government's attention, I believe, and I hope that the Minister will consider those submissions sympathetically and urgently as being made in good faith.

SPEECH.PARA: The veterans legislation needs more attention and amendment. Despite this amending Bill there are still matters which are not addressed. The defence service home loans scheme is still unresolved. The announced patient contribution in nursing homes still hangs over veterans' heads and will probably be sneaked through under the regulation making power. I am concerned about that.

In the interest of time I will not further extend my remarks, although there are very many other concerns of veterans that I would like to address. I think that is something I am known for in this House. I believe the veterans of this country deserve the best possible treatment. When they went to war all sorts of promises were made to them. Now the time has come to deliver on those promises. We must not back off from them. We must pay the bill, as we said we would.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had a good Minister when you were the Minister.

—I did my best. I conclude by confirming that, as this Bill does preserve the TPI rights which have been threatened, I will support it. However, as I have pointed out, there are a number of aspects of this Bill which do not please me, and this Parliament will probably hear more from me putting the case for our veterans, to whom this nation owes so much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixty-two years ago was an election year in New South Wales. The Leader of the Australian Labor Party Opposition at the time, Jack Lang, fought the 1925 election on three issues: the abolition of the upper House, pensions for widows and the introduction of child endowment. On the latter Lang made a promise to the families of New South Wales in his policy speech, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will explore all avenues in order to provide for the families of workers living on low wages.
It is monstrous to expect a family of six, seven or eight persons to exist on a wage based on a family of four.
It means continual poverty, sickness and struggle with the spectre of unemployment ever present.
Labor will find a satisfactory solution to this problem.

Lang's 1925 promise to families established a proud and enduring Labor tradition, a tradition to assert the responsibilities of the state to the family in a practical way. That tradition continues today, and that responsibility is reaffirmed in the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlement Amendment Bill (No. 2), which implements the family allowance supplement. The family allowance supplement, which will be introduced next month, has two important features: the benefits it provides are substantial and it is targeted at families on the lowest incomes. In other words, it provides the greatest assistance to those Australian families in greatest need.

The history of the development of assistance to families in Australia shows two recurring themes. There has been opposition and neglect from the conservative parties, and the only significant advances ever have occurred under Labor governments. For example, Lang, following his election in 1925, confronted determined opposition. His predecessor, John Storey, who incidentally established Australia's first and only Ministry of Public Health and Motherhood, promised but never delivered assistance to families. The Lang Bill provided 10s a week for each child under 14 years of age, and this at a time when the basic wage was #4 2s and lower paid workers received much less. Lang records that at the time carriers were paid 25s a week and they had to find a horse and cart as well. Very often the horse was fed and the family went without. Lang's 10s a week a child Bill was rejected by a hostile upper House in 1927. Interestingly, it was also opposed by the Trades Hall at the time. The officials of Trades Hall feared that endowment would be used to lower the basic wage.
We have a happy contrast today: the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Bill Kelty, has rightly hailed the Hawke family package as a great reform. Kelty has said:
Left to our own bargaining capacity, it would take at least 50 to 60 years to increase the real wage rates of the lower wage earners to rates represented in the family package.

In the face of upper House obstruction, Lang accepted a compromise of 5s a week. There the base rate stayed, at 50c a week for the next 50 years. In fact the conservatives, under Stevens, who succeeded Lang in New South Wales, took away the payment for the first child. The Commonwealth took the scheme over during World War II and extended it to all Australian families, but still failed to pay for the first child. Labor, in 1945, increased the base rate to 7s 6d a week and, in 1948, to 10s a week. It was left to Menzies in 1950 to restore the 5s a week payment for the first child-the only improvement of any significance implemented by conservative governments in 60 years. During the 23 years of conservative rule between 1949 and 1972, endowment for the first child stayed at 50c a week; endowment for the second child stayed at $1 a week; and for the third and fourth children it rose from $1 to $2 and to $2.25 respectively. For the families of Australia those were 23 years of neglect.

Under the Whitlam Labor Government families enjoyed the first real improvement in over a generation. Endowment was continued and to it was added a system of tax rebates which increased the value of payment for the second child four-fold and for the first child to nine times the level it was under the Liberals. All of this was abolished by the Liberals in 1976 and replaced by the family allowance. The Fraser family allowance scheme has always attracted more credit than it deserved. It was in fact a fraud on Australian families, because at no time did the family allowance reach the value of endowment and indexed rebates provided by Labor in 1975.

The 1987 Labor package provides substantial and tax free payments of $22 a week for children up to 12 years of age and $28 a week for teenage children, plus a rental allowance of $15. It targets those benefits within the framework of a generous income test. For example, a family with five children under 12 years of age and renting will receive part payment with an income of up to $598 a week. I believe that the principle that benefits should be targeted to those in greatest need is very important. It is especially important in times when governments have limited resources. This principle is being applied well in the design of the family allowance supplement.

I have previously expressed concern that the family allowance supplement might suffer the same fate as its predecessor, the family income supplement (FIS), in that its undoubted benefits might not reach all eligible families. It is well recognised that the FIS had a low take-up rate. How low nobody really knew, but estimates have varied from 50 per cent down to 20 per cent, mainly because the scheme was poorly promoted and poorly advertised. It is a difficult proposition because the target group is in work-low paid work but nevertheless work. So the client or target group is never in regular contact with officers of the Department of Social Security. They need to be reached for this scheme to be a success. In this respect I congratulate the Government, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and his Department on their efforts so far to publicise the family allowance supplement and to reach the target group. Those efforts so far have been good. The brochure which has been produced is clear and attractive and easy to read, with a tear out reply slip that I am sure will boost the take-up rate. The public launch, which took place last Friday at Mount Druitt, was a well attended and very successful occasion. It was attended by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Social Security and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), the local member for the area covering Mount Druitt. The Prime Minister and the honourable member for Chifley both delivered fine speeches on that important occasion.

It is a great pity that the event did not attract greater publicity. In this respect, I must say that I am disappointed with the metropolitan media, because the Saturday papers had the choice of using photographs of the Prime Minister with the honourable member for Chifley and the Minister for Social Security on the one hand, or, with Alan Bond at a subsequent function on the other. In a regrettable instance of misplaced priorities, the newspapers chose the Bond photographs. I have nothing against Bond. He is making a very generous gift of a replica of the Endeavour to the Australian people. But a half a billion dollar package to assist Australian families was a far more significant story, particularly when the columnists of the same newspapers regularly attack the Prime Minister for supposedly abandoning traditional Labor values. Further, the honourable member for Chifley, either in or out of a cocked hat, is one of the most photogenic members ever to have graced the green leather of this chamber. I think it is a pity that the photograph was not used. Despite that fact, the launch at Mount Druitt was a great success.

The follow-up activities that the Minister has mentioned include the distribution of information through trade unions and community organisations, the seeking of assistance through employers and working through ethnic groups and Aboriginal communities. I am sure that, given this effort, the take up rate will be a very good one.

The history of the development of programs to assist Australian families has been marked by a consistent difference between the non-Labor and the Labor parties. On the conservative side of politics, whenever the current Opposition and its predecessors have been able to get away with it they have never hesitated to attack family living standards. They have improved the lot of the Australian family only when it has been absolutely politically unavoidable, and even then only by miserly amounts. The only exception in 60 years of hostility and neglect was Menzies' 50c paid in 1950 for the first child. Successors to Stevens, Menzies, Fraser and the rest of the conservatives in this Parliament-the inheritors of that Liberal anti-family tradition-are just as anti-family as their predecessors. Let me quote from the transcript of an interview with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program AM on 5 November. When asked about expenditure cuts to finance a new Liberal tax policy, he said:
. . . we've also indicated in the welfare area, whether it be in unemployment benefits, supporting parents benefits and indeed on Medicare, the schedule of areas we would cut.
Well, they're all going to be reviewed because our tax package is dependent on cuts in Government expenditure.
So they'll all be there.
The interviewer asked:
Can you be more specific, especially in areas concerning social welfare?
The Deputy Leader of the Opposition stated:
Yes, I could be. But, after all, the duty is on the Government to be specific, not us. So I'm not going further than that at this stage, nor do I have to.

What terrific news that is for the under-privileged! What a great reassurance that is for Australian families from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition! Labor, in contrast, has a great and proud history of improving the lot of Australian families. Lang, Curtin, Chifley and Whitlam all worked for and improved conditions for Australian families. The Hawke family package is the latest achievement in this proud Labor tradition, a tradition which is based firmly on the ideals on which our great Party was founded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I want to address the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) and to refer particularly to one of the sections in that Bill which relates to proposals to change the hardship provisions for the assets test. In my view this is yet another case of the Government overstepping the mark and imposing, in relation to this relatively new assets test, intolerably harsh rules which do not take account of the variety of circumstances in which people can be affected by the assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to get my comments into context let me firstly read what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) in his second reading speech said these provisions would do. He said:

Under the hardship provisions of the assets test, certain assets can be disregarded. However, income which could reasonably be generated by those disregarded assets is taken into account when calculating the rate of pension payable under the hardship provisions.
Recent interpretations of these provisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have undermined its purpose and effect, so this Bill contains a measure to clarify the Government's intention.
The Minister continued:

Pension calculated under the financial hardship test will be reduced by the greater of 2.5 per cent per annum of the property disregarded under the test; or the income which could reasonably be expected to be obtained from commercial use of the property disregarded under the test.

The Minister referred to income which could reasonably be generated from the property or assets which had been disregarded. The Government is of the view that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), having looked at the circumstances of the cases of the people involved, has come to the wrong decision. The AAT has determined that there are cases of hardship but the Government is saying `the AAT is wrong. What we will do is deem a minimum 2 1/2 per cent income on those assets. We believe that the income which could be generated by those assets ought to be assessed at 2 1/2 per cent flat with no discretion'. That is really what is at stake here.

I put to the Minister the difficulties which this measure will pose for many people who have been subjected to the assets test. Let us get that into relative terms. I am not talking about the 15 millionaires who are supposedly caught by the assets test. I am talking about the other end of the scale-the really hard cases, the battling Aussie, especially the battling Aussie farmer. Why farmers? Let me just explain. Firstly, I take the asset that most people hold or try to gain through their life, that is, their house. Their house is not taken into account in the assets test. If one happens to be lucky enough to live in a city, one's house is likely to be worth a lot more than if one lived in the country. So, firstly, farmers are discriminated against because if they put their money into a country house their assets will be worth less than if they put their money into a city house. Secondly, many poor farmers have taken in family members, as I shall explain in some examples I shall give later. They have done so in circumstances in which I believe the application of this measure will cause enormous trauma and social dislocation. If the pensioners who have been granted a pension up to date but, subject to this legislation, will not be eligible for one in future, are forced to realise their asset to sell up the farm, they will be selling the livelihood of other members of their family, and that will cause enormous dislocation. In fact, it could increase, not reduce, the Government's social security payout.

I say to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe)-I am delighted that he is at the table-that in some instances the return on rural land is not as high as what might be considered basic commercial returns, because the farmers who have survived on that rural land have accepted, and are prepared to suffer, lower standards of living than their urban counterparts. I could take the Minister to many farms in my electorate where farmers are happy farming their land but do not earn the sorts of returns that one would expect as normal commercial returns for the asset value of that land. I repeat that we are talking about the really hard cases, not the general run of the mill cases. The Department was good enough to indicate to me just how many cases we are talking about. I think it is important that we get this in perspective. I was advised that as at 30 June 1987 there were 820 hardship cases to which this legislation might apply. Of those cases, 24 were receiving benefits as a result of AAT decisions.

The Minister, in his second reading speech, said that the AAT had decided that these people were in circumstances of hardship, and although the Department had not accepted that these were hardship cases they had been granted pensions. There were other cases that had been before the AAT-I think that 32 cases have been reviewed by the AAT. Fifteen decisions have been in favour of the Department and 17-involving 24 cases-have been in favour of the applicants. If we limit ourselves to the people to whom the Minister referred in his second reading speech, we are talking about 24 people. Even if we take the outside number of 820 people, how many of those will be affected by this change to the legislation?

The Department has carried out a survey of 44 cases in New South Wales where the 2.5 per cent deemed income provision would have had an effect on the pension that was otherwise payable. Only four of those 44 cases had used the 2.5 per cent. Of the 40 remaining, if the 2.5 per cent deemed income provision in the legislation were implemented, the Department believes on that survey that 20 per cent will not be affected, 20 per cent will have their pensions cancelled and 60 per cent will have a part reduction in their pensions. So if that survey is applicable to the whole of Australia-and there is some doubt about that, but let us say that the survey is indicative of the rest of Australia-then we are talking about 80 per cent of the 820 hardship cases on which basis the Department is currently paying pension, whether it is the result of the Department accepting or of the AAT ruling that it is a hardship case. Again, I say that we are really talking about the hard cases. There are not a lot of them. Eighty per cent of 820 is 650-odd cases. The Government is currently paying pensions to 1.3 million age pensioners. We are talking about fewer than 0.05 per cent of the age pensions payable in this country. I put it to the Minister that by deeming that these people will earn 2 1/2 per cent from their assets, the Government will cause some real difficulties for some of those 820 cases.

I want to highlight to the Minister two cases which come from my electorate where I believe it is unconscionable to remove the discretion that the Department currently has and to impose a 2 1/2 per cent deemed income provision. I take the case of Mr and Mrs Butler. They took up a war service settlement block of 260 hectares 38 years ago. It was their first real home. Mr Butler was 39 years of age and Mrs Butler was 37. They had been married for eight years before they got their first chance to get a small war service settlers block of 260 hectares. When their son left school he immediately went to work on the family farm. He had been working there for 14 years without income; he had not been paid wages as his parents could not afford it. In 1981 the parents retired and they leased the land to their son for $100 a week.

Following the introduction of the assets test, Mrs Butler-who has, of course, lived with her husband on the property in the south-east of South Australia since 1949-suddenly had her pension cancelled. The pension had been denied to Mrs Butler on the ground that her husband owned a property worked by their son, who had been paying them rental of $100 a week since their retirement. Mr Butler, who is 72 years of age, had received a war service pension. The farming community was extremely concerned that one of its members could be so affected by the assets test. Honourable members will remember that there was uproar throughout Australia over the harshness of the assets test. So the Government brought in provisions to ameliorate the really hard cases. Even under those provisions, the Department of Social Security did not believe that the Butlers were entitled to a pension and so, with the support of the farming community and the National Farmers Federation which assisted in underwriting the legal costs, the Butlers appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The hearing was told that the parents had surrendered insurance policies in 1984 in order to reroof the house on their property. That left them with $800 with which to support themselves after their pensions had been cancelled. They needed to borrow money from their family to support themselves, including from their son who, in turn, had borrowed money from the bank. The capital value of the 260 hectare farm had been assessed in November 1985 at $412,000, although it was agreed at the hearing that it was probable that the land values could have dropped by 20 or 30 per cent. Here was an asset worth between $300,000 and $400,000 which had been farmed by the parents. The son leased the land, having worked on it for some 14 years without being paid wages. The Government came along and said, `Well, we have applied the assets test. Sorry, you will have to get off. Your son will have to pay you a pension or we will have to sell up the land'. The son was clearly not in a position to pay his parents a pension. There was just not that amount of money to be earned from the property. In this case the appeal to the AAT was successful and the pension was restored to the Butlers. But all that is now put at risk because if this legislation is passed, the Department can now override the AAT decision by reviewing the pension that is currently payable to Mr and Mrs Butler. It can say to them, `Well, we are sorry. You have proved to the AAT that yours was a genuine case of hardship where it would be unconscionable for us to force you to sell the family farm from under your son, but the legislation has been passed and that is what we are going to do'.
Sitting suspended from 6.29 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was pointing to the concern that I and the Opposition have with the impact of this legislation on some of the people who have been affected by the assets test and who will no longer be able to avail themselves of the hardship provisions. I was giving examples, and will give another example-a farmer in my electorate whose parents in 1952 bought a war service settlers property of 900 acres. Subsequently the son left school, went to work with his parents on the land, and bought another 350 acres. But the Department of Lands in South Australia said that the small area he purchased was not viable by itself and that it should be put in the name of the parents and the young man concerned as joint tenants and become part of the total farm.

SPEECH.PARA: The parents are now in their late sixties, they have retired, and would like to be on a pension. The son, who is 35 years old, is working on the land and has a wife and four children. The property is in joint tenancy and is valued at some $480,000. Given the application of this amendment to the legislation, the Department will say, `Your parents have two-thirds of the ownership of the property as two of the three joint tenants. Therefore, the value of their portion is around $320,000 and they should be getting a deemed income of 2.5 per cent from that land'. Therefore, the Department's view is that the parents are not entitled to a pension.

The Department of Agriculture has reviewed the case and has said that once the loan commitments on the stock mortgages are paid the annual net income is $8,000. The question I ask the Government is: How can one deem an income from this property of 2.5 per cent when the South Australian Department of Agriculture says that once the stock mortgages are paid the net income from that property is $8,000? The Government is saying to the person concerned that out of that $8,000 he must pay a pension to his parents and keep a wife and four children. Clearly it is a scandal and this legislation should be allowed to remain unamended. The discretion should be left, as it is now, with the Department.

In my view, there are three options. First, the Government could leave the law as it is, which clearly is the option favoured by the Opposition as expressed in our amendment. Secondly, and alternatively, the Government could give an undertaking that the new rule deeming a 2.5 per cent income from assets will apply only to new pension applicants. It will allow those who have successfully proved on lodged claims with the Department of Social Security or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal that they have a hardship case to receive a pension. Clearly, the Opposition favours the first option. The second option would be reasonably acceptable. The third option, the one that we fear most, is that the Department will review all of these cases, even where the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has been satisfied that there is hardship and that the assets test should not apply. Our concern is that in those circumstances under this legislation the Department of Social Security will be bound to review the pension, and that in such cases those people will have their pension revoked and will be forced to sell the land from under their children's feet, and their children will in all likelihood be forced on to the unemployment benefit. I believe that the net cost to the community will be much higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the cognate Bill are significant in the Government's strategy. Reference was made to these matters in the Budget because we believed that we needed to do something substantial and fundamental in respect of the standard of living of people in the community, particularly if it could be demonstrated that living standards for some had begun to fall. Let me take the picture back a little further and sketch what I believe is the fundamental element in our approach to standards of living. The Opposition seems to miss this point whenever it seeks to address these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: We have held it to be fundamental that housing is important in establishing living standards. I shall deal with the social security aspects in a moment. Consequently we have directed a good deal of effort towards establishing housing in both the private and the public sector. We have achieved great success in the number of homes built and the number of people who have taken over those homes. The fundamental point that can be demonstrated about this country and standards of living is that when one gets people into homes it immediately transforms their lifestyles. It gives them a stake in the community which they might not otherwise have. Therefore, any debate on social security and the rights and entitlements of people in the community and the Government's duty to meet those rights and entitlements must be underpinned by the philosophical view one takes about housing. Our philosophical view is that housing is a fundamental.

The other philosophical view the Government has is that employment is a fundamental. When one considers the record that this Government has been able to establish, one can look by the end of 1988 at a substantial increase in jobs-indeed, a million new jobs since 1983. As a new member of parliament in 1983, I found the projections that we were making about jobs quite impressive. I now find in retrospect that we were able to achieve our target and go well beyond it. Therefore, the second part of any debate about living standards and the rights and entitlements of people in the community must be underpinned by a view about employment. The second characteristic that Labor members can point to is that this Government has a very good employment record.

The third characteristic that sets us apart from the Opposition in this debate is that if one has limited resources and an economy in which one has to make some tough decisions it is important that those limited resources go to areas in which they can be most effective. We have attempted to put together a social security policy that aims to address need. That is not without difficulty. When one approaches social security policy and seeks to direct resources to those most in need, one knows that one will also not give resources to those who, in the Government's judgment, are not so greatly in need. We have made that judgment in a number of areas; we have certainly made it with respect to pensions and the assets test of which the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) has spoken. In doing so, we have been able to say that, given a limited resource base, if one addresses those most in need on can feel satisfied at the end of a period that one has done something substantial in changing living standards.

Previous Labor speakers in this debate have given great detail in this respect and their speeches have been impressive. One factor which characterises our success in addressing the area of need has been the change in the pension rate. We are now looking at a pension of 24.8 per cent of average weekly earnings. It is a wonderful achievement and our target is to get the figure towards 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. In this third element of policy, when one tries to address the area of need, one seeks to award pensions where they are most needed.

The other side of the coin which disturbs me is that the Opposition for a good deal of its time is preoccupied with those who may no longer get a full entitlement to pension. As I said earlier, it is entailed by the decision that one seeks to address those who are most in need. There will be some people one sees as not being in great need. The Opposition continually makes the point that it is concerned about those who no longer receive those entitlements. What we find surprising is that Opposition members never spend any time talking about those who have been aided, those who are at the lower end of the economic spectrum. The electorate makes judgments from time to time. It has made a judgment three times since I have been a member of this Parliament. The electorate has found the Opposition policy somewhat wanting.

Having addressed the areas of need more powerfully than was the case in the past, we find that we still need to make some adjustments. That is what brings me to one of the elements of this policy, the new family package. Given the change in the nature of Australian society and the economy, we have deduced the fact that large numbers of people need an injection of money to lift their living standards. From the research that has been undertaken we know that this group of people tends to be characterised by large families. They tend to live in large suburbs which many honourable members on this side of the chamber represent, the western suburbs of Melbourne and Sydney for instance. If we are able to address this area of need-evidence is available that families in the private rental market are even worse off-in terms of money we might go a long way towards solving some of the immediate economic problems these people face. That is what this legislation is about.

Having considered the issue of housing as a fundamental underpinning and having done something to make housing available, having considered the area of unemployment and having tried to make jobs available and then having said that, given limited resources, we will direct those resources to the areas of greatest need, despite the political fall-out that might entail, we then came to the conclusion that we needed to do something else in terms of an injection of funds. As I have said, my colleagues have addressed those matters very eloquently. It would be wrong to try to cover their ground again. It is important to mention how well my colleagues have covered this area, including references to former New South Wales Premier Lang. I found that a very impressive historical testament. The Opposition still does not seem to have learnt the lesson that it is all very well for a policy which focuses on need and which concentrates on those who may have missed out in the process but we should remember that a substantial number of people have gained in the process. We still hold the view that we have a responsibility to them, particularly in difficult economic circumstances.

One of the things that characterise this economy now, given the difficulties of economic management, as distinct from the economies of Great Britain and the United States, is that we do not have the degree of social division that characterises both of those societies. People in economics such as I might want to dwell upon global statistics but when it comes down to it one has to ask oneself how healthy a society is as a consequence of its government's policy making. On the barest possible analysis Australian society is far healthier because of the lack of the social division that characterises Britain which now fundamentally has two economies, the economy of the north which is depressed and the economy of the south which, at least in terms of the yuppies, was booming three weeks ago. The United States economy can be characterised in regions. Nevertheless, what fundamentally underpins United States society in terms of all the social statistics is that it is a divided community.

All Government members can feel satisfied that we have addressed the fundamental elements of housing and jobs, and the areas of need. In so doing we have a community that is not characterised by widespread social division. It is always possible to point to problems but they exist in any large community. If we look at the overall structure we can feel pleased and somewhat proud that we have achieved major economic changes without producing social division. That is not easy in this world, particularly given the changes in economic activity.

In addressing the areas of need, one of the areas we still need to look at in regard to senior citizens is that very often superannuitants, for example, because they do not have entitlements to fringe benefits, in final terms may end up a little worse off than people who are on the full pension. What we ought to be examining is our attitude to the aged. It has been examined in part here impressively. We have made some changes to fringe benefits entitlements and in terms of extra earnings, what is called the Father Christmas clause, which is a very good move. We can do two things. Firstly, like many communities we ought to honour the aged. We ought to make the fact that one turns 65 years of age something to be respected. Many other countries do it, and do it well. Secondly, we ought to give senior citizens a senior citizen's card.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Edwards card.

—Yes. The card could say, in effect, `You have now turned 65. You are a senior citizen of Australia. This card will entitle you to a limited range of fringe benefits'. Those benefits could include certain entitlements with respect to the telephone rental allowance. State governments could also give senior citizens an entitlement to a reduced fare or even free off-peak transport on trams, trains or buses. Certainly in regard to movie theatres and sporting associations there could be entitlements. I have already discussed with the Western Australian Cricket Association, the Western Australian Football League and the Hoyts cinema chain whether they would recognise that sort of card. It would not be a great cost to the community. A large monetary element is not involved. My friend and colleague the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free) acknowledges that.

SPEECH.PARA: We should examine the idea of a senior citizen's card. Once people turn 65 we could offer them an indication that we believe that is an important achievement and give them rights and entitlements they might otherwise not get. It would do something to even out some of the slight anomalies that occur between superannuitants and those who are on the full pension. If we implemented this proposal in co-operation with State governments many people would welcome it. I say that in the context of this debate.

Having made all the decisions I have talked about, particularly in relation to the basic economic entitlements of housing and jobs and having addressed the areas of need, we are in a better position to address these matters. The senior citizen's card package could well be negotiated with State governments and with the appropriate private sector operatives. If we could do this at this level of government many people would feel that we had done a great deal. We might well make it a bicentennial project. If we had a senior citizen's card we might be able to negotiate a deal with the airlines. I have already made some tentative inquires with the airlines. During 1988 a person who possessed a senior citizen's card might well get a trip to Canberra to view the new Parliament House. The airlines could use some of their spare capacity to enable this.

Many elderly people in Australia, particularly those from outlying States, such as Queensland, which my colleague the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) represents, and Western Australia, which I represent, would deem it a privilege to be able to come to Canberra and view their new Parliament House. If the senior citizen's card were in place entitling a card holder to come to Canberra using the standby capacity of an airline-many standby seats are available-or a similar arrangement with bus companies, we might well find that we could build many bridges in the community. Many people think that the Parliament House we are moving to is an expensive enterprise and one they want to see some value from. One way to guarantee that they see some value from it is to make it possible for everyone over the age of 65, through having a senior citizens card, to come to Canberra and visit the new Parliament House as a bicentennial project.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Senate, too.

—As my friend says, we could show them that there was activity in the Parliament by getting them to visit both the House of Representatives and the Senate. They would learn a lot more about the operation of Australia's national government and Parliament. We have the opportunity to look at this idea of mine of a senior citizen's card-and I have discussed it with Caucus colleagues-as a 1988 project. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in discussion earlier this year, indicated to me that a number of steps needed to be taken. One of those steps was to look at the earnings-free area. That area has been looked at, and I think that is very important.
—A great reform.

—It is a great reform because it means that people will no longer lose their pension entitlement because they have short term earnings. People might work at the Melbourne Show or the Sydney Show or they might work as a Santa Claus and lose their pension entitlement.

SPEECH.PARA: Incidentally, I think I should make it clear in this debate that the decision that caused pensioners' incomes to be in peril because of short term earnings was a decision not of the Government but of the Federal Court of Australia. It arose out of a number of other matters. There was a tendency for a number of people to see that decision as something that was just brought about by this Government. In fact, it was not. It was a decision by a court which, looking at the legalities of the matter, ruled that we were not entitled to overlook those extra earnings. What we have done is reinstate that element in this legislation, and I believe that to be very important. It also indicates that this Government is responsive. Previous speakers, including the honourable member for Barker, have said that the Government is not responsive. This Government is responsive to these issues in the community.

Summing up, I believe that what we have attempted to do, in terms of this legislation and in terms of our overall strategy, is to address the economic fundamentals. Those fundamentals relate to such matters as housing and employment. They also relate to this Government's ability to direct resources to areas of need. In the current economic crisis, which has been of concern to everyone in the community, one of the things that has been very satisfying is that we have not been overtaken by a sense of the 1930s. The big thing that has characterised this period, as distinct from the 1930s, has been people's knowledge that their income is secure, particularly if they are social security beneficiaries. The other thing to be noticed already is that people's jobs have been secure, and that is also in marked contrast to the 1930s. One of the lessons that we in this Government have learned-and it has not always been an easy lesson-is that, when we do have to make tough decisions about social security recipients and apply these needs-based policies, it will always be the case that some people will be put under pressure because they will miss out. But it is also clearly demonstrable that in so doing we have ceased to pay pensions to some people who clearly never needed them.

I know that a lot is said by the Opposition in this place about the assets test. The Opposition still holds the view that it would repeal what I would regard as the socially progressive elements in our policy. Perhaps Liberal members should talk to the President of their Party because clearly he is a little more attuned to the socially progressive elements of the policy that we have put in place. It has not been without cost. The cost has been the effort put in by Ministers and backbenchers in explaining it to people. But this should be considered in conjunction with tax reform.

I conclude my remarks by saying that the view put by the Australian Council of Trade Unions is that these decisions, particularly in relation to the family allowance supplement, are better than a wage increase. They clearly are, because they are directed to those in need, they do not have the highly inflationary aspect that a wage increase would have had and they leave us with the conviction that we are getting to the areas of need.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they are tax free.

—As my colleague points out, the supplement is also tax free, so in fact the maximum benefit is going to the areas of greatest need. I am pleased to be able to make these remarks in relation to this legislation. It is just a further example of us putting in place policies that are directed and sensible. Accordingly, I am pleased to commend these pieces of legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising tonight I must say that I am very pleased to make a contribution to the cognate debate on the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlement Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I will be making my contribution in the area of social security and veterans' entitlements. Before commencing I would like to take this opportunity, because it is the first time I have had the opportunity of speaking while the current Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has been at the table, to congratulate him on his elevation. I was one of those who were pleased to see him receive that mark of his ability. I would, of course, prefer to see him as a shadow Minister on this side of the House. Be that as it may, I offer him my personal goodwill for the job he is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like also to congratulate the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on his contribution to tonight's debate. I think it is quite significant that he spoke for the full 20 minutes without reference to a single note. It was his usual performance. But I regret that I have to take issue with one or two of the things the honourable member for Stirling said. Madam Speaker, it will come as no surprise to you, to him or to anybody else in this place that I might just happen in passing to have a word or two to say about the assets test. The honourable member for Stirling described it as a socially progressive policy with a great deal of cost in effort by Ministers. I would like to suggest that the real cost has been to elderly citizens of Australia. I will develop that particular theme as my time proceeds. The honourable member for Stirling also made some reference to an earlier speaker on the Government side. He referred to his citing an impressive historical example in referring back to Jack Lang in the 1930s.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1920s actually.

—I thank the honourable member very much and accept his correction. I was also listening to other speakers on the Government side in this debate. The honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), in a not very impressive historical example, placed the blame for all of the current ills of Australia on the Menzies Government. We in this place are accustomed to, used to and practically bored stiff by the practice of the Government, from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) down to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), of carrying on with the stale pastry of saying, `It all goes back to the Fraser time; it is the Fraser-Howard Government or the Fraser-Anthony Government'. This stale pastry has been trotted out sitting day after sitting day, week after week, ever since I have been elected. But I really thought the honourable member for Forde carried it just a little too far in laying all the blame at the feet of Sir Robert Menzies.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the veterans affairs part of this legislation, I must say that I really welcome the action which is removing the anomalies associated with the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension following the decision of the Federal Court of Australia in August 1987. Honourable members will recall that that decision had the impact of making it not just likely but legal under the existing law that TPI pensioners would lose their TPI pension at the age of 65 years. Of course, that created an enormous amount of anguish and a great deal of distress among the veterans community, particularly among those of our fellow Australians in receipt of the TPI pension. Again, I commend the Minister at the table for his prompt action, not just in having that effect set aside in this legislation but also for making the announcement as soon as he possibly could after consultation with his Cabinet colleagues so as to relieve the distress of so many elderly Australians, people for whom I have a great deal of sympathy.

I have a total commitment, intellectually and emotionally, to the veterans community in this country. I know, from first-hand experience of my family, the commitment made by veterans. I would just like to echo the words of the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann), who spoke earlier in this debate and who said, as I have said here before on many occasions, that the TPI pension is not so much a pension as it is compensation. It is a commitment made by successive governments in this country of all political colours. It is a commitment that must be maintained and cannot be moved away from.

I am also very pleased with the extension of full entitlements to World War II ex-service women. I say in passing that that was coalition policy at the last election and I am very pleased indeed that the Government has taken up that policy and brought it into effect. It is worth noting, too, that World War I ex-service women were extended these benefits in 1958. While it is a bit of a case of better late than never, I am very pleased that these benefits are now being extended to World War II ex-service women. But, at the same time, I note that the Returned Services League of Australia is concerned that this clause does not refer to ex-service women who were warned for active service and embarked but did not actually serve in a theatre of war. I would have thought that this extension of benefits could easily have been made. We on this side of the House are quite concerned that service women who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam have been excluded from this amending legislation. With all goodwill, I invite the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to relook at that point. I am told that it would affect only 150 women and that, if those 150 women claimed absolutely everything to which they were entitled, there would be a maximum cost of $65,000 per year. I must say that I am quite concerned that for such a limited amount of money we are excluding ex-service women who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

I note, too, that the Returned Services League is concerned that no provision has been made for the payment of interest on payments to entitled veterans who have had pensions withheld for some reason, whether applications were awaiting determination or held up in the Department of Finance. It is probably fair to say, not only for veterans as in this case but also for other people in Australia, that what is good for the goose should be good for the gander. For instance, if any of these people are late with a taxation payment, there is an automatic fee of interest of 20 per cent. It is quite reasonable and fair and in the spirit of a fair go that anybody having his pension withheld for some reason should have interest paid to him on the outstanding moneys owed to him.

I am really very concerned about what is likely to happen with the assets test. As I have done on many occasions in this House, I repeat that the Opposition, the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia, has a total commitment to abolish the assets test on pensions when they return to government. That is a commitment from which we will not waiver.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does John Elliott feel about that?

—The honourable member will have to talk to John Elliott. He is not in this Parliament. I say again that the policy of the coalition, of the Opposition, is that the assets test on pensions will be repealed. I have been very concerned about this ever since before being elected to Parliament. I am concerned that so many of our elderly citizens have been placed in a situation of distress. It particularly applies to people in the farming communities, in those parts of Australia outside the capital cities.
