We have the unfair situation that somebody with 200 or 300 acres in my electorate can lose the pension because of that, yet somebody else in Vaucluse or some other place, with a house worth $1m, can still get the pension.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is here, I would like to make reference to one of the matters which he raises constantly in debate whenever the assets test is raised. Just as I have a view, I note that he has his. I respect his view but I do not respect the way in which he keeps floating out the position of the 12, 16 or 32 millionaires. I for one must say that I do not really think that somebody who is a millionaire should necessarily get the pension, although the Minister would say that, if a person is a millionaire in terms of assets in a harbourside house, that person should get the pension. The reality is that I am not concerned about those millionaires that the Minister trots out. I agree with him that it is inappropriate for them to get the pension, but I do not think he is correct, right or fair in trying to demolish the debate or the arguments about the assets test as it affects ordinary Australians just because of the few outstanding exceptions. Of course, what will happen with this amending Bill is that it will open up access to the hardship provisions but will also tighten the application of the assets test. The new provision requires as a matter of law the pension calculated under the financial hardship test to be reduced by the greater of 2.5 per cent per annum of the value of property disregarded under the test, or the income which could reasonably be expected to be generated by the use of property disregarded under the test if the property is used commercially, that is, efficiently and economically.

The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), when he was speaking in the debate, rolled out the old canards, the stale pastry, about the millionaires. For some reason that I could not really understand, he started talking about pensioners driving BMWs and Saabs. I just could not see the relevance of that. We are not talking about people driving BMWs and Saabs. We are talking about elderly Australians who have made their contribution to this country, who have worked hard all their lives and are still being dispossessed by the assets test.

Clause 11 (3) (c) seeks to amend sub-section 7 (1) to impose a further limitation on the application of the financial hardship test to beneficiaries. That test would exclude property of a beneficiary from the normal operation of the assets test only if the beneficiary or the spouse of the beneficiary could not sell or realise the property and could not use it as security for borrowing. The explanatory memorandum states:
Accordingly, if there is a market for the property, that property would not be excluded.
That is a most significant phrase:
Accordingly, if there is a market for the property, that property would not be excluded.

But the question must be asked: at what price? There is always a market for property if it is cheap enough, if it is going to be thrown away. Is the intention of the Minister and the Bill to force people to sell out at ridiculous prices just to stay alive because they do not measure up? I ask that question again: at what price will they be forced to sell?
I am also very interested in the prospect of the application of the assets test to unemployment and sickness beneficiaries over 25 years of age. The explanatory memorandum states:

The test would be similar to the current pensioner assets test, although broadly once the assets threshold was reached, benefit would cease to be payable. This measure would come into effect on 13 December 1987.

I can see some virtue in what the Minister is trying to achieve with this measure, but, again, I see a great deal of danger. There is no time limit, no period of waiting to see what will happen, once somebody becomes unemployed. We could have the situation of somebody becoming unemployed and, because of the property he holds, being assessed as unable to get the unemployment or sickness benefit and being immediately forced, therefore, into selling off property. What would be the effect on the family if in six weeks, two months or six months the man again gets a job? Mind you, I must say that, under the present economic policies, that is not very likely because, if that person is in his forties or fifties, the likelihood of his getting another job is, unfortunately, very remote indeed. This is something that causes me a great deal of concern. I briefly repeat the point that, if there is a market for the property, that property would not be excluded-but at what price? Are we to force people who lose their job to flog off their assets for virtually nothing in order to survive? I do not think that that is the Minister's intention. I hope he will look at this aspect of it and reconsider it.
There may be an anomaly in terms of the assets test being introduced on the payment of unemployment, sickness and special benefit to people over 25 years of age. The second reading speech states:
Under the assets test, benefit will generally not be paid to people whose assets exceed a specified amount.

The amounts are the same as those used for the pension assets test. For a married home owner it is $59,250, or $118,500 combined. I do not have time to cite all the figures. I wonder what will happen when a married man with a wife, children and a mortgage has to sell assets and is subjected to the same assets test as a married couple. I think that there may be a problem there.

It seems, on listening to the honourable member for Stirling-I said when I started that I appreciated his contribution to the debate-the honourable member for Forde and the honourable member for Dobell, that there is a belief on the Government side of the chamber that the Australian Labor Party has a mortgage on compassion and caring. I assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Minister and the people of Australia that that is not the case. We in the National Party and our colleagues and friends in the Liberal Party are equally concerned about the people of Australia. We are equally concerned about the poverty which exists. I am most distressed about the long waiting queues for housing in my electorate, which is on the north coast of New South Wales, and the 25 per cent unemployment rate. It is not just 25 per cent unemployment for youngsters; it is for people in their forties and fifties whose chance of getting another job is very remote.

I think it is appropriate to say at this point that the family package provisions put forward by the Government will help many people. I do not propose to take the time of the House by singling them all out. Government speakers have done that. They have praised those things very well indeed. But I would like to raise one particular point. The Minister, in his second reading speech, referred to the job search allowance. I am pleased to see what the Government is doing here because I believe-although I am sure that the Minister will disagree with me-that this is an indication that the Government has finally admitted that Priority One: Young Australia has failed. I regret that that is the case. The Minister for Social Security may laugh. He will have an opportunity to tell me how many jobs have been created under Priority One. I see that he is shaking his fingers to indicate that he will do so. When the Minister tells us how many jobs have been created, perhaps he will tell us what the target and the time span were. Unfortunately, Priority One has failed. The Minister said:

The job search allowance will replace unemployment benefit for 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds in January-it will make it very clear that income support is closely tied to the need for young people to be better prepared for the work force.

I totally endorse what the Minister said about the need for young Australians to be better prepared to enter the work force, but I ask him-he may be able to answer very simply-when those people come off the unemployment benefit, because he has said that the job search allowance will replace the unemployment benefit, will they be taken off the unemployed list? Will they be taken away from those who are counted? Is this an artificial means of reducing the unemployment statistics? I think that that is a fair question and I would appreciate an answer. I find quite a lot to agree with in what the Minister said. For instance he said:
We cannot let our young people waste their potential. The job search allowance aims to give them a helping hand in constructive ways.

I will support the Minister and the Government in any practical means of helping to find more jobs for young and more mature people in this country of ours. Our unemployment is totally unacceptable. I look forward to the time when kids can leave school, as they are doing now because some have finished their higher school certificate, with the expectation of having a job and a career that is surely the birthright of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Government and Opposition members for their contribution to this cognate debate on the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). As the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) has just suggested, Government members concentrated their attention largely on the reforms included in the legislation in terms of family assistance. I endorse much of what they said regarding the importance of these measures. I am sure that honourable members on both sides of the House welcome the targeting that is involved in the assistance and the very substantial assistance we have provided not only to pensioner and beneficiary families but also to low income working families. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) referred to the issue of a senior citizen's card. That is a matter which has been close to his heart for some time and the Government will give consideration to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition concentrated its criticism of the legislation on the introduction of the benefits assets test and the 2.5 per cent deeming rule which has been written into the legislation. Ordinarily, the assets test imputes income at the rate of about 10 per cent of the value of an asset. Where this results in hardship, there is a discretion to reduce the level of imputation. That is done on a discretionary basis. I think honourable members will recognise that the Government's decision regarding hardship and its decision to allow that administration to proceed administratively as opposed to legislatively has caused some problems in terms of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's decisions.

The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) suggested that the new measure was somewhat harsh, but the Government has to ensure, when it does provide for hardship, and provides effectively for some discretion in relation to the assets test, that that discretion will be honoured in practice. Effectively, we are aware that in terms of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions the hardship provisions were being circumvented. While the honourable member may suggest that, relatively speaking, we are talking about a small amount of money, the reason this Government has been more successful, if I may say so, in terms of managing the economy and achieving Budget outcomes, is that we have worried about what the honourable member has described as relatively small amounts of money.

There is no question that a farmer who had retained a valuable farm, even though it was not producing income, because he wanted to hand it on to his children when he died, and when no income was imputed, even though he had a capacity to support himself by selling or mortgaging the farm, was not required to sell or mortgage it. Rather, the public purse was being called on to support him because, effectively, he wanted to keep the farm to hand on to his children. From time to time crocodile tears are shed on the Opposition side of the House with respect to the assets test. I think that that is seen to be the case if one recognises that, generally speaking, very many people are in the social security system who are certainly not asset rich. Indeed, one of the characteristics of poverty in this country is the absence of assets.

The rules with respect to the assets test exclude the family home. People may have very substantial assets by any standard and not entirely lose the pension. The pension system is there to make sure that Australians have adequate income support. It is not there to subsidise inheritances. If people are concerned about retaining the family farm within the immediate family there is provision by way of the pensions loan scheme. The full pension can be paid and the public can get reimbursement when the pensioner and his or her spouse die. The pension loans scheme is a fair and equitable way of looking after these cases. I enjoin honourable members who are genuinely concerned about what they say they are concerned about-that is, the protection of the family farm or the non-disturbance of a family who has been associated with the property for a long time-to recommend that the pension loans scheme be made more use of in those situations. The Government makes no apology-and we certainly make no apology in the context of the difficult times in which we have operated-for targeting our expenditure to those who have the greatest need. If I might say so, members of the National Party of Australia repeatedly suggest in this House that $2m or $3m is an amount of money with which the Government ought not to concern itself. The honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) suggested essentially that an amount of money of the order of $70m was not worth the Government being concerned about.

The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) criticised the benefits assets test. It is true that in some respects it is somewhat tougher than the assets test on pensions. Of course, one has to recognise that we are talking about a different kind of payment. Benefits tend to be essentially short term. A person with substantial assets without income for a short period is not, comparatively speaking, badly off. The situation is very different for pensioners who are often on a pension for 20 or 30 years.

Administrative reasons played a part in the decision to go for the sudden death assets test. Administratively, it is a much simpler test. The assets test effectively imputes income to a pension proportioned to the values of the asset. As I indicated, the benefits income test is harsher than the pension income test. However, it applies exactly the same principles as the pensioner assets test. The benefits assets test is necessarily, therefore, sudden death. Because of the harsher income test on benefits that the assets test applies, there would be no entitlement to benefits. Any other arrangements would be anomalous.

Several other questions were raised in the debate. I took note of the concern of the honourable member for Fairfax about the older unemployed. I draw his attention to the second of the social security review papers, which specifically dealt with the older unemployed and made a number of suggestions about ways we might provide more effective assistance to that group of people. The Government will consider those next year.

The eligibility of theological students for Austudy is a matter for my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). I will raise that matter with him. I simply make the point that in the Review of Social Security we will be looking at the relationship between income support payments and labour market programs. Questions of eligibility for payments as an alternative to unemployment benefit are a major focus of that concern. In that context it would be possible to examine the concern of the honourable member for Fairfax.

Several matters were raised with respect to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) requested clarification of the Government's intention concerning the extension to 31 December 1988 of pensioner health benefits for some persons as a result of changes to their eligibility consequent on the May economic statement. Sole parents with full time dependent student children aged 16 to 24 who lose eligibility for the supporting parent's benefit or class A widow's pension between 1 September and 31 December 1987 because of the change in the definition of `qualifying child' are to retain entitlement to pensioner health benefit cards until 31 December 1988. These persons were, of course, given short notice of the change. In recognition of this and to allow the sole parents to adjust to the changed financial situation and to plan for the future, the Government decided to extend eligibility for fringe benefits to the end of 1988.

I understand that the honourable member for O'Connor also raised the matter of the deletion from 1 August 1987 of items for the removal of keratosis, warts, et cetera, from the Medicare benefits schedule. It is not a subject matter dealt with in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill but is the subject of much complaint by doctors and patients. The removal of these items was originally difficult, time consuming and mainly performed by specialists. Changed technology has meant that the majority of these conditions are now treated rapidly and painlessly by general practitioners during consultation. The old fee was for a procedure; the new fee is the appropriate consultation fee only. A separate item to cover the removal of large numbers of difficult warts is to be considered for inclusion in the Medicare benefits schedule. Discussions are being held with the medical profession on this subject. Items covering the removal of skin cancer have not been deleted from the schedule. The Government recognises the need for separate procedures to cover these services. Solar keratoses are removed by techniques similar to those for other keretosis warts and are covered by the appropriate attendance item.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in his response implied that I had said that the Government should not concern itself with small amounts of money. Nothing could be further from the truth. I said that the undermining of the assets test hardship provisions involved in this legislation will have an unconscionably harsh impact on a small number of pensioners and that this new provision ought to apply only to new applicants for pensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for their contributions to this debate, especially the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard), the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). The debate was very broad ranging. I think it went from Bob Menzies, to Ben Chifley, to Malcolm Fraser, to nursing homes, to agent orange, to repatriation hospitals, to defence service housing, and on and on.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to answer questions raised by some honourable members who were concerned about certain aspects of this legislation relating to the Department of Veterans' Affairs and veterans' entitlements. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the National Secretary of the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL), Mr Ian Gollings, were concerned about certain aspects of the legislation. I asked the honourable member for Dobell to deal with those. I understand that the honourable member for Farrer was not happy with that, and he just wanted my assurance again on certain aspects in relation to section 24; so I will be happy to do that for the honourable member.

He has requested an assurance that the distinction between the existing section 24 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, which is expressed in the positive sense, and proposed new section 24a, which is expressed in the negative, will not change the way these provisions are applied. Section 24 is a test as to whether certain criteria do apply to a veteran. Proposed new section 24a is a test as to whether the criteria do not apply. I am happy to assure the honourable member, and the National Secretary of the Returned Services League, that this will not change the way these provisions apply.

The honourable member for Farrer is also concerned about the application day. The application day is the day on which the claim or application is received at an office of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Proposed new sub-section 19 (2a) will provide that eligibility for a special rate or intermediate rate pension will be determined only on the application day. This will mean that the determining authority will not be able to look at a veteran, say on the application day, and decide that the veteran is eligible on that day, and also look at some later day, such as when the veteran would have ceased work for reasons other than war caused disabilities, and then grant a pension only for the limited period during which the veteran was unable to work due to war caused disabilities.

This legislative mechanism will overcome the decision of the Federal Court of Australia in McGuire's case where the court based its decision on its view that eligibility for special rate and intermediate rate pensions is subject to a continuing test. Those cases held that a veteran is entitled to receive the totally and permanently incapacitated pension whilst he continues to satisfy the eligibility criteria, not for life. In conjunction with the other proposed amendments, the inclusion of a definition of `application day' will ensure that special rate and intermediate rate pensions, once granted, are payable for the life of the veteran, subject to the exceptions provided for in proposed new section 24a.

The honourable member for Farrer was also concerned that while ex-service women from World War II were receiving full free treatment the Government was not giving the same treatment to ex-service women who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. I would like to point out to the honourable member for Farrer that the Government's decision was in response to a call from the ex-service organisations, particularly the Returned Services League of Australia's resolution 25 of the sixty-ninth National Congress of the RSL, which sought:
that all Repatriation benefits (medical and hospital) as allowed to the Returned Sisters of the 1914-18 War be extended to include all returned ex-servicewomen of the 1939-45 War.

The RSL has not made out a similar case for returned nurses of later conflicts. On the contrary, the RSL has given assurances that the extension of benefits to this group will not be seen as a precedent for a more generalised claim, but is seen as recognition of special disadvantages suffered. I think the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) was also interested in that. I hope that answers their questions.

The other problem that I refer to was mentioned by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron). He was very concerned about the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. He also mentioned that a certain veteran in Queensland was claiming that the Vietnam veterans were getting special treatment over him. I can assure the honourable member for Moreton, and the veterans community, that the Department of Veterans' Affairs does not discriminate and that it treats all veterans equally. I have given that assurance not only to the veteran concerned, but to all Australian veterans. The honourable member also criticised the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital and was also concerned about the visiting medical officers dispute. I have made an offer to the visiting medical officers and I hope they will accept that offer. I am sure that everyone will be happy when they go back to their work at the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital.

I would like to point out that the Government, since coming to office, has put in place a $75m capital works program for all repatriation hospitals throughout Australia. I think that is quite a significant contribution. From 1982-83 to 1987-88 Greenslopes received over $20m for minor, medium and major works, and over $9.5m for specialised equipment. So I think we can view with some suspicion the suggestion of the honourable member for Moreton that the Government is not paying attention to the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. I once again thank all honourable members for their contributions to the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 41, page 36, lines 4 and 5, omit the definition of ``parent'', insert the following definition:
`` `parent', in relation to a person (in this definition called the `child'), means another person who is:
(a) a natural or adoptive parent of the child;
(b) acting as the child's guardian on a long term basis; or
(c) the spouse of such a parent or guardian;
but does not include another person:
(d) with whom the child does not live if the child is living with a different person to whom paragraph (a), (b) or (c) applies; or
(e) who the Secretary decides, in the special circumstances of the case, should not be treated as a parent of the child;''.

(2) Clause 109, page 67, lines 22 to 24, omit the note in italics at the foot of subclause (2), insert the following note: ``Commencement: Immediately after the commencement of the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986 (other than section 61 of that Act)''.

There are only two amendments. The more substantial amendment is to clause 41 of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Bill (No. 2) which deals with a problem with respect to the definition of a parent. For the purposes of the parental income test the definition is not entirely accurate. It picks up only natural parents, whereas it should pick up social parents-that is, those who normally act as parents. The amendment seeks to make clear who those social parents are. First, natural parents are covered as well as adoptive parents. Secondly, persons acting as guardians are covered. Thirdly, the spouse of such a parent or guardian is also covered. This makes up the range of people who might be regarded as parents. This means, however, that a person could have up to six parents, which is an absurd result. Accordingly, the new definition enables flexibility in identifying the appropriate parent or parents. The mechanism used is discretionary in nature to allow a common-sense approach to be taken in the matter. Of course, a decision taken as to whether a person was a parent would be subject to appeal in the normal way. An explanatory memorandum has been circulated to honourable members concerning this change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not object to the amendments that have been moved by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). However, I would like to take this opportunity to re-emphasise the point I made this morning-that is, Australia now has the most anti-family, anti-child tax system in the Western world. We are now the only Western country not to have a comprehensive tax relief package which recognises the cost of raising children.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has failed to integrate effectively its social security and taxation policies to obtain the necessary national goals which it claims. In fact, the Social Security Review pointed out that Australia's taxation related assistance, including allowances for families with two children, is only half the average provided by other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Yet we have seen over the last five Budgets a consistent attempt by the Government virtually to remove from the taxation system the last vestiges of the programs which have been in place since the days of the Menzies Government, to the effect that people should be looking for vertical as well as horizontal equity in matters such as family relief.

In 1951 tax relief for the taxpayer on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children stood at 21.58 per cent of average weekly earnings. By 1987 this had fallen to 3 per cent, a decline of nearly 20 per cent. Therefore, the relative tax position of middle income families in Australia has been savagely eroded during the last four years because of the Government's failure to increase or index the family allowance, the decision last May to means test the allowance, and the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and medical expenses. As a result of the Hawke Government's policies, even poorer families not affected by means testing have experienced effective tax increases of several hundred dollars a year, and many will not benefit from the Government's poverty package. Historically high mortgage rates have also had a savage impact on family budgets at a time when average real income has fallen dramatically.

As I said in my speech on the second reading, when we talk about poverty in Australian society, it is not simply a case of what benefits may be available from the state. One must also take into consideration the likely impact of employment problems, the question of training for opportunities to enter the work force and, perhaps most significant of all, the capacity and ability for financial reasons of individual Australian families to achieve home ownership in our society. While much credit has been given over the years to the fact that we have over 70 per cent home ownership, the simple fact is that over the last half decade the trend is now falling, and more and more families in the lower income areas, particularly in suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne, are finding it extremely difficult to make ends meet and to provide the necessary finance to meet either loan repayments or rent payments. The provision in this proposal to increase the subsidy for low income earning families by a mere $15 a week by way of a rent subsidy will not, frankly, touch the sides of this problem.

Consequently, in many respects, the Government's family package has failed to compensate for the decline in real disposable income which has occurred during the term of the Labor Government. In fact, over 40,000 families will be caught by the disastrous poverty trap built into the package by the new marginal tax rates and Medicare. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) admitted in the House that the family package would make some lower income families worse off. The imposition of 110 per cent effective marginal tax rates will affect over 40,000 single income families. Yet the Minister has contradicted the Prime Minister and has sought to deny the fact that there will be, and are, serious poverty traps in the proposal in the family package which must be addressed.

The Minister has failed to address the real issue of the combined effects of Labor's new tax scales, the 20c in the dollar Medicare levy and the 50c in the dollar clawback on family allowance supplements which create a poverty trap for one in 12 low income families targeted by the new family package. Therefore, is it any surprise that the University of New South Wales has pointed out that despite the fact that about a quarter of a million low income children will be better off as a result of the Government's proposal, the fact remains that there will still be some 500,000 Australian children living near or below the poverty line? While the Minister assures us that we are only seeing stage one of this proposal, I trust that in the next two years or so we will see a serious attempt by him and this Government to overcome what still remains a very unsatisfactory situation. To help solve the problems of one third of the children in that situation is significant but, as I said earlier, it is not enough.

I draw attention again to the question of the marginal tax rate. Over 40,000 families will be caught by the disastrous poverty traps built in to the Government's family package. Under this new scheme single income families with two children and on $376 a week-which is no fortune, as the Minister is well aware-will actually have 10c less disposable income for every additional dollar they earn. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has estimated that some 20,000 families will be affected by the 110 per cent-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member to be relevant to the clause to which the amendments relate. At the moment he appears to be making a second reading stage speech.

—I am not, Mr Deputy Chairman. Having been here for some years, I recall that the normal practice in committee stage debates of this nature is to have a liberal interpretation of the clauses that can be covered.
—Normally we speak to the amendments, which in this case relate to clause 41.

—One of the significant points of the amendments that have been moved by the Minister and to which we do not object is the whole question of the definition of `the family'. The family is the very essence of the social structure of this nation and we believe that it must be given far greater support than it has had to date. It is precisely for that reason that we are concerned about the number of major poverty traps that are built into the system. For example, families with two children and on $374 to $390 a week, with three children and on $410 to $437, with four children and on $450 to $480 and with five children and on $490 to $520 will be significantly worse off. This creates a complete disincentive for families in these brackets to increase their incomes, as they will actually be better off if they stay on low earnings and remain dependent on social security. In fact, the Government is giving with one hand and grabbing back with the other. It is typical of the hype of this Government and it is important to add that to the revenue and expenditure sides of its equations. Effective marginal tax rates show the effect that an additional dollar of earned taxable income has on the amount of money that a family has at its disposal. Consequently, deductions from this extra dollar are made by both the taxation system, including Medicare, and the Department of Social Security, through the income test.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the objectives of this whole package is to tighten up the capacity of individuals in our society to obtain access to social security benefits. While the economic circumstances facing Australia are extremely difficult, the Opposition supports the Government's objective to reduce social security costs where possible, while doing its best to ensure that those most in need will get first priority. Having said that, I point out that there is still a fundamental problem in relation to the way in which these social policies will impact upon the family. I emphasise this point, whether we are talking about the normal father-mother type family unit, foster families or any other combinations. The simple difficulty we face today is the one that the Institute of Family Studies has emphasised so often-that a family with three children must earn more than $40,000 a year to achieve the same disposable income as that of a childless household on the national average wage. In fact, it has become almost a scandal in our social services and tax systems that a two income family without children is substantially better off financially than any single income family earning an equivalent amount. Those are the fundamental issues which the Opposition believes must be addressed.

I think I should finish on the point that I made earlier: when we look at all the scientific research information which is available to us and the demographic trends in Australian society at present, we see that there is no reason for complacency. At a growth rate of 0.8 per cent we are now well below the reproduction rate. While some people may claim that we can depend virtually on immigration as a means of increasing our population, the simple fact of the matter is that the aging of the Australian population and the demographic make-up of our society is such that we must look most carefully at what elements of Government policy directly contribute to the formation of Australian families and what elements directly reduce that capacity. Therein lies the basis for the ultimate success of our society and that will be the basis upon which we will be tested by future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Committee unduly, other than to say that the schedule of amendments now before the Committee includes an amendment to the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act. That amendment to lines 22 to 24 of clause 109 relates to the date of commencement of the legislation and arises from an oversight in the printing and drafting of the commencement date. The Opposition has no objection to this clause. However, I must point out to the Committee that both the parent Act, the Veterans' Entitlements Act which was passed quite recently in May 1986, and the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act-which some honourable members have suggested in recent times should have been done away with by now and brought under the complete cover of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, given the small number of people covered by it-have been subject to a large number of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) has a particular interest in the fate of seamen in the Nowra end of his electorate. He has to look after many constituents who have a direct interest in this legislation. I want to place on record that in terms of the thrust of all the amendments which are proposed in this important area of legislation dealing with repatriation, it is important that we do not lose sight of the need to ensure that we err in favour of taking proper care of our veterans and that we do not take away proper care, entitlements, benefits and assistance.

In this regard, I mention in passing that in the course of a Senate Estimates committee hearing a fortnight ago I arranged for a series of questions to be asked by Senator Walters and Senator Brownhill. I was able to flush out the fact that three officers of the Department of Finance who were sitting at the back during the examination of the estimates of the Department of Veterans' Affairs formed part of a cell or section in their Department which monitored veterans affairs and which drew up a list of cutbacks in relation to repatriation each time there was a mini-Budget and Budget meeting of Cabinet. I forced those three ladies to name themselves so that their names would be recorded in the Hansard record of proceedings. I did so so that we would have a little less anonymity in regard to such proceedings and a little more accountability about what is going on in the area of repatriation in this country today.

I have just returned from speaking at a function in the northern part of Canberra at which massive concern was expressed over not only a cell in the Department of Finance but also a cell, at one level, in the Department of Veterans' Affairs in which many young lawyers administer the procedures and the determining system of that Department with scant regard for the ex-service personnel, the World War II servicemen and other veterans. We have to be conscious of the fact that many World War II veterans are reaching a critical age at which they require a great deal of assistance. I refer to a situation where that arose at a hearing last week in Canberra; a double amputee had to fight all the way for a totally and permanently incapacitated pension. There is a lot to be concerned about in this regard.

One thing I welcome is that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has made a number of clarifications in this chamber associated with the legislation before the Committee. The Opposition is not opposed to the legislation in general terms, but I serve a note of warning that we will continue to do battle in terms of looking after the interests of those who served their country in time of war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take part in the committee stage of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) because, as we examine the clauses and amendments and identify the fact that they relate to questions of family and the definition of family and family policy, we have to ask ourselves whether we are looking at the matter in its totality as it affects the future of the nation, or are simply addressing an immediate problem. I do not underestimate the significance of the immediate problem for families on low incomes. However, I am concerned that in the way in which the needs of families on low incomes are being addressed, we are creating a structure which will cause more families greater problems than we will relieve families from their present difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: Until the Labor Government came to office there was general acceptance of the view that there should be universal benefits for families. There was a recognition that parents or a parent supporting children should be given some tax allowance, some cash allowance, or a combination of the two, that acknowledged the support that that parent or those parents were providing for their children compared with taxpayers, whether living as couples or living individually, who have no children. Since Labor came to office we have seen the continuous erosion of the benefits being paid to the great body of Australian families supporting children. This has put increasing pressure on them so that in many instances those pressures have been the cause of family breakdown. Such breakdowns have resulted in the need for an increasing number of supporting parents to become dependent on the social security system. Likewise, low income families, because of lack of job opportunities-for the Government has failed to expand the number of job opportunities to make them available to all parents who would like some employment-have not had adequate support.

This legislation provides special benefits to those who satisfy a rigorous means test-a means test which, as my colleague the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has pointed out, has very high effective marginal withdrawal rates. In effect, as a result of legislation introduced by a Labor government we are taxing some families at a rate of 110c for every additional dollar they earn. Admittedly, that loss of child allowance and family allowance supplement is time-lagged. By that device the Minister has said, `Oh, there are not really poverty traps because of the time-lag effect'. But if families do, as most families will, analyse the impact on them of the earning of an additional dollar, they will calculate and understand that the family allowance supplement which should be a universal supplement available to all families is being withdrawn at these very high effective marginal rates.

Though we have heard a good deal in this debate about the amount that this family allowance supplement is costing the Government and that $500m is being directed in favour of families on low incomes, it is noteworthy that $1,110m is being denied to all families. For if the family allowance had been continued in its universal form and had been updated at the rate at which pensions are updated in accordance with consumer price index fluctuations, all Australian families would be receiving an additional $1,110m. But the great majority of Australian families are denied that support. Therefore, we find, even in the Government's social security review, a lot of attention drawn to the fact that all families are in need.

The Government has failed to reconcile two objectives-on the one hand that of alleviating poverty and on the other that of removing the causes of that poverty. The causes of that poverty could, in large measure, be removed if more adequate allowance were made to all parents in recognition of the cost that they bear in maintaining their children. Instead of maintaining the level of support to all families, it is being cut back. Then we say, `Oh we have a poverty problem'. Why do we have a poverty problem? It is because we have not been increasing the universal family allowance to maintain its real value or, in my view, to lift it to a more realistic value related to the cost of maintaining children. Again, many of the studies that have been conducted since the Australian Labor Party came to office have made it quite clear that the amount of support provided, even under the old family allowance system and even if updated in accordance with the cost of living index, would have been inadequate in relation to children of different ages.

This is at a time when we have a population crisis. So often we hear the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) say that we are confronting a time when we shall have an aging population. We mean by that that out of the total population a higher percentage will be in the retired citizens category than has been or is the case. Why is that? Some might say that it is because people are living longer. That is true, but that has been going on for many years. The real reason why we have an aging population is that we have a failing birth rate. We are not replacing our population. We have a negative population growth. If we had a stable or growing population, as a consequence of a rising birth rate, we would not have such concerns about the aging population. There would be more young people, there would be a higher percentage of children, and, as a consequence, the proportion of the population aged 65 or over would be less.

This is a real crisis for Australia. Therefore, we have to ask ourselves whether we want a country that has a stable or growing population or one that is fading away because of its dramatically dropping birth rate. If we want a growing population, we must ask ourselves why the birth rate is failing. These days, it is possible for young couples to choose, and they should have the right to make that choice, family size, child spacing, when the first child is born and so on. But many young couples are being influenced in the size of their families by the economics of our tax and social security system. They know that to have a family of two children it will cost them upwards of $100,000 to carry those children through to over 18 years of age. They know that, as a consequence of the tax and social security system, they will get very little recognition of the cost and resources that they put in to bringing up their families. Until we recognise this fact, we shall continue to have a declining birth rate.

While this legislation helps some of our poor today it will, I believe, be one of those social security mechanisms that will cause more people to fall into the categories of need that the Minister is trying to overcome through this legislation. We will overcome them only when we recognise the true value of all Australian children and when we introduce once again a universal family allowance-a tax rebate, a tax credit system; it does not matter what mechanism, as long as the final outcome is the same for the family.
