TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1987 concurrently with orders of the day Nos 9 to 15. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we debate a package of eight Bills arising from the Government's Budget decisions as they affect Australian education and from other policy decisions taken or foreshadowed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) in statements in this House. I will not take the time of the House in referring to the normal post-Budget machinery that authorises Commonwealth expenditure on tertiary education and schools for the forthcoming calendar year, 1988, nor will I refer to the routine retrospective adjustments to tertiary and school funding for the current year, 1987, in light of actual cost movements occurring in the course of the year. I will confine myself to those departures in policy or practice with which the House must concern itself, and to some central policy issues in the field of education that are of profound national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the area of tertiary education the particular issues I intend to raise are the dearth of finance available to the tertiary sector, resulting in the denial of places to an estimated 20,000 qualified students in 1987, the failure of the Government to maintain the triennial system of funding for higher education while the new Minister attempts to write a new policy for higher education, the introduction of tuition fees for higher degrees, and the proposed changes in funding for research.

With regard to schools, I shall comment on the impact on schools, particularly government schools, of improvements in retention rates, and also on the burden of excessive government regulation on non-government schools. I shall also refer to the Minister's foreshadowed proposals, reflected to some extent in this legislation, to abolish the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC), and to establish instead a National Board of Employment, Education and Training, thus depriving the users and providers of education in Australia of an effective voice in the formulation of public policy.

The Bills include a restructuring of the financial assistance given by the Commonwealth to technical and further education (TAFE), and amendments to student assistance provisions under Austudy. My colleague the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) will draw attention in the course of the debate to the gross failure of the Government to administer Austudy in a manner satisfactory to the recipients of benefits. As these Bills form part of the Government's budgetary framework the Opposition will not seek in either House to block their passage. However, to draw attention to the grave shortcomings in many areas of the Government's education policy and administration, I shall move amendments at the second reading stage of certain of the Bills. I now move the following amendment in relation to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1987:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its failure to administer Austudy student assistance grants in a timely and efficient manner, thus causing grave inconvenience to students and their families'.
I foreshadow that I shall move amendments in relation to other Bills, including to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987, as follows:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-
(1) condemns Government policies which have denied 20,000 qualified students entry into higher education this year and which promise no better performance in 1988;

(2) notes with concern the failure of the Government to maintain the triennial funding system for higher education, thus introducing uncertainty and potential wastefulness into the planning and expenditure of universities, institutes and colleges;

(3) draws attention to the dangers inherent in allowing centralised bureaucratic bodies to decide whether or not research conducted by universities and colleges of advanced education is in the national interest; and
(4) questions the inclusion of funds for key centres for teaching and research as a part of research funding rather than as a separate allocation concerned mainly with the improvement of teaching.
I foreshadow that I shall move the following amendment in relation to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House expresses its concern that the transfer of responsibility from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to the Department of Employment, Education and Training proposed in the Bill is a precursor to the denial of an adequate consultative mechanism and public voice for those directly concerned with running and using Australia's various education systems'.
I foreshadow that I shall move the following amendment in relation to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, this House deplores the excessive regulation by the Federal Government of non-government schools, which is designed both to impose an external value system on those schools and to hamper the growth of non-government schools and thereby limit parent choice'.

The first issue I would like to deal with tonight is the overall level of resources available to higher education. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training in his statement to the House on 22 September last drew attention to the failure of the higher education system to meet the demand for student places at a time when there is widespread recognition of the need for higher levels of participation in the system to meet Australia's economic and social objectives. Some 20,000 qualified students were unable to gain entry to institutions in 1987. On the Minister's calculation we might well face a deficit of 75,000 places by the turn of the century without corrective action being taken.

Whilst the Minister's statement of the problem is welcome, his actions in this Budget package take a backward step along the desired path. The increase in full time equivalent student places in universities and colleges of advanced education (CAEs) will be only 2.1 per cent in 1988 compared with a 2.9 per cent increase in 1983. As the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has pointed out in its recommendations for 1988, this legislation provides an additional $38.4 for increased intakes in higher education. In the May economic statement the Government announced a 1 per cent so-called `efficiency' cut of $22.4m in 1988. Thus the Government has provided a net increase of only $16m in higher education funding, or around 0.7 per cent. In effect, says the Commission, the funding for the additional 3,500 to 4,000 intakes has been offset by the cut in the May statement.

The worrying aspect of this squeeze on funds is that it is being imposed on a system that is already run down. CTEC is especially critical of the levels of equipment and building funding, noting in its 1988 report a `severe backlog in capital needs', and even raising the `distinct likelihood of serious accident through fire or other cause' if such prosaic items as minor works grants are not significantly increased. The rundown in the higher education sector is reminiscent of the late 1950s before the Menzies Government accepted the recommendations of the Murray Committee report, a landmark in the development of education in Australia. Clearly we face another critical period now, but the simple remedy of pouring additional taxpayers' dollars into the system is no longer available as it was in the 1960s. Tax is already too high in Australia, a fact at last recognised by this big spending Labor Government. To quote the Minister directly from his 22 September statement:
In current budgetary and economic circumstances, however, it is simply not feasible to achieve quantum leaps in participation in higher education by providing quantum leaps in public expenditure.

I agree with that. However, the question is: Where will the additional resources come from? The Minister rather judges the question. He cites improved productivity and effectiveness, together with a broadening of the funding base, as part of the solution. He has already caused considerable offence in the university community by berating those over-regulated institutions for their inflexibility and alleged poor performance. It is like overloading a pack-horse and then shouting at the poor beast for stumbling on the slope. The fact is that the Minister will not achieve the objectives he outlines in his statement without allowing the institutions considerably more flexibility in attracting private sources of funds, and then considerably more flexibility in their use of those funds. Setting aside the tuition fees issue for the moment, institutions that were perceived to have more control over their own destiny would be much better placed to attract private business sponsorship. To put company funds into an institution that is seen as little more than a creature of government is almost like sponsoring a branch line of the government railway.

A critical test for autonomy and flexibility in the use of resources is whether or not the institutions will be allowed to deal directly with their staff on salaries and conditions of service. Although the need for flexibility in this area is most commonly raised in connection with faculties competing directly with the private sector for staff, such as commerce, economics or engineering, the issue is far more basic than that. If one wants to set up one of the best philosophy departments in the world-and why not?-the capacity to negotiate flexibly is equally as important as in the more industry related departments. Although the question of flexibility in the use of staff resources is one of the issues to be covered in the Minister's forthcoming policy discussion paper on higher education, it is regrettably clear from the Minister's statement that he is thinking of `industrial relations club' type regulation rather than giving the institutions total freedom to write contracts with their staff as they see fit within their global budgets.

Unfortunately it is not within the power of a Minister in a Labor Government to propose any significant deviation from the pattern of centralised wage fixation, the centrepiece of the Australian Labor Party (ALP)-Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) policy framework. The registration of academic staff unions-surely a contradiction in terms-under the industrial relations system has already advanced the process of solidification of reward systems beyond this Minister's political power to change. There is, however, a far more sinister aspect to this unionisation of higher education, for ultimately academic freedom and excellence are incompatible with trade unionism. Just as the excessive power of industrial unions in Australia has cast a pall of mediocrity over those areas of the economy on which it is inflicted, so too will the application of so-called industrial reality promote mediocrity in the very institutions where mediocrity is a deadly cancer.

Already the effects of academic trade unionism are inhibiting the pursuit of excellence. In some universities the process of choosing the most brilliant post-graduate students for staff positions is inhibited because the positions have been taken by tutors whom it is impossible in the new climate to remove. Constraints of this kind are intolerable in areas of internationally acknowledged excellence and, because all areas in universities should be striving for the best, the constraints are intolerable everywhere. Let me make it clear that I am not arguing against tenure, about which there is much uninformed comment. I am arguing for the right of institutions to make their own sensible decisions about conditions of service, including when and where to confer tenure and on what conditions.

If flexibility in the use of resources is an important goal, so too is flexibility in the attraction of resources. I have already referred to the problem of attracting corporate support. Thus we come to the question of tuition fees, a hook on which the Government is squirming most uncomfortably. The former Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, in keeping with the ALP Federal platform, maintained strong personal opposition to the introduction of fees in any form. She was, however, overruled by Cabinet when the higher education administration charge was introduced. It is no secret that the present Minister wants to change the ALP platform. There is no doubt that the administration charge is a breach of the platform and of ALP campaign promises, as is the measure being debated tonight to allow institutions to charge tuition fees for higher degrees.

The irony of this latter measure is that the present Minister, as shadow Minister for Education in the Labor Opposition, went to the barricades in 1981 against the Fraser Government's proposals to do the very same thing. In a speech to the House of Representatives in 1981, the current Minister said:
It is a direct breach of a promise. That is why we will be opposing that particular legislation.
He went on to say:

Another point that has to be made is that the Government is intent with this legislation on re-establishing the principle of tertiary tuition fees. It is intent on re-establishing a fee collecting mechanism . . . That is why we are intent on opposing it.
He maintained that if the legislation were passed:
It would be a quite simple matter for it in the future, without much fuss or bother, to extend the application of fees to include a vast array of other classes of students.
He continued:

That reason, if no other, is sufficient for us to oppose vigorously the reintroduction of fees. It is not just a question of the impact of fees on the admittedly relatively small group of students to whom they apply; it is the question of preventing the re-establishment of a principle which this Government-
referring to the Fraser Government-
would have no hesitation in extending to include other groups.

It is essential, if higher education is to gain the extra resources it needs, for institutions to have the freedom to gain extra income from tuition fees. In the last election the Opposition proposed a system of higher education scholarships to provide free places in line with currently available and future taxpayer funding capacity.

Over and above the free places, universities and CAEs would be free to accept additional students on any basis they saw fit. Such a system would remove the anomaly whereby overseas students can get fee paying places in higher education, whereas some 20,000 qualified Australian students are denied this opportunity. Such a system would have the additional benefit of providing a stream of private funds to supplement what the taxpayer can provide.

The present Government has no choice but to adopt this, or some other fee system, otherwise its objectives for growth in higher education will fail. In retrospect, it was a mistake of the Whit- lam Government to nationalise higher education, just as it would be a profound mistake to nationalise the independent schools. Our schools would be crippled today if they were wholly dependent on taxpayer funds. Our health system is suffering desperately from the $2 billion nationalisation in 1984 under Medicare, which denied the system that stream of private funds and made it much more dependent on the dwindling taxpayer dollar. So, too, are Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Bank starved of the capital funds they desperately need to compete with private enterprise. This is a generic problem spreading across most parts of public enterprise and service provision. Its outcome is inevitable. The only question is how long it will take for that inevitability to be acknowledged and the pain relieved. From the sound of the current debate in the Labor Party I believe that pain will be protracted.

While the Government frantically tries to change gear in higher education policy, higher education suffers a jolt to its funding system through the abandonment of the triennium that was to begin in 1988. In effect, the Minister has said that his predecessor made such a mess of her job that the Government, after 4 1/2 years in office, needs to start again and the brunt must be borne by the institutions. CTEC has pointedly remarked in its 1988 report on the adverse effects of this policy decision on the planning and expenditure patterns of the institutions. Inevitably, some of the scarce money in the system will be wasted through stop-start inefficiencies.

I now turn to the structural changes in the Government's educational advisory system. One of the Bills in this package has the effect of transferring functions from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to the Department of Employment, Education and Training in preparation for the changes foreshadowed in the Minister's statement of 15 October last entitled `Advisory Structures and the Administration of the Department of Employment, Education and Training'. The plan is to abolish the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the CTEC, to transfer their administrative functions to the Department, and to establish the new National Board of Employment, Education and Training as the Government's principal advisory body.

The more one examines this proposal, the more one is forced to the conclusion that it runs totally against the goal of sensible public debate on the whole spectrum of education issues, and tightens the grip on an already over-centralised and over-regulated set of educational systems. The Minister's objectives sound fine and have been widely applauded. The instruments he chooses to achieve those objectives are, I regret to say, corporatist in nature and ultimately counter-productive.

The Opposition holds no particular brief for the administrative functions of the Schools Commission or the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. They were Federal bureaucracies superimposed on the States and the independent institutions in an attempt to correct perceived shortcomings. They achieved some success, but at the cost of demoralising to some extent the institutions they were designed to regulate, and removing much of their incentive for self-reform and innovation. The effectiveness of the state school systems has not been noticeably improved by the existence of these Federal bureaucracies, even though some of the superimposed programs have been essential to meet the needs of consumers.

The question of what happens to investigatory and advisory functions of these bodies is, however, a different matter. With their independent powers of investigation and publication, and with their broadly representative composition, the commissions have provided an essential counterbalance to the authoritarian tendencies of Federal and State bureaucracies. They have also provided an independent forum for informed public debate on educational issues. In this they have provided a valuable public service.

The commissions are to be replaced by a national board which introduces for the first time into education the Government's corporatist model of control by big government, big business and big unions. The Board of 12 members will consist of four permanent public servants, two ACTU representatives, two representatives of big business, two `education-training providers', and two so-called `independent' members chosen by the Minister. There is no consumer representation at all, and the whole educational system of professionals and administrators other than TAFE gets one of the two places for `education-training providers'. If the Economic Planning Advisory Council is to be any guide to the future operations of the Board, the ACTU will exercise a veto over publications, as Mr Kelty did with the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC). EPAC was castrated by ACTU medievalism. We do not want the same in education. It is particularly distressing to see these developments proceeding in parallel with the unionisation of academic staff, on top of the already existing baleful influence of excessively powerful teacher unions.

The Minister claims that the various educational interests will be accommodated within the advisory councils reporting to the Board. However, unlike the Schools Commission and CTEC, the councils will be allowed to deal only with matters referred to them by the Minister or the Board. They will have no independent powers of investigation or publication. They are effectively gagged.

The Minister has claimed widespread support for this proposal from interested parties. This is not true. Most of the provider and consumer groups have expressed their grave concern over the proposed structure, and these concerns are building up. We will be having more to say on this subject in the lead-up to and consideration of the enabling legislation, which will have to run the gauntlet of the Senate.

The next area of concern prompted by this legislation is research. One of the Bills redirects $5m from general recurrent grants to universities to fund an expansion of special research centres and key centres of teaching and research as well as targeted research activities in the advanced education sector. As CTEC points out, it is puzzling as to why the funding of the key centres of teaching and research, concerned primarily as they are with the improvement of teaching methods, should be placed under the Australian Research Council (ARC) umbrella.

However, I have far more serious concerns about the direction of research funding. I will leave for a future debate the important question of the allocation of research funding between institutions, including CAEs. At this stage I confine myself to sounding a warning about the ARC component of the new national board structure, the dangers of bureaucracy overwhelming excellence in the field of research, and also the dangers of the Government's understanding of what constitutes the national interest.

As Minister for Health in 1982, I blocked an Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) proposal to consolidate Australian biomedical research into a statutory authority. In an area where Australia has achieved universally acknowledged standards of excellence under the aegis of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and other funding mechanisms, it would have been a grave mistake in my view to have consolidated and placed under a single administration the variety of activities that had provided both flexibility and excellence of outcome. The ARC proposal comes from the same source, ASTEC. So far the capture of the NHMRC has been resisted, but the same thinking is there, and I think it is dangerous. Centralisation, bureaucratisation, ossification and mediocrity go hand in hand. Competition for funds on the criterion of excellence is the only way to ensure that research money is spent wisely. The farther one gets from the researchers themselves in the conduct of these events, the more the risk of declining standards.

As a member of the Myer Committee on Research Centres of Excellence in Universities and from my extensive contacts with Australia's outstanding biomedical researchers, I have a horror of the rigorously competitive drive for excellence of these people being depreciated by the intrusion of the utterly different cast of mind of the public sector administrator. This is not to depreciate the essential and valuable contribution of the latter to the national good, but merely to recognise the proper place for that contribution.

The same arguments apply to the so-called national interest criterion for the allocation of research funds, which has already been applied to the award of a proportion of postgraduate awards and is intended to be incorporated in the ARC arrangements. Is the national interest best advanced by a vast number of independent decisions about research made according to the criterion of excellence, or by a Canberra-based structure advised by people remote from day to day research practice? Let me quote directly from a recent speech made by Professor David Penington, Vice-Chancellor-elect of the University of Melbourne and an eminent medical research scientist:

We are told now that research should increasingly be targeted to fields designated as in the national interest. We are told that some sections of our universities should receive no funding for research and be committed solely to teaching. The Federal Minister makes the statement that no university will receive funding for research in all of its disciplines. Even more remarkable is the statement `that research successes have been more by accident than design' . . . So much of our success has been accidental and due to extraordinary efforts or extraordinary brilliance of a minority of people.

One is tempted to react with anger or irritation and to state that the Minister simply does not understand the research process. Indeed, there is a profound danger that if these views were to dictate the imminent re-shaping of Australian science and technology, we would find ourselves committed to applied research only.

There is an analogy here with the problem of underinvestment in Australian industry. The ACTU, in Australia Reconstructed, argues for tripartite-that is government, business and union-decision-making about the direction and extent of business investment on an industry by industry basis. It is argued that such a process advances the national interest more than having a myriad of individual and corporate investors risking their own or their shareholders' funds in ventures for which they take complete responsibility, with the penalty of going broke if they fail. I have no doubt as to which system I would choose.

The other dangerous overtone of the Minister's approach, which reminds me of British Prime Minister Harold Wilson's infatuation in the 1960s with the white heat of the technological revolution, is its tendency to depreciate the role of the humanities in advancing the national interest. Every so often governments get it into their heads that they can force an outcome out of the higher education system by fiddling with the immediately visible controls. They simply do not understand that the shortcomings of the system, of which there are many, are more deep-seated, and many of them derive from government regulation.

Finally, let me turn to the schools, where time constraints limit me to two concerns. The first concern is the very grave difficulties being faced by schools, particularly government schools, in handling the greater numbers of secondary students arising from the admirable objective of improving retention rates. Unfortunately, the interests and requirements of many of the students now deciding to remain at school do not coincide with the curriculum currently available in our high schools nor with the teaching skills or experience of the majority of high school teachers.

Additionally, the management systems of the schools and their disciplinary powers appear to be inadequate to cope with the needs of these students. The strain on the teachers is extreme in some schools. Much more attention must be devoted to problems of this nature if the objectives of higher retention rates are to have any meaning other than in the statistics proudly quoted by the Government.

The second concern I have is in the regulation, or over-regulation, of non-government schools. The Government has an underlying dislike of non-government schools, reflected in the highly restrictive policies introduced by Senator Ryan. Unfortunately, the present Minister seems not to want to overturn this particular aspect of his predecessor's program. Two aspects of Federal Government regulation are irking non-government schools. The first is the imposition of social values by regulation, with the schools having to report to the Government on their progress in imposing within their schools certain values seen by the Government as desirable. Since most of the non-government schools base their very existence on strongly held value systems, many of them resent this kind of intrusion. They regard the choice of the parents in these matters as the guiding principle.

The second aspect of regulation causing concern is something equivalent to the Japanese system of non-tariff barriers to imports. Because of the strong public demand for places in non-government schools, those schools are constantly seeking to expand to meet the demand. In this objective they are frustrated not only by the restrictive guidelines imposed by the Government with the intention of limiting growth, but also by the over zealous application of those rules by officers of the Department. I am hearing more and more stories of this kind. As the Opposition does not agree with the original policy decision to restrict non-government school growth, it is equally opposed to this bureaucratic frustration. It is ludicrous for non-government school administrators to spend as much time as they do providing more and more material to be second guessed by departmental officers.

This debate provides one of the few opportunities we have throughout the year to examine the stewardship of the Government in the field of education. Other Opposition speakers will examine various aspects of the Government's performance as far as time permits. Disraeli said:
Upon the education of the people of this country, the future of this country depends.

Issues of the most profound importance to our future are now on the agenda. In our schools there are questions about curriculum and assessment, as well as management and discipline. In TAFE there are questions of the relevance of training to our national economic needs. In higher education there are questions of resources, of academic freedom and excellence and of the future direction of research. It is hard to think of more important questions affecting Australia's future.

I want to make it clear that the Opposition is ready to support constructively any changes for the better in our education system. However, in contributing to this debate, we will be arguing for choice and quality and against enforced uniformity and mediocrity. It is our strongly held view that our systems at all levels of education are over-centralised and over-regulated. They are provider rather than consumer driven. They are too inflexible to meet our present and future needs, but much of that inflexibility is externally imposed. Within the systems there are creative, intelligent and energetic people wanting to achieve and to excel. Everything we do as legis- lators should be designed to encourage them, not frustrate them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—I am pleased to speak to this package of eight education Bills following the recent Commonwealth Budget. I am particularly pleased to do so as part of a government which is looking at the exciting challenge of bringing together strands of employment, education and training under the one portfolio. I was rather concerned at the anxieties felt by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who delineated a number of areas in higher education where he would like to see winds of change. A number of the aspects to which he referred have been given serious consideration in the House by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). The task force on higher education which has been established by the Secretary to the Department of Employment, Education and Training will examine a number of resource related issues, including some of those mentioned by the honourable member for Mackellar.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mrs DARLING

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the areas being considered by the task force will be growth rate targets; resources required and means of achieving these; general productivity issues; options for a unified system of higher education; concentration of effort in teaching and research; scope, scale and provision of external studies courses; means of achieving flexibility in staff resources; and means of enabling institutions selectively to increase revenue from non-Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) sources. In fact, a policy discussion paper will be issued towards the end of the year as already announced by the Minister and will be used as a basis for consultation and community comment. Following consideration of response to this paper, the Government will present its long term policies in the form of a major policy statement which will be finalised in the 1988-89 Budget context.

INTERJECT.PARA: So, overall, I would suggest that the honourable member for Mackellar would indeed have reason to be anxious were he at the moment in a parliament and in a government which were sticking to the old, static structures of the past, a government and an education system which were being hurt by benign neglect of the past. But in fact, the honourable member for Mackellar is in the Opposition of a parliament which is noted for a government of thought and a government ready to change the education system for the better, and most particularly for the better of young people and those Australians who have not been having a fair deal in the past.

Whilst the provision of education in Australia is primarily a public responsibility, it should not necessarily be seen as the total responsibility of a government. All sectors of society are involved. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training noted when tabling his statement on higher education in this House on 22 October 1987 that it is more than coincidence that the world's most successful economies over recent years have given high priority to basic education and vocational preparation of their young people. The two factors are obviously very closely linked. While education on the whole is the prerogative of State governments, the quality of education available to people should certainly not depend upon what State they live in. Concern for equity in schooling across the nation has led the Commonwealth Government to accept a responsibility for meeting special educational needs over and above the broad State responsibility to allocate major educational funding. The Commonwealth Government sees its particular responsibility as meeting the special educational needs to ensure the overall quality of education in Australia.

Education has both individual and social objectives. In the national interest we strive to heighten the quality of education provided by the school system. Firstly, of course, we must assess quality. We do so at national, economic and social levels to fit our policies to conjointly meet those needs. In this context, it is the Hawke Government's policy to continue to provide funding for tertiary education in the States and the Northern Territory and to increase that funding as necessary with increases in the cost of living.

Of the package of Bills before the House, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987 provides financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory for tertiary education in 1988. It transfers administrative responsibility for Commonwealth tertiary education programs to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. This Bill will appropriate $2,707m for grants to tertiary education as it continues funding for universities, advanced education, technical and further education (TAFE) and non-government business colleges in 1988.

The funds allocated by the Bill accord with the Government's decisions in response to the report by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, Higher Education Recommendations for 1988, and give effect to the announcements on TAFE made in the Government's report Skills for Australia at the time of the Budget. The Bill has been simplified both in structure and presentation. More plain language has been used and schedules for grants of a similar nature with common conditions are now combined. For example, the schedules for higher education capital and equipment grants cover both universities and colleges of advanced education.

While our education system must retain its own personality, it makes sense that both educational programs and training schemes lead to people being able to realise their full potential personally and in the work-place. This means real education and real training for real jobs. This must be our aim. The pulling together of the equally important strands of education, employment and training under the one portfolio is a real move towards realising this aim. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the Government and the community have a big job ahead overhauling the higher education and training systems to meet the needs of all Australians, of young people in particular.

We invite Opposition members to work with us. We think it is appropriate as they consider the Bills before us tonight that, instead of harking back to a past that was noted often for its lack of dynamism which has adversely affected young Australians in the past, they join us as we look at the establishment of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) along the lines proposed by Charles Halton as part of the challenge providing the practical structure for the implementation of our new joint policies. The Minister is now working with Mr Halton to ensure that the best aspects of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and CTEC are reflected in NBEET. I assure the honourable member for Mackellar that Government members are aware of the worth of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and of CTEC, but we are looking to a new era in which we cannot afford to let young people down by sticking to educational purity and not dirtying our hands with training and not bringing these two aspects together because what was in the past is always best. Only privileged people who are comfortably in full time employment can afford to take that stance. We need to educate our young people, to train them for real jobs. That is what both the formulation of NBEET and the Green Paper on higher education are all about.

The honourable member for Mackellar also mentioned the structure of the new Board. He expressed concern that there would not be enough diversity of opinion on the membership of the Board. I would like to make the point that discussions are still taking place and that the Minister is undertaking a strenuous timetable meeting community groups. I am very aware of this as the chairperson of the relevant Caucus committee. The Minister is also putting in many hours meeting with us, as are the interest groups to which the honourable member referred.

Four advisory councils will report to NBEET: the Schools Council, Higher Education Council, Employment and Skills Formation Council and the Australian Research Council. The Board will have a full time chairman and three full time executive members, as well as, in certain circumstances, one part time executive member. The Board will consist of 12 or 13 members all up. I think it is pertinent to note that the chairperson and the three executive members will also be chairpersons of the councils-the Schools Council, the Higher Education Council, the Employment and Skills Formation Council and the Australian Research Council. They will have a double voice being on one of the councils as well as on the Board. Part time members will include two union representatives, two business and industry representatives and two education training providers. There is also an independent membership of two or three, so the Minister can look to even up the overall representation. He has taken pains to see that there will be full representation.

While the Federal Government is meeting the need to improve and expand the higher education system, results will be realised only if all key parties make their contribution. The demands on the higher education sector are increasing, but these demands cannot be matched simply through increased expenditure. Expenditure will need to be carefully balanced across sectors and priorities set. Important changes are required in the higher education system to meet Australia's economic and social needs. The Government is also taking a lead here in issuing the Policy Discussion Paper on Higher Education, to which I have already referred.

Of the remaining Bills before the House, the Australian National University Amendment Bill 1987, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill 1987 and the Maritime College Amendment Bill 1987, will ensure consistency of treatment with tertiary education in the States and the Northern Territory as a consequence of the new States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987. The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 amends the 1984 States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act to provide grants for the 1988 calendar year, in line with the recent Government decisions, and to supplement existing grants for 1987 and 1988 for price movements. The Bill sets aside an estimated $1,739m for school programs in the calendar year 1988, consisting of $1,339m for general recurrent grants, $222m for capital grants and $178m for specific purpose grants. The Bill also appropriates a further $9m for 1987 programs, for price increases in line with retrospective cost supplementation arrangements. This brings total funding for 1987 programs to an estimated $1,638m.

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 amends the 1984 States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act to adjust for cost movements in tertiary education grants to the States and the Northern Territory, providing $3m supplementation in accordance with the Government's agreed procedures to make retrospective adjustments for cost variations. The Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1987 limits the extent to which Austudy is payable to students in private sector institutions.

The final Bill, the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, amends the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Act 1983 to adjust grants available to government and non-government education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory to conduct projects under the participation and equity program (PEP) in 1987. The Federal Government's PEP commenced in 1984 with the objectives of increasing participation and achieving greater equity in educational provision. Initial legislation provided for the years 1984 to 1986, but in May 1985 it was decided that the program should be extended for an additional year. The program has played an important role influencing the direction of education at both the secondary and primary levels. Through the stimulus of PEP there is now a large measure of self-sustaining momentum in school systems and schools. It most definitely has left its mark. PEP is to cease at the end of this year and I am sure that many members on both sides of the House will regret that it is to go. This Government's commitment to ensuring participation and equity in Australia's education system will most certainly continue.

The significant, real per capita increases to schools, under the general recurrent grants program, and the priority areas identified for the use of these extra funds will ensure the continuation of initiatives begun under PEP. The Federal Government will continue to support improvements in the quality of schooling and will provide additional resources for schools to support the specific educational needs of particular groups of students. Money alone will not make education effective if it is not wisely spent. For instance, Queensland is the only one of all the Australian States which has not endorsed the national policy on the education of women and girls. All other States have endorsed the policy of shared principles, objectives and priorities for the period 1987-89 aimed at widening educational options for girls.

The Queensland Teachers Union has called on the Queensland Government to endorse the national policy and implement it in co-operation with other States. But while other States' education departments have special units in this area for teacher in-service education, and a number of other areas, the Queensland Government ignores the special educational needs of Queensland school girls. So the education dollar must be targeted to fulfil needs. There is not any point, as has happened in the past, in providing academic subjects or subjects which would well fit a student for a job in a city store if the student is living, and intends to work, in a rural area based on agriculture or in a fishing community. The new youth training program, which will commence in 1988, will take over from PEP initiatives in TAFE by providing a range of short term vocational training opportunities for unemployed and disadvantaged young people.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission reported in its review Quality and Equality that, of all citizens, children are least able to protect or further their interests on their own behalf. I agree that this is particularly so for those children who, through no fault of their own, face educational, economic or social disadvantage. As they grow into young adulthood their opportunities should not be limited by their parents' capacity to provide education. The quality of education available to people certainly should not depend upon what State they live in or how much money their local parents and citizens can raise. Equity for schooling should exist across the nation. Furthermore, education should be linked to training and both should result in people entering the job market equipped with skills which befit them for real job opportunities. Despite the disadvantage of the extremely unstable economic situation inherited in 1983 as the result of past neglect, the Hawke Government is acting to meet this joint challenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw the House's attention to two matters in regard to this great raft of Bills we are dealing with in one batch tonight and they both relate to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. The first matter about which I want to complain is the way in which the Government has applied restrictions to non-government schools in western Sydney. I have before me a letter from Mr Howard Garner, Director, New Schools Section of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which he has written to people interested in non-government schools. Enclosed with that letter is a list of schools in New South Wales which are limited in their ability to attract additional students.

SPEECH.PARA: One-third of all schools in New South Wales that are capped are in western Sydney, a most deprived area educationally and socio-economically. Yet the Government is sticking the boot into people in Australian Labor Party (ALP) electorates, ignoring the commitment of parents and endeavouring to limit the opportunities that parents want for their kids. The schools are ordinary schools. I will read the names of some of them: Blacktown Christian Community School, Blue Mountains Grammar School, Broughton Anglican College, Catherine McAuley High School at Westmead, Eagle Vale Catholic Primary School, Erskine Park Catholic Secondary School, Immaculate Heart of Mary Primary School at Quakers Hill, Kenthurst Catholic Primary School, Kenthurst Catholic Secondary School, Macarthur Christian College at Menangle Park, Menai Catholic Primary School and the list goes on. Thirty-odd schools of that type are being prevented by the Government from providing the service that the parents of western Sydney want. Those parents are prepared to put their money and effort on the line. The Government says that, despite the shortage of educational resources in that part of New South Wales, despite the overcrowding in many public schools, despite the commitment of parents, despite the low incomes and the difficulty in finding employment, it is determined to restrict educational opportunity.

, Government members have bleated tonight about the equity that this Government is supposedly bringing to education. I can see no equity being demonstrated towards parents and children, especially to needy children who need a good education, who are determined to do the best for themselves and for their parents. They are being restricted by a government which is uncaring, a government which aims to take complete control of the non-government sector by squeezing it. The schools to which I refer range right across the west, in suburbs such as St Marys, Erskine Park, Blacktown and Rouse Hill. These are not wealthy suburbs; these are suburbs in which battlers live. The Government is prepared to put the boot into battling families in this way.

What is being done by this Government is criminal. It is the ideological bent of the former Minister for Education, the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan), and the current Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to restrict educational opportunities. Why else would they apply these restrictions to ordinary schools attended by ordinary children? For the first time we have seen intervention at a level never before seen in Australia. Schools are being made to comply with the whims of the Government. Not only has the Minister for Employment, Education and Training limited educational opportunity in primary and secondary schools, but also by that process he is restricting kids' access to tertiary education. The Australian Labor Party equivocated for years about a university in the west. It finally decided on a half-baked idea, which is proceeding. It looks as though the city of Blacktown will get a steel mill, but it will not get a university. The university will be out there somewhere. So much for the heart of western Sydney. Government members really deserve censure for their lack of support for their constituents and their lack of ability to convince the Government of the priorities that it ought to have. Across the west people are looking for opportunities and jobs. Education will lead them to those opportunities and jobs. The Government is supposedly applying these restrictions in order to achieve its objectives. What a crazy set of priorities!

Another important area concerning the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) that I want to deal with tonight relates to English as a second language (ESL)-the big matter for public discussion following the Budget in 1986. There were dramatic cuts to ESL programs. The Government has claimed that it has restored the level of funding. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his statement on the ALP immigration and ethnic affairs policy, launched in Melbourne on 18 June 1987, said:

I should say that the Government is committed to maintaining sufficient levels of funding flows to general ESL programs, in recognition of the need to ensure that people of non-English speaking background are not disadvantaged in Australian society, and that the education and skills they bring to this country can be fully utilised to the benefit of all Australians.

What are the facts? Funding for the ESL program is down in total by another 4 per cent on last year's cuts. Certainly the new arrival program has been increased, but funding for the total program is down, including the program that gives significant support to language teaching. That provides assistance for specialists and/or mainstream teachers to address the English language needs of students of non-English speaking backgrounds. So the in-service and in-school training for teachers is up, and the new arrival program is up slightly, but the total program in real terms falls by 8.5 per cent. So much for the Prime Minister's commitment made during the election campaign. So much for the Government's commitment. I do not think that this Government can be trusted. Even in the Australian Capital Territory where there is no support from a State government, similar cuts have been made-a total fall of 4.5 per cent or 8.5 per cent in real terms. This reflects the falls that have been felt around Australia. In the Australian Capital Territory there is no advantage of a State government to plug the holes as necessary.

Despite the claims of the Prime Minister, the proof of the pudding is there-the proof that his commitments cannot be given endorsement and cannot be trusted. How can anyone trust this Government? Before the last election the migrant communities around Australia were most concerned. The McNair Anderson poll indicated the number of migrant families and newcomers who distrusted the Government's commitments. It also showed the number of migrant communities that were concerned about the English as a second language programs. Even Senator Richardson and the Premier of New South Wales described the language cuts as `stupid' but those programs have not been restored. They have been nowhere near restored. On 23 September last year the Sydney Morning Herald reported Barrie Unsworth as saying:
Ethnic groups will feel your Government has lost touch with their needs.
That is a quote from Premier Unsworth. Senator Richardson said something similar. In the Canberra Times of 10 November 1986 he is reported to have said:

If I'd sat down for a month and tried to work out how to offend and how best to hurt [ethnic groups] I'd have cut back English as a Second Language as a program . . . That decision was not only bad politics, it was wrong in principle and wrong in implementation.
The implementation continues to be wrong. The Government's own Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services, the Jupp Committee, stated:

At the school level, a survey by the Commonwealth Department of Education and Youth Affairs in 1983 found that around 23 per cent of children enrolled in schools in Australia (approximately 690,000 students) came from homes in which at least one of the parents or guardians normally spoke a language other than English. While it is not suggested that all of these children would have been experiencing language-related learning difficulties in school, a recent review of the Commonwealth English as a Second Language Program (CESLP) found that 55 per cent of those in need of specialised English as a second language (ESL) assistance in the schools surveyed were not receiving it.

The Government has done nothing to lift the program as advised by its own Ministers, by the Jupp Committee report-a committee of the Government-and by report after report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. These reports all say that English as a second language is the most significant program one can give to young people.

I would like to quote to the House just one further significant report. However, there are three or four of them-anyone can look them up. They are reports from the Commonwealth Schools Commission in 1985, 1986 or whichever year. All these reports say the same thing about the significance of English as a second language. I wish to quote from the Schools Commission report of 1984 because the facts still stand. The Commission had recently received a report of the review of the program undertaken by Professor Campbell, the very distinguished Professor from the University of Queensland. The report of the Campbell Committee of Review of the Adult Migrant Education Program revealed a serious deficiency in the provision of resources for students of non-English speaking backgrounds in need of English as a second language assistance and in the way in which many schools responded to these needs.

According to the report, many students of non-English speaking backgrounds do not proceed far beyond a coping or survival level in English language competence. What has the Government done in the face of that criticism? It has restricted the increase in funding to a one-year, on-arrival program only. There is no sense of continuity or follow-up. There is just one year's basic English as a crash program for kids who do not have English as their basic language. The Government hopes that that will provide those children with the basis for further education and a capacity to move through the school system. Of course it will not.

How can children conceptualise the abstracts of education, the need to express themselves, the need to understand the ideas that they will be faced with in secondary and tertiary education if they do not have a sound grounding in the English language? The Government's program is one of walking away from basic responsibilities. It is putting in place an increased program with increased resources. In total, expenditure on the program is down but the real reason why it has been cut is that there is no follow-up or continuity program. It is a one-off, one-year crash course for non-English speakers.

I do not know how these people will survive in a competitive society such as we have at the moment. I do not know how they will survive in secondary schools and achieve their potential there. Nor do I know how they will survive when they come to look for tertiary education. Senator Ryan had the goodness of heart to say late in the event of 1986 that she was sorry. Being sorry for a lost generation is not enough. This House knows it. Honourable members opposite know it. The Senate knows it. However, the Government apparently does not understand. What is wrong with Government members? Why do they not make the Government understand? They have the committees and the other processes by which to do this. As members of the Australian Labor Party, they claim to belong to a democratic organisation in which there is a long tradition of everybody having an equal say. What about an equal say for some of the kids who will miss out on opportunities as a result of their policies, their programs and their broken promises? I can hardly understand why this is so, although maybe I can, because ego seems to be more important to the Prime Minister than substance. I can hardly understand how the Prime Minister could make the claims he did before the recent Federal election and then not deliver those in the programs following the election.

I refer to a recent revealing inquiry chaired by Dr James Jupp. The Government has shelved that inquiry, by the way. It was supposed to be in two sections and although one part has been done, there is no talk of a second one. Dr Jupp had a project team look at the English language problem. The team reported:

The language barrier was identified by most participants as a major factor to which they ascribed many of their problems, frustrations and anxieties. It was described as a crucial problem in all areas of their Australian life, adversely affecting their social functioning and general well-being. This was despite the fact that a large proportion (47.5 per cent of those consulted) had been in Australia for 15 years or over.

That is the priority people are putting on the acquisition of language in Australia. The same flippant attitude is being adopted in regard to the national language policy. That policy has been so long in gestation that nobody knows what it is about, except for some bleating comments now and again from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to groups who happen to want to interview him about it. However, from reports I have had the program is going to be economically based. It will be based on both existing and potential trade relations. The honourable member might be a good Minister but I do not know how he will predict what will happen to trade over the next 20 years and who we will be trading with.

The Minister is going to select the languages that will be taught as part of a national language policy on the basis of trade processes and trade potential. But what about the services required in this country for multilingual speakers to provide services in welfare and health and many other areas for those people who are not competent in English? That is another important area in which we need good language skills. What about our capacity in diplomacy-not just in the area of trade, in buying and selling? I refer to the capacity to communicate effectively with countries with whom we have contact around the world and with whom we must have good understanding. We have a pool of resources in Australia waiting to be used and which, with some slight government encouragement, can be used effectively in programs through schools and universities, then in the foreign service, welfare services, education and health. This is an area completely neglected by this Minister.

The Opposition is not about dumping people in Australia and hoping that they survive. This area is high in our policy priorities. One brief extract from our policy says that we will give priority to English language training programs, in particular the teaching of English as a second language, because this Government is bringing people to Australia and dumping them here, expecting them from their own resources after 12 months of intensive English language for children to be able to survive in a competitive society. The Government's concept of looking after people is far from all the reports and authorities which the Government has established to advise it. Even the recent addition to government advice, the Office of Multicultural Affairs (OMA), is giving high priority to the English language. It is the top item in its recent publication A Fair Go and a Fair Share: Access and Equity for All. The English language is up front there. I refer honourable members to page 13 of this document where speaking everybody's language is the top priority given by OMA for Australians of non-English speaking background. We have had report after report, yet the Prime Minister had the hide to make the promises he made in the last election and then not deliver. Not one person in the Australian Labor Party is prepared to stand up and be critical, not one individual of you. You are gutless, the whole lot of you. You do not represent the people you are supposed to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will speak through the Chair.
—Certainly, Madam Speaker. I would not like to use those terms in reference to you. Therefore, I spoke directly to the members in the chamber.
—No, the honourable member must speak through the Chair.

—Many mechanisms can be used by those of us in politics to draw the attention of the Government, particularly the Executive, to matters where they fall short. These are two important matters. The kids of western Sydney and the children of non-English speaking migrants need support and a worthwhile English language program and, in the former case, need decent schools and educational opportunity. They are not getting them from the Hawke Government, nor will they ever.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Union of Soviet Socialist Republics-Compensation: Commonwealth Employees

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Humphreys) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics celebrated the seventieth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution. It is appropriate that this event should be acknowledged here, for it was certainly a significant event and has had a profound effect on the history of the world. The achievements of the Soviet Union in the 70 years since its inception should be recorded, for they are indeed quite remarkable. Its first achievement is that this regime, in the 70 years since it was established, has been unable even to feed its own population. It has also been unable to provide its people with anything remotely like the standard of living that Western democracies have been able to provide for their populations.

SPEECH.PARA: In 70 years it has attained such little popular support from its population that it still today has to reign by the same terror that brought it to power. This is certainly a remarkable achievement, as is the fact that even after 70 years it cannot afford to allow its people the slightest glimmer of freedom or the most elementary human rights. It remains in power after 70 years because it controls every aspect of human life of the unfortunate people who still live under its rule.

Outside its own boundaries, it has succeeded in subjecting to its rule millions of people who have never been asked whether they want to live under Soviet rule or not. It exterminated millions of human beings in the Ukraine; it invaded the Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia; it imposed a vassal-like dominion over Finland; and it incorporated into its empire East Germany, Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria and other countries, all of which it continues to occupy. As a consequence, it suppressed the freedom of millions and continues to do so with scarcely any protest from the West.

Not content with this empire and the denial of basic human rights to anyone touched by its rule, it has continued to foment revolution with the clear objective of extending its influence well beyond its borders and into Africa, Asia, the Pacific, South America and beyond. In doing so, it has tried to acquire a new respectability, which it is helped in acquiring by the same societies that it would seek to undermine. For example, when our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visits the Soviet Union on his pilgrimage in a few weeks, he will apparently sign a new agreement with the Soviet Union to promote, believe it or not, sporting contacts between the Soviet Union and Australia. As we know, sporting contacts have become the main target in the current campaign against South Africa. Over the last few days, Mr Pat Cash in particular has been singled out for the venom of the Prime Minister for having the audacity to earn his livelihood and promote his future by playing tennis in South Africa. What do we find but that the Prime Minister is now going off, turning a blind eye to years of atrocities in the Soviet Union, and actually encouraging closer sporting contact between Australia and the Soviet Union. What utter hypocrisy!

TALK.START.PARA: —How selective.

—As my colleague says, what utter hypocritical selectivity the Prime Minister shows. What an irony it is that we should actually be promoting new sporting contacts with a country that denies a democratic vote not to part of its population, like South Africa, but to all of its population.

SPEECH.PARA: As the seventieth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution passes, we should remember, in sorrow, that we are noting the foundation of a state that remains as much today, as it was 70 years ago, based on force, terror, imperialism and the denial of all human rights to its own people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a proposal which is being considered, a proposal which causes me considerable concern and which represents an attack on the rights of all workers employed by the Commonwealth and its instrumentalities. Consideration is being given to possible amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. The effect of the amendments, if they go ahead in the form presently proposed, will be to abolish the common law rights of all those who work for this Government and its instrumentalities to recover damages for injuries suffered in the course of their work as the result of any breach of duty by the Government as an employer.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some Press and media reaction which is not unfavourable to the proposed abolition of the common law rights of Commonwealth employees. The Press in this country has never been shy in calling for the abolition of the perks of the fat cats of the Public Service. Common law rights are not a perk and those affected are not fat cats. The workers represented by the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union, the Australian Public Service Association, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, the Australian Transport Officers Federation, the Miscellaneous Workers Union and the Federated Clerks Union will all be affected by the removal of rights available to other members of the community in situations in which they suffer a loss as the result of the negligent breach of duty by their employer.

Whenever a lawyer speaks of the right to sue somebody for damages for injury, he does so to cries of self-interest. I am not ashamed that I have acted for many people seriously injured on the roads or in the workplace. If anything, that experience has brought me closer to the real needs and aspirations of those whose earning capacity or enjoyment of life has been permanently diminished as the result of the fault of another party. The evolution of the common law concept of the rights and duties that members of the Australian community owe one another is a concept which was hard won and of which we can be proud. The community generally is comfortable with a system that provides that where an employer chooses to disregard safety standards and put workers at risk he can be sued by those workers for any loss or injury that results.

Those who argue in favour of the abolition of this basic and fundamental right say that the present system costs too much and that the common law sacrifices the aims of rehabilitation in favour of pecuniary compensation. These are spurious arguments. The abolition of the common law right cannot be justified on the ground that it is a disincentive to rehabilitation. Nor can that loss be justified on economic grounds. Both those arguments were used by the Government in Victoria in 1985 to justify the introduction of its WorkCare scheme. Today, two years down the track, the Victorian WorkCare scheme is facing a huge deficit blowout and the prospect of a massive increase in premiums. The Government in that State has admitted that injured workers have no incentive to return to the work force and is undertaking drastic reforms in an effort to forestall a backlash from employers, trade unions and the community at large. In a mere two years WorkCare has generated roughly $2.4 billion in unfunded liabilities. A worse blowout could hardly be imagined. And the much-vaunted claims that WorkCare would be an incentive for injured workers to return to the work force--
